Titular: Freeport says “now not the time” for deal with Barrick Gold
Texto: Freeport-McMoran’s chief executive dismissed reports it could sell its giant Grasberg copper mine in Indonesia to rival Barrick Gold, saying “now’s just not the time” for any deals.“Now’s just not the time for Freeport to think about doing a big strategic move,” Richard Adkerson told the BMO mining conference in Florida.Barrick Gold’s chief executive Mark Bristow has said he is interested in buying the Grasberg copper and gold mine in Indonesia, and has had conversations with Mr Adkerson.Located 14,000 feet above sea level in Papua, the Grabserg mine is the world’s second-largest copper mine and the world’s largest gold mine.But Mr Adkerson said the time was not right for any deal since the mine was moving from open pit mining to underground mining, and Freeport’s stock was also “just too cheap.”“Now is not simply the time for us to think about doing anything,” he said. “I talk to our shareholders and there’s consistent support for that.”Shares in Freeport-McMoran have fallen by 14 per cent year-to-date on lower copper prices and concerns over the impact of the coronavirus.

Titular: Freeport turns to artificial intelligence to raise copper output by 90,000 tonnes
Subtitular: US company to roll out machine learning technology across mines in the Americas
Texto: Freeport-McMoran, one of the world’s biggest copper producers, is targeting a 90,000-tonne increase in annual output from the introduction of machine learning technology at its mines.The US-listed company has been testing an artificial intelligence model at its Bagdad mine in Arizona, which it is now planning to roll out across all of its operations in the Americas. The move will lift its yearly copper production by about 5 per cent.“We have set an aspirational goal of adding 200m pounds [90,000 tonnes] of copper from these initiatives with very little capital investment,” Richard Adkerson, chief executive, said in an interview in London.Copper is critical to the switch away from fossil fuels to renewable energy, with the red metal used in wind turbines, batteries that power electric vehicles and charging points.Typically a project to develop new capacity for 90,000 tonnes of copper, worth about $500m at current prices, would cost about $1.5bn to $2bn and involve buying new haul trucks, giant shovels and ore crushing equipment.“It’s been a remarkable success,” Mr Adkerson said of the trial, which has boosted production at Bagdad by 9,000 tonnes this year.Compared with many other sectors, the level of technological maturity in mining is still relatively low. But that is starting to change as the industry faces pressure to reduce carbon emissions and its physical footprint.At ageing deposits such as Bagdad — where prospectors first staked their claims in 1882 and most of the best copper has been extracted — miners are having to crush more lower-grade rock just to sustain output.The machine learning model, which Freeport developed with McKinsey, the consultancy, uses data from sensors around the mine and suggests new ways to improve the performance of its crushers and processing mills, according to the company.The system found that the mine was producing seven distinct types of ore and that the processing method, which involves the use of large flotation tanks, could be adjusted to recover more copper by adjusting the PH level.The machine-learning programme is one of three major initiatives Freeport says will boost copper production by 30 per cent. The other projects are the transition to underground mining at its giant Grasberg mine in Indonesia and the Lone Star, a new copper development in Arizona.Concerns about the Grasberg underground project have weighed on Freeport’s share price, which has flatlined this year. However, Mr Adkerson, said the Grasberg project was very different to Oyu Tolgoi, the underground copper mine Rio Tinto is struggling to develop in Mongolia’s Gobi desert. “They are sinking a shaft and we are going in horizontally. And these are ore bodies we have mined . . . since the early ’90s. We know the rock,” said Mr Adkerson.Once the switch to underground mining is complete in 2020, Grasberg will be producing more than 700,000 tonnes of copper annually, making it the second biggest mine in the world, as well as 1.8m ounces of gold.“Those volumes are sustainable for 20 years and beyond,” said Mr Adkerson, adding that excess cash would be used to pay down debt and step up shareholder returns.“The market is heavily discounting the risk associated with the underground transition. We are confident we can complete it but we have to do it,” he said.

Titular: Freeport production hit by anti-mining protests in Peru
Subtitular: Disruption caused by anti-mining protests caused company to miss sales forecasts
Texto: Sales at Freeport-McMoran, the world’s biggest independent copper producer, dropped in the last quarter hit by the switch to underground mining at its flagship asset and disruption in Peru.Freeport, which is led by Richard Adkerson, had already warned production at its giant Grasberg mine in Indonesia would decline as it moved operations from an open pit to a block cave.However, the disruption caused by anti-mining protests in Peru was a surprise and caused the company to miss its sales forecasts.Shipments from Freeport’s Cerro Verde mine in Peru were 217m pounds of copper in three months to September, down from 280m in the same period a year ago.That contributed to a 23 per cent drop in overall sales 795m. In July, Freeport said it expected to sell 830m pounds of copper in the third quarter.For about three weeks from the middle of July access to the port of Matarani was blocked by demonstrations against a new copper project being developed Mexico’s Southern Copper.Freeport, Glencore and China’s MMG were among the miners unable to ship copper concentrate — the key feedstock for smelters- during that period. MMG has also been affected by separate protests close to its Las Bambas mine.“Third-quarter 2019 production and sales were impacted by protests in Peru associated with an unaffiliated copper development project that blocked access to the shipping ports and main transportation routes, mill maintenance activities and mine sequencing changes at Cerro Verde that delayed access to higher grade material,” Freeport said in a statement.The company reported an adjusted net loss of $8 mln, which was bang in line with expectations. It shares rose 2.7 per cent to $10.20.2019 has seen significant disruption for copper mine supply, with a 2 per cent fall in global production, according to Morgan Stanley. However the price of copper has flatlined because of weak demand and jitters over the US-China trade war.On Tuesday, Anglo American reported an 8 per cent decline in copper production to 158,900 tonnes in third quarter due to unprecedented drought conditions impacting its Los Bronces mine in Chile.Traders are braced for further disruptions in Chile, which is experiencing its worst civil unrest since Augusto Pinochet’s dictatorship unravelled in the 1980sOn Wednesday, London-listed Antofagasta said protests in Chile could cut its production by 5,000 tonnes.Chile is the Saudi Arabia of copper. It produces 5.8Mt of copper annual, or 28 per cent of the world’s mined copper supply.In its results statement, Freeport said it expected to complete mining of the Grasberg open pit by the end of the year, while the block cave projet was “going very well.” and production would improve significantly by 2021.“The Grasberg block cave represents about 50 per cent of our underground reserves. It’s the same ore body that we’ve been mining from the surface for the past almost 30 years,” said Mr Adkerson on a call with analysts.He added: “In block caving…ore collapses into caves under gravity, so there is no stripping or mine waste. We will only have to mine about a thord of the material that we’ve historically mined and produce more copper than we have in these – all these years from the surface.”

Titular: West Papuan leader in exile criticises miners amid unrest
Subtitular: Activists call on BP and Freeport-McMoRan to cease operations after deaths in the Indonesian province
Texto: West Papuan independence leader Benny Wenda has called on the United Nations and the international community to intervene and for resource companies in the Indonesian region to halt their operations following accusations of a violent crackdown by Indonesian authorities. West Papua and neighbouring Papua are militarised and under-developed mountainous Indonesian provinces on the western half of the island that also accommodates Papua New Guinea in the east.Despite attempts by Jakarta to keep unrest in the provinces away from the international spotlight, the latest outbreak of tensions and growing support for Papuans among Pacific Island nations is making that more difficult as tensions continue in the area that hosts a number of key resource projects.Mr Wenda said Freeport-McMoRan and BP should stop operating in West Papua and Papua. He accused the companies of ignoring the landowners, the Papuan people, and collaborating with Indonesian military forces in an “illegal occupation”. “I ask shareholders to review this. Look at the situation and what is happening towards my people,” Mr Wenda told the FT. “I rightfully call out Indonesia for committing a slow genocide towards my people and appeal for international intervention before it is too late,” he said. Indonesia’s ministry of security did not respond to requests from the FT for comment but Indonesian government officials have previously rejected accusations of genocide as “groundless”.BP said in response it would not take a political position the Papuan issue and it was proud of its Tangguh LNG project in the province of West Papua.“We’re proud of our operations, track record and relationships with the local communities,” said a BP spokesman. “More than half of our workforce in Tangguh is Papuan.”A Freeport spokeswoman said the US mining company supported long-term peace among stakeholders throughout Papua. “We do not tolerate human rights abuses at our operations. We also do not condone any form of violence against those who peacefully promote human rights,” she said. Freeport’s Grasberg mine in the province of Papua is one of the world’s largest gold and copper mines. The latest outbreak of civil unrest in the region was sparked after a video showing a racist attack against Papuan students at a hostel in a city in a different Indonesian province, Surabaya in East Java, was circulated on social media.Despite a move by Indonesian authorities to condemn the attack, riots and unrest followed prompting Indonesia to increase its military presence and block the internet in the region in August. Human Rights Watch has since called for an investigation into reports of the deaths of at least 10 people including Papuan protesters. Indonesian authorities have restricted access for foreign journalists and activists to the area, so information is difficult to verify. The region was annexed by Indonesia in 1969, and the outcome of a referendum held at the time that voted in favour of the transfer to Indonesian sovereignty has been disputed by Papuans, who are ethnic Melanesians.Siobhan McDonnell, a legal anthropologist at Australian National University, said the region’s resources were a key reason for Indonesia’s annexation of the area, which has seen an influx of workers from elsewhere in Indonesia. Mr Wenda fled the region for the UK in 2002 while facing trial in Indonesia over his pro-independence activities. Mr Wenda said international pressure was growing on Indonesia over its actions in West Papua, citing a call by the Pacific Island Forum, which includes Australia and New Zealand, for the UN to investigate the deteriorating human rights situation within a year.

Titular: Freeport posts quarterly loss on lower Grasberg output
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan, the world’s largest publicly traded copper producer, reported its first quarterly loss since the commodity price crash of 2016 on Wednesday due to reduced output from its Indonesia assets.The Arizona-based company is preparing to move from surface to underground mining at Grasberg, the world’s second biggest copper mine.Before it makes the switch Freeport is trying to make sure it extracts the maximum amount of copper and gold, which is produced as a byproduct from the vast open pit at Grasberg.Freeport said mine sequencing changes had delayed access to high-grade material during the three months to June, temporarily hitting revenues and profits. Copper and gold sales guidance was unchanged 3.3bn lbs and 800,000 ounces respectively.That saw the company report a second-quarter adjusted net loss of $58m or 4 cents per share, down from a net profit of $869m or 59 cents per share in the same period a year ago. Revenue fell 31 per cent to $3.56bn.The loss had been expected by analysts and comes as Freeport steps up spending on the underground mine at Grasberg, which should be producing 130,000 tonnes a day of copper-bearing ore in 2023.Between now and then Freeport and its Indonesia partner will spend $900m a year on developing the huge underground ore bodies at Grasberg.“We are pleased to report that execution of the underground ramp-up at Grasberg is advancing according to plan and recent milestones are encouraging as we target increasing volumes and cash flows,” said Freeport chief executive Richard Adkerson in a statement.Freeport recently resolved an ownership row over Grasberg with Jakarta. To win an agreement, the company said it would build a new copper smelter in Indonesia.The company said on Wednesday that a site for the new smelter had been selected and construction would begin in 2020.“While 2019 is clearly a tough year for Freeport due to low volumes, high unit costs, high capital expenditure and a low copper price, it is also a transitional period for the company, and the longer-term investment case is positive,” said Freeport analyst Jefferies analyst Christopher Lafemina.Shares in Freeport rose 1.2 per cent to $11.79 on Wednesday.

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan sells Finland cobalt refinery to Umicore for $150m
Texto: US copper miner Freeport-McMoRan has sold its cobalt refinery in Finland to Belgium’s Umicore for $150m.The Phoenix-based company said Umicore would buy the Kokkola refinery and an associated battery materials business.It follows the sale by Freeport of its giant Tenke cobalt and copper mine in the Democratic Republic of Congo to China Molybdenum in 2016.Kokkola is Europe’s largest cobalt refinery. Almost all of the world’s cobalt is processed in China.Umicore is Europe’s largest producer of cobalt-based battery cathodes, which are a key component of electric car batteries.

Titular: Freeport CEO says company is not for sale
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan, one of the world’s biggest copper producers, is not up for sale, according to its chief executive.“We have no plans to sell the company,” Richard Adkerson told analysts following the publication of third-quarter results on Wednesday. “We’re focused on our internal business.”Big miners and Chinese companies are looking to increase their exposure to copper, which is expected to benefit from the growth of renewable energy and electric vehicles.With Freeport close to concluding an important agreement in Indonesia, the company has been tipped as a possible takeover target. However, ructions caused by the US-China trade war may mean that big deals are off the agenda, at least in the near term.“I personally do not believe that in today’s world’s uncertainties there are opportunities for big mergers and transactions in the industry. I certainly don’t consider it to be something that we would look at in the near term given our share price,” Mr Adkerson said.Shares in Freeport have fallen 45 per cent this year and were trading close to a 12-month low on Wednesday at $10.94.On the call, Mr Adkerson claimed the deal to sell a majority stake in its Indonesia subsidiary to a local company would create a better operating “environment” for Grasberg, it flagship copper and gold mine.After years of wrangling, Freeport and its joint venture partner Rio Tinto reached a deal with Jakarta last month to cede control of PT Freeport Indonesia (PTFI) to Inalum, a state-owned company. This is part of wider government-led push to gain greater control of Indonesia’s natural resources.To fund the deal, Inalum is looking to raise debt, something Mr Adkerson said would ensure the two sides will be working on the same page.“They will want to see the operations run with stability because they’ll need cash flows to fund this significant debt they’re taking on,” he said.“And so they’ll want to see the operations run smoothly, to generate cash flows, to service our debt and generate dividends. So I believe firmly that, that this will create a better overall environment for operations than what we’ve experienced in recent years,” he said.

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan’s chief forecasts copper deals
Subtitular: Adkerson says lack of new development and electric car boom a catalyst for M&A
Texto: Deals in the copper mining industry are almost inevitable as companies scramble to gain access to new deposits, says the head of Freeport-McMoRan, one of the world’s biggest producers of the industrial metal.“We almost have to [see deals] because there is an absence of new development projects,” said Richard Adkerson, chief executive.“For some time now copper has been a strategic objective of every mining company. But the more attractive deposits are owned by companies that don’t want to divest them. So that creates an interesting set of dynamics.”Global miners, including BHP Billiton, have said they want to increase their exposure to copper, a commodity that will be in ever-greater demand as the green energy revolution takes hold and it is needed in battery-powered vehicles and their charging points. For the moment they are wary of hitting the acquisition trial, having spent billions of dollars on ill-timed deals during the commodities boom of the 2000s.However, with a dearth of new projects under development they may have no alternative but to acquire assets as the electric car boom takes off. Chinese mining companies, such as Zijin Mining Group and Citic, are also looking to bulk up in copper.New York-listed Freeport, which owns a string of copper mines in North and South America, is seen by some analysts as a potential takeover target now that a multiyear battle for control of its giant Grasberg copper mine in Indonesia is almost over.Its shares have fallen nearly 40 per cent this year, weighed down by fears the US-China trade war could impact global growth and demand for copper. The company has an equity market value of $17bn.Freeport is in the final stages of divesting a majority stake in its Indonesian operations to state-owned company known as Inalum. In exchange, Freeport will gain the right to operate Grasberg, the world’s second-biggest copper mine, until 2041.“By having Inalum as partner we think that it will be positive in terms of dealing with everything from government relations, to provincial and employee relations and environmental issues,” said Mr Adkerson. “We think it will make Grasberg a more stable operation.”The deal is the consequence of a push by Joko Widodo, Indonesia’s president, to control more of its natural resources. Jakarta wants all miners to switch to new licences and build smelters in the country to boost local production.Although Freeport and Jakarta signed a “definitive agreement” last month, several hurdles remain to clear before the deal is completed. These include antitrust filings with regulators and financing.Under the deal, Freeport is divesting a less than 10 per cent stake in PTFI, its Indonesian unit, to Inalum, which at the same time is buying Rio Tinto’s 40 per cent interest in Grasberg for $3.5bn.There have been worries over Inalum’s ability to raise debt financing because of new environmental standards on the disposal of waste material from Grasberg, which sits 4km above sea level among the soaring peaks of Indonesia’s eastern Papua province. However, Mr Adkerson is quick to play down those concerns.“The Environmental Agency has met with us and also we are told with Inalum’s bankers and given assurances that those [standards] are going to be amended and dealt with in a way that does not involve significant incremental cost to the operations or disruptions,” said Mr Adkerson.*“With the Grasberg divestment issue largely behind, we expect management to turn its focus towards capital returns . . . and growth opportunities,” said Chris Terry, Deutsche Bank analyst in a recent report.Asked about Freeport’s commitment to build a $3bn copper smelter in Indonesia, Mr Adkerson said the company was studying various funding options and Inalum would also participate.“Our intention is to form an entity and obtain debt funding for the smelter and we may well have a partnership with PT Amman,” he added, referring to the owner of Batu Hijau copper mine in Indonesia. Like Freeport, it also faces an obligation to build a smelter.Looking ahead, Mr Adkerson said his priorities were to see that the partnership with Inalum was executed “as planned”, and stabilise operations at Grasberg, which is transitioning to underground mining.Technical challenges have slowed the ramp-up of one underground project at Grasberg, while the development a large block cave under the main open pit will not start producing copper until next year.These issues will be uppermost in the mind of investors when Freeport reports third-quarter results on Wednesday.“We expect a focus for the quarter will be a progress report on the block cave in the main pit and at the Deep MLZ [project] where production was slowed due to seismic activity,” said analysts RBC Capital Markets.On his future, Mr Adkerson, 71, said he had no plans to retire, pointing out that he was younger than President Donald Trump who “is talking about a second term”.This article has been amended since publication to show that new environment standards are not expected to involve significant costs.

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan says its prepared to adjust production due to trade jitters
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan, the world’s biggest publicly listed copper company has said it is prepared to adjust production if rising trade tensions and macroeconomic jitters hit demand and the price of the industrial metal.Copper, used in everything from household wiring to telecoms networks, has plunged by 14 per cent since early June on concerns about the impact of the trade war between the US and China on global growth.The metal dipped briefly below $6,000 a tonne earlier this month amid a brutal sell off that also hit other industrial metals but has since recovered. As well as trade jitters, analysts are worried about demand in emerging markets because of the impact of strengthening US dollar and higher oil prices.“For the past month, we’ve seen the price of copper go [down] and we’ve got all these uncertainties overhang the world’s economy because of the trade talk and the trade actions,” Freeport chief executive Richard Adkerson said on a call with analysts on Wednesday.“If prices deteriorate, we have, and would again, adjust our operations to make sure that all of our mines are cash flow positive. We would defer expenditures, we would adjust operating cost as well as deferring capital expenditures, and we would hunker down again, for a period of time and our company would continue the cash flow positive. But that’s strictly a contingency plan.”Most of the world’s big mining houses are now preaching a mantra of “value over volume”, saying they are prepared to cut or adjust production in response to market conditions. This marks a big shift from their attitude during the commodities boom of the 2000s where they were digging frantically in order to take market share from their rivals.Mr Adkerson’s comments came as Freeport reported second-quarter results that topped market expectations boosted by higher prices and output.In the three months to June, Freeport said net income rose to $853m, or 58 cents per share, up from $241m, or 17 cents a share, a year earlier . Analysts had been expecting earnings of around 51 cents a share for the quarter. Revenue increased to $5.2bn from $3.7bn.Freeport realised an average sale price for its copper of $3.10 a pound, up 16 per cent from the same period in 2017.The company also maintained production guidance for 2018 of 3.8bn pounds of copper and said it planned to extend open pit mining activity at its Grasberg copper and gold deposit in Indonesia for a further six months in to the first half of 2019.At Grasberg’s Deep Mill Level Zone underground mine, Freeport said it still expected to reach full production rates of 80,000 tonnes a per day by 2022 in spite of recent seismic activity that pushed back the start of mining until the middle of 2019.Asked by analysts about the outlook for the copper market Mr Adkerson said he remained positive.“As we sit here today, there is an anomaly between market sentiment and fundamentals in the marketplace. We’re continuing to see real demand being very positive for our global business, including our business in China. The fiscal markets are broadly balanced globally. Exchange stocks are actually down since mid-June and supply growth continues to be muted,” he said.“And I’ll just make a quick note on China’s actions in the last few days to losen its fiscal situation in this country to continue to support continued investment.”

Titular: Ethical investors want more proof of good deeds
Subtitular: Clients and advisers push for tougher validation of data
Texto: Last year, investors ploughed $20.6bn into US sustainable investment funds compared with $5.5bn of net inflows in 2018, according to Morningstar, the data provider.But despite the near fourfold increase in investor interest, advisers are sceptical about the company and asset management data showing the environmental, social and governance impact of the funds themselves.“I struggle mightily. I don’t believe the indexes. They are using self-reported data and I just don’t buy it,” says Traci Richmond, a financial adviser with The Meakem Group in Bethesda, Maryland.The problem with ESG data is the lack of verification. “There’s so much data and information out there, it’s really, truly a data war,” says Tim Williams, the director of education initiatives at the Money Management Institute, a trade association.Morningstar, Bloomberg and MSCI are among the providers of ESG data and rankings. Each has recently attempted to address investors’ scepticism by seeking out more third-party verification. MSCI, for example, points to “alternative data sets” published by “sources outside of the company” that help “minimise reliance on voluntary disclosure”.There is also a growing trend to adopt ESG reporting standards set by organisations such as the Sustainability Accounting Standards Board (SASB) and the Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TFCD). But these bodies cannot set mandatory rules on data verification.I don’t believe the indexes. They are using self-reported dataThe US Securities and Exchange Commission has resisted adopting measures that some investor groups have proposed. Hester Peirce, one of the commissioners, has been openly disdainful of the ESG trend, describing it as “labelling based on incomplete information, public shaming, and shunning wrapped in moral rhetoric preached with cold-hearted, self-righteous oblivion to the consequences, which ultimately fall on real people.”Even so, late last year the SEC sent letters to some fund managers who target socially responsible assets, asking them to provide data on what factors they took into consideration.With no clear state-backed scrutiny of ESG data, investors and advisers must uncover deficits or misrepresentations in the growing pool of facts and figures themselves. “The challenge is how do you take all that information and turn it into useful investment decisions at all levels of the food chain,” Mr Williams says.Many wirehouses, the national brokerages selling investment services via advisers, have started to provide tools and resources to help clients better evaluate ESG data — and not just accept them at face value.Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch, Wells Fargo and UBS have increased their spending to acquire higher quality data and better sorting mechanisms for funds and assets that purport to be socially responsible.Last summer, Morgan Stanley launched a tool to help investors and advisers uncover misalignments between their portfolios’ assets and socially responsible objectives. The tool only uses third-party verified data and identifies where data quality deficits persist, says Courtney Thompson, a vice-president in Morgan Stanley’s Global Sustainable Finance group. “Having the data available is a key [and is] driving traction around the investments.”Morningstar also advises investors to be sceptical of fund managers and companies claiming a socially responsible focus. “I would caution investors that, while ESG index funds on the whole separate ‘better’ ESG companies from ‘worse’ ones reasonably well, those decisions are not based on fundamental evaluations and mistakes can be made,” says Jon Hale, Morningstar’s head of sustainability research. “Companies have started to understand that their ESG and sustainability disclosures are being scrutinised more heavily, and that helps.”Investors should seek underlying holdings reports from fund managers “so they can look at really what exposures they have”, says Vanessa Jilot, a financial adviser at Viewpoint Financial Network in Pleasanton, California. “My clients hope that, as you have more money moving to request ESG data, reporting will get better.”

Titular: Rio Tinto sells Grasberg stake for $3.5bn
Subtitular: Indonesia to take a controlling stake in world’s second-biggest copper mine
Texto: Rio Tinto has agreed to sell its interest in Grasberg, the world’s second-biggest copper mine, for $3.5bn, a deal that would open its share register to a wider range of investors.The sale is part of a complex three-way deal that will see Indonesia take a controlling stake in Grasberg, fulfilling a pledge by the country’s President Joko Widodo to boost local ownership of natural resources.As well as buying Rio’s 40 per cent interest in Grasberg, Indonesia’s state miner Inalum has also agreed to pay $350m for an additional 9.36 per cent stake in the mine from its operator Freeport-McMoran.Once these transactions have been completed and Rio’s interest converted into equity, Inalum will emerge with a 51 per cent interest in Grasberg. The rest will be controlled by Freeport.The deal brings to an end a year of wrangling between Jakarta and Freeport. It comes as President Widodo seeks re-election next year and the mining industry grapples with a rising tide of resource nationalism from Africa to Asia.This agreement marks a significant milestone towards establishing a new long-term partnership with Indonesia to provide long-term stability for GrasbergPhoenix-based Freeport has been seeking to retain operational control of the mine until 2041 and keep key legal and financial safeguards enshrined in its current operating licence so that it can push ahead with an underground expansion project at Grasberg.“This agreement marks a significant milestone towards establishing a new long-term partnership with the Republic of Indonesia to provide long-term stability for Grasberg,” said Richard Adkerson, Freeport chief executive.Located in a remote province of Papua, the main open pit at Grasberg sits more than 4,000 metres above sea level in snow-capped mountains. Continually shrouded in fog and soaked by heavy rains, conditions at the pit are among the toughest in the mining industry.Rio has been a partner in Grasberg since the 1990s when it agreed to help fund development of the mine in return for a 40 per cent share of output above certain thresholds. That would have shifted to 40 per cent of all production by 2023.The sale of Rio’s interest in Grasberg means that investors with strict environmental and social mandates will be able to invest in the company for the first time in decades.They have not been able to hold Rio shares because of Grasberg’s safety record and its use of a local river system to dispose of waste material from the mine. According to Barclays there have been 81 fatalities at Grasberg since 2003.“Rio is on the influential Norwegian government environmental exclusion list, due to Grasberg and its river tailings system we see potential for this now to be lifted,” said UBS analyst Myles Allsop.The sale of its interest in Grasberg also marks the latest move by Rio to streamline its portfolio and will fuel speculation about a further return of capital to shareholders when the deal is completed this year. With Grasberg, Rio will have raised $7.5bn from disposals this year.“Management indicated with 2017 results [in February] that there is no need to further reduce net debt, deals are too expensive and capex will remain $5.5bn-$6bn until 2020; as a result, we think proceeds are likely to be returned to shareholders — potentially via special dividends and [share] buybacks,” said Mr Allsop.For Freeport, the agreement over Grasberg removes an issue that has weighed on its share price and could make the company a takeover target for a rival looking to boost its exposure to copper, a metal tipped to benefit from the growth of renewable energy.“Most major miners are positive on the outlook for copper but have limited organic growth potential or problematic assets,” said Christopher LaFemina, analyst at Jefferies. “We expect the majors to eventually pursue deals in copper, and Freeport could be a good strategic fit.”

Titular: Rio Tinto confirms talks over $3.5bn Indonesia mine exit
Subtitular: Deal aimed at bringing local ownership of Grasberg to 51%
Texto: Rio Tinto looks like it is inching closer to selling its stake in the Grasberg copper and gold mine in Indonesia, confirming on Wednesday that talks on a potential $3.5bn deal with Inalum and Freeport-McMoran were ongoing.The three companies are engaged in discussions aimed at bringing local ownership of the mine up to 51 per cent, which is a key demand of the Indonesian government. Rio released a stock exchange announcement noting a report by Bloomberg that PT Indonesia Asahan Aluminium (Inalum) was interested in buying Rio’s stake for $3.5bn. Rio is ready to accept the deal, said the report. The report pushed shares in Freeport McMoran up almost 3 per cent to $17.17 on the NYSE. “Rio Tinto confirms that discussions between Rio Tinto, Inalum and Freeport are ongoing, including as to price. No agreement has been reached, and there is no certainty that binding agreements will be signed. This announcement contains inside information,” said Rio. Rio is entitled to 40 per cent of production above agreed levels until 2023 and 40 per cent of all output thereafter.Shares in Rio were up 0.9 per cent on the ASX on Wednesday.

Titular: Freeport flags further problems in Indonesia
Texto: Shares of Freeport-McMoran were down more than 14 per cent on Tuesday after the company flagged further problems at its giant Indonesian gold and copper depositFreeport chief executive Richard Adkerson said Jakarta has imposed new environmental standards on its Grasberg mine, which he slammed as “shocking” and not “feasible”.For the past 20 years, Freeport has been able to dispose of waste material, or tailings, produced by the Grasberg mine on land and via a local river system. This is used to carry tailings downstream to another deposit area.The government now wants the company to retain 95 per cent of the tailings on land, rather than 50 per cent.“You can’t revisit a system that was agreed to 20 years ago and has been operating effectively over 20 years with no unexpected environmental consequences,” Mr Adkerson told analysts on Tuesday following the publication of first-quarter results.“There’s no impact on marine life. There’s a thriving mud crab industry in the area. People fish offshore where we are. And so this is a distraction, but we have to deal with political issues, and this is one of them,” he continued.The main pit at Grasberg is located 4km above sea level among the soaring peaks of Indonesia’s eastern Papua province. It is widely regarded as the most complex mine in the world.“We had an agreement with the government that over the life of the mine, we would retain 50 per cent of the tailings on land. They’re now saying it should be 95 per cent, which just cannot be done.”He added that was “outrageous” that Freeport might have to pay a financial fine “for doing something that the government approved.”Christopher LaFemina, analyst at Jefferies, said it appeared Jakarta was trying to put pressure on Freeport as negotiations over the ownership of Grasberg continued.“We do not believe that Grasberg can operate without using the river to transport the tailings from the milling operations at 3000m above sea level to the deposition area, which is at the bottom of the mountain, basically at sea level,” he said.“Installing pipelines to transport the tailings is economically and possibly even technically unfeasible and certainly cannot be done quickly even if it were feasible.”The row with the Ministry of Environment and Forestry is the latest hurdle facing Freeport’s business in Indonesia.The Phoenix-based company has been told to sell a part of Grasberg, the world’s second-biggest copper mine, to local investors so that it can meet the Indonesian government’s 51 per cent ownership objective.If it hasn’t reached a deal by the end of June, Freeport will have to seek another temporary mining license from the government to keep operating.“Does Indonesia really want the mine to shut down, or is this more of a point of leverage for the government over Freeport and Rio Tinto in the on going negotiations? We suspect it is the latter, but this new development does make the negotiations more risky, in our view,” said Mr LaFemina.Shares in Freeport were down 14 per cent at $16.16.

Titular: A clean energy world needs a thriving mining sector
Subtitular: Nice green infrastructure requires metals and minerals
Texto: Mining companies and their financiers cannot be sure whether what they are doing is compulsory or forbidden. Or both. Governments, investors and lenders in the developed world have a growing disdain for the so-last-century business of mining. That attitude should be reconsidered if we want a clean-energy economy.For example, it has been known for some time in Europe, America and Japan that cobalt will be a necessary material for high-performance batteries for at least the next decade or so. Yet almost all the available finance for new cobalt production has come from Chinese investors and lenders.So it should not be a surprise that by 2022, according to Bernstein Research, Chinese companies will control about three-quarters of the new mine supply of cobalt, and just under half of the world’s total production. The remaining supply will come mostly as a byproduct of nickel and copper mines scattered across the globe.While Europe and America were generating slide decks and seminars about clean energy, the Chinese were buying mines in Africa. You can be certain that the Chinese industrial strategy will go beyond selling cobalt ore to selling electric batteries and vehicles to the rest of the world.Maybe one could imagine a series of miracle breakthrough technologies that reduce the requirement for cobalt for electric vehicles and mobile devices. Then the Chinese would be left with a lot of surplus cobalt in the Democratic Republic of Congo.Even in that fantasy world, we will need a lot more copper, vanadium, lithium and other minerals to raise world living standards. Poor farmers in India with kerosene lamps will want electrified houses. Africans need electric generators and transmission lines to build an industrial economy. Of course the workers and peasants of Greenwich and Palo Alto need cars and multiple mobile devices.If you think a class of oil company shareholders controls energy policy, wait until you find out how few companies control mining and mining finance. Before the October 1973 Middle East war, the “Seven Sisters” of international oil companies were supposed to rule the energy economy. They were then displaced, first by Opec members and other national oil companies, and then by smaller “independent” companies that eventually sponsored shale oil and gas development.There is a reasonable case to be made that a very short list of mining companies collectively have more of a lock on new, private, non-ferrous metals finance than the Seven Sisters did over oil. Their managements, mind you, would laugh bitterly at the idea. Every day they are beset by tax and royalty demands by their host governments, not to mention ever-tightening environmental regulations. Still, try to start a new mining company without a rich state sponsor.In the past several years the Chinese state-sponsored metals companies have managed to work and push their way to the top table. But even with today’s relatively favourable metals prices there are few real challengers to Glencore, Rio Tinto, BHP Billiton, Freeport-McMoRan, Anglo American and a handful of their peers.Part of the reason for this is the much more restrictive regulatory environment for project financings. All bank financing became more bureaucratised and risk-averse after the global financial crisis. But there was a sentiment that project financing for infrastructure and, yes, mining, could be structured in ways that would give some reassurance to the regulators and risk committees. That provided an opening for less well capitalised new entrants.Obama administration officials took the lead in seeking more stringent rules for what the Basel committee of banking supervisors calls “specialised lending”. When the deregulation-happy Trump people came to power, there was a belief that this complex and previously self-regulated activity would receive less attention from the supervisors.Nope. At the beginning of the year, the Basel committee, with American support, produced a slightly fudged set of agreed rules for “floors”, “slotting”, “losses given default”, and so on for the world’s bank lenders. “Specialised lending” (including project lending) would be reviewed “in due course”.While that sounds like a loophole, project finance bankers understood it as a yellow-to-red signal. As one European specialised lending banker tells me: “Project finance is [risked] much the same as unsecured corporate loans, or even higher, because [the new rules] penalise the construction period. That is not right, because well structured project finance should be safer.”Project financings are typically secured by contracts for the product or use of facilities, and incorporate commodity price, currency and interest rate hedges. The effect of the new Basel rules is a noticeable narrowing of the window to new entrants to an industry, who may be sponsoring sound investments but who do not have access to the public equity or corporate bond markets.That would include smaller mining companies. While mining may not sound as politically appealing as infrastructure, you do not get to build that nice green infrastructure without metals and minerals. Someone has to dig those up and refine them. If new entrants are not given a well-watched financial path, then the materials will be produced by oligopolies and state enterprises.

Titular: Freeport results shine, aided by higher metal prices
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan has posted its highest quarterly profits since 2014 as it seeks a deal to keep producing copper and gold from its giant Grasberg mine in Indonesia.Aided by higher metals prices, the US miner said adjusted net income had doubled to $750m in three months to December, beating market forecasts. For 2017 as a whole, adjusted net income was $113m against a loss of $4.46bn a year earlier.Copper, used extensively in wiring and power networks, rose 22 per cent last year and is currently trading above $7,000 a tonne, helped by a weaker dollar and accelerating global growth.“We are continuing to make significant progress in our ongoing negotiations with the Indonesian government to restore long-term stability for our Grasberg operations,” said Freeport chief executive Richard Adkerson in a statement.Jakarta is seeking 51 per cent local ownership of Grasberg, the world’s second biggest copper mine, as part of a broader push to take greater control of its natural resources.Freeport is willing to sell but only if it can retain a big enough stake to justify a multibillion dollar underground expansion of the mine.The two sides spent most of last year in negotiations but failed to reach an agreement. Analysts say one way to break the impasse would be if Rio Tinto decided to sell its interest in the mine to a state-owned mining company.If Rio was to part with its interest — the Anglo Australian miner is entitled to 40 per cent of production above agreed levels until around 2022 and 40 per cent of all output thereafter — Freeport would only need to sell a smaller portion of its 91 per cent stake.While Rio is prepared to sell, it is not clear at what price.In Thursday’s results statement Freeport, which also operates in the US and South America, said it expected to sell 3.9bn pounds of copper in 2018 and 2.4m ounces of gold.The company did not declare a dividend.Net debt ended the year at $8.7bn, down from $11.8bn in 2016.On a call with analysts and investors, Mr Adkerson said there “appeared to be a desire” on the part of the Rio and Jakarta to do a deal.“It’s the most likely outcome,” said Mr Adkerson, adding that he felt “comfortable the valuation will be reasonable.”With higher copper prices boosting cash flow, Mr Adkerson said that Freeport would soon be resuming its “long-term tradition of returning cash to shareholders.”“Freeport reported better than expected fourth-quarter results, and management noted that three way negotiations in Indonesia are progressing well, with all parties involved expecting agreement to be reached in the first half of 2018,” said Jefferies analyst Christopher LaFemina.

Titular: Freeport-McMoran expects to agree deal terms with Indonesia over mine stake sale
Texto: Freeport-McMoran expects to iron out differences with the government of Indonesia and reach a deal to keep operating its giant copper and gold mine in the country, it said on Wednesday.The US miner has been embroiled in a bitter dispute with the government in Jakarta over its contract to mine at Grasberg amid a popular clamour in Indonesia to control of more of its natural resources.In August, Freeport agreed a framework to divest 51 per cent of its Grasberg operations to local investors in return for retaining operational control of the mine and the certainty of legal and fiscal terms.However, the two sides have not be able agree on a number of key issues related to the proposed sale including valuation, timing and structure. If a deal is not reached it will throw into doubt plans for a multi-billion dollar expansion of the mine.The Phoenix-based company said on Wednesday the two sides had a “mutual objective” of completing the required documentation for a sale by the end of the year.“We are encouraged by continued progress in our active negotiations with the Indonesian government regarding our long-term operating rights in Indonesia and remain focused on managing our long-term business for the benefit of shareholders,” said Freeport chief executive Richard Adkerson.His comments came as Freeport reported third quarter results that topped market forecasts.The company reported adjusted net income of $492m, or 34 cents a share, against $178m in the same period last year and above the 31 cents a share analysts expected.Revenue was $4.31bn, up from $3.88bn a year ago and the company maintained its full year sales guidance at 3.7bn pounds of copper (1.68m tonnes) and 1.6m ounces of gold.Copper, which is used in everything from household wiring to electricity grids, has risen 28 per cent to above $7,000 a tonne this year as accelerating global economic growth has boosted demand. A series of outages at major mines, including Grasberg, has also helped support prices.

Titular: Indonesian ministries tout win in Freeport mine dispute
Texto: A triumphant tweet from the Indonesian government this week has revealed how much was at stake in its share dispute with Freeport McMoRan, US operator of the vast copper and gold mine at Grasberg in the eastern province of Papua.After Tuesday’s announcement that Freeport had agreed to hand over 51 per cent of the shares to the Indonesian government, both energy and finance ministries in Jakarta tweeted: “#Freeport Taat Indonesia Berdaulat”, or “Freeport is obedient, Indonesia is a sovereign state”.In backing the cause of economic nationalism, Indonesia joins Bolivia, Argentina and most recently Venezuela in taking back control of key natural resource projects.Grasberg, the world’s second-largest copper deposit, was 90 per cent owned by Freeport. But in January, Indonesian authorities said miners needed to switch to new licenses and agree to build smelters to help boost local production, as well as hand over 51 per cent to local investors.

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan boosted by higher copper price
Subtitular: S&P 500 sets fresh lifetime high as energy and bank stocks rally
Texto: Shares in Freeport-McMoRan, the world’s biggest listed copper company, jumped by the most in 16 months on Tuesday as a higher copper price and news of constructive discussions with the Indonesian government over its operating licence helped offset the sting of a guidance cut.The stock rose as much as 13.4 per cent to a five-month high of $14.70 after Freeport’s chief executive Richard Adkerson said he was optimistic of reaching an agreement with Jakarta over its contract to operate in the country and run the giant Grasberg copper deposit.The move is the stock’s biggest one-day rise since last March.“We are now approaching a stage where both parties have expressed an objective of a near-term resolution,” Mr Adkerson said.“I believe we are seeing that objective being more clearly identified by senior levels in the Indonesian government than we have seen in the past.”Freeport has been embroiled in a bitter dispute with the government in Jakarta over its contract to operate Grasberg, the world’s second-biggest copper mine.Indonesia wants Freeport to tear up its existing agreement and switch to a special mining licence and also divest a majority stake in its local subsidiary to domestic investors.Freeport says it will not meet these conditions unless it gets the same legal and fiscal assurances as under its existing deal, a contract that has been in place for decades.The dispute threatens plans for a multibillion-dollar expansion of Grasberg, which is situated in one of the most remote parts of Indonesia.Elsewhere, shares in 3M took a spill after the maker of Post-it notes and Scotch Tape reported slightly weaker-than-expected sales growth in the second quarter.The Minnesota-based company said its revenues had risen 1.9 per cent to $7.81bn, shy of the Wall Street forecast of $7.86bn.Sales were weighed down by divestitures as well as the impact of currency fluctuations. Net income rose to $1.58bn from $1.29bn.3M’s shares dropped as much as 6.1 per cent, the most in two-and-a-half years, to $197.17 after the report. The stock was up 17.6 per cent this year as of Monday’s close.Investors also gave another industrial heavyweight the cold shoulder.Shares in United Technologies, which hit a record high earlier this month, fell as much as 2.6 per cent to a one-month low of $119.99 after the company raised its outlook by less than the market was expecting.The company, which makes everything from jet engines to moving walkways, lifted the lower end of its adjusted earnings per share outlook for 2017 to $6.45-$6.60, compared with the $6.30-$6.60 range it was expecting.However, that failed to meet the market’s lofty expectations. Investors had been hoping the company would raise the upper end of its earnings guidance.Until Tuesday, shares in United Technologies had gained more than 12 per cent this year amid a rebound in global growth and expectations that it would benefit from President Donald Trump’s promise to boost military spending.The declines in industrials failed to weigh down the wider market, however. The S&P 500 set a record high, rising as much as 0.5 per cent to 2,481.24 as energy and bank stocks rallied.The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed as much as 0.7 per cent to 21,670.62 while the Nasdaq Composite was within a whisker of breaking Monday’s intraday high after gaining 0.1 per cent to 6,417.12.

Titular: Freeport fights for future of Grasberg mine
Subtitular: World’s second-largest copper mine under threat after bust-up with Indonesia
Texto: Richard Adkerson, chief executive of Freeport-McMoRan, has six months to thrash out a deal with Indonesia to assure the future of Grasberg, the world’s second-biggest copper deposit.The main open pit at Grasberg sits more than 4,000 metres above sea level among snow capped mountains in a remote and restless part of Indonesia. Continually shrouded in fog and soaked by heavy rains, conditions at the pit are among the toughest in the mining industry.But government interference in the lucrative mine has proven more difficult to deal with than even the harshest of conditions. Freeport, the Phoenix-based mining company, is locked in a dispute with the government over its contract to operate in the country — and in turn whether the Grasberg mine will ever be developed to its fullest potential.The dispute led to a ban on copper exports from the mine for almost four months, which was only lifted after Freeport threatened to suspend work on a multibillion-dollar project that will sustain production at Grasberg until 2041.The two sides now have a six-month window to craft an agreement that will allow Jakarta to meet a popular desire for control of more of its natural resources, while giving Freeport the assurances it needs to keep investing at Grasberg.“We have work to do, issues to discuss, but we’re going into this with goodwill and optimism about reaching a win-win situation,” said Mr Adkerson after a meeting with Indonesia’s mining minister Ignasius Jonan last week. “For Freeport, the key requirement is having assurances and a stable investment environment to support our long-term operations.”If Freeport — which has a market capitalisation of $17bn and sales of $14.8bn — cannot develop the underground deposits at Grasberg it will blow a very big hole in its future production, say analysts. Last year, the mine produced more than 1bn pounds of copper, about 3 per cent of global supply, against overall company production of about 4.2bn pounds.But the situation is no less critical for Jakarta, which badly needs the revenues generated by the mine to help finance an ambitious infrastructure programme and provide employment in the eastern province of Papua. Since the start of the year, Freeport has reduced the workforce at Grasberg by 10 per cent.Freeport claims Indonesia will receive more than $40bn in taxes, royalties and dividends from Grasberg between now and 2041, assuming full development of the underground deposit.But first Freeport needs to invest in its future. Supplies from the open pit will be exhausted over the next couple of years, so Freeport and its partner Rio Tinto are developing several huge underground deposits.They are not willing to invest billions of dollars needed to mine the copper rich ore unless Freeport can preserve key legal and fiscal safeguards contained in its current operating contract. Rio’s chief executive Jean-Sébastien Jacques has described Grasberg as a world-class deposit but has questioned whether it is a world-class investment.“It’s a very precise document, very clearly worded with all sorts of protections,” says Richard Wilson, chairman of metals at Wood Mackenzie, a consultancy, in reference to Freeport’s license, also known as a ‘contract of work’.Facing pressure from the public to be tough with Freeport, Jakarta has not been willing to roll those guarantees into one of its new mining licenses. It has, however, given Freeport a temporary license that lasts until October, providing the two sides time to reach a deal. “The President does not want to shut down Freeport for good but they have to give us more,” says a senior government official.Under changes to Indonesian law announced in January, miners will need to switch to new licenses and agree to build smelters in the country to help boost local production. In addition, foreigners miners will need to divest 51 per cent stakes in their operations to local investors — something Freeport would find very difficult to do, says Mr Wilson.After selling its Tenke mine in the Democratic Republic of Congo to reduce debt last year, Grasberg is the crown jewel in the company’s portfolio.“Freeport can’t spend $5bn on mine development and $2bn on a smelter and expect to have a minority participation in the venture,” Mr Wilson says. “That untenable.”In spite of uncompromising stances of both sides, analysts and lawyers believe a deal will eventually be reached because both sides have too much to lose.Keep up to date on the latest news and insight on deals every weekday morningFreeport has already said it is prepared to sell up to 30 per cent of PT-FI, the holding company that controls Grasberg. Freeport has a 90 per cent stake in PT-FI and the Indonesia government about 10 per cent.Freeport has also promised to build a second smelter as long as it can maintain the tax and legal certainties in its current ‘contract of work’.“The one thing that we will insist on, is that any divestment be made on the basis of the fair value of the assets,” Mr Adkerson told analysts after Freeport announced first-quarter results last month.However, any agreement will have to be carefully packaged so that government can look strong in the eyes of the Indonesian people, while at the same time giving Freeport what it needs to go ahead with its planned investment at Grasberg. Bill Sullivan, a lawyer at Christian Teo and Partners in Jakarta, says it is possible to structure a deal so that Freeport could sell 51 per cent of PT-FI but retain control of the company through voting rights. Tax and legal guarantees could also be added to a new mining license.“At the end of the day they need each other,” says Mr Sullivan. “They might not like each other but they need each other and that suggests to me that they will find a way to go forward.”

Titular: Indonesia grants new mining permit to Freeport-McMoran
Texto: Indonesia has issued a permit to US miner Freeport McMoran that could allow for a resumption of exports from the world’s second-largest copper mine after almost a month’s standoff.Freeport can apply immediately for an export permit, Reuters reported, citing an official at the country’s mining ministry. That could allow exports of copper concentrate from the giant Grasberg mine.A spokesman for Freeport, however, said there is still no agreement. “Exports remain restricted as a result of the January 2017 regulations,” he said.Copper prices have risen 5 per cent since Freeport’s exports were stopped on Jan. 12 following the issuance of new regulations on exports of unrefined metals. They rose 4 per cent on Friday to trade at $6,070 a tonne – the highest level in over a year, boosted by a cut in output from Chile’s Escondida mine, the world’s largest, following a strike.The dispute with Indonesia has raised questions about the project for its other partner, Rio Tinto. Under a contract with Freeport, Rio receives a small share of Grasberg’s production until 2021, after which it will be due 40 per cent of output.This week Rio’s new chief executive Jean-Sebastien Jacques said the company is going to “watch very carefully what’s happening before we commit additional material money into the project.”“Grasberg is a world-class resource but the question is whether it is a world-class business for Rio,” said Mr Jacques.

Titular: Indonesia and Freeport-McMoran dig in on mine stand-off
Texto: The stand-off between Indonesia and Freeport-McMoran continues.The world’s biggest publicly-listed copper company said on Friday that a ban on exports from its giant Grasberg mine in the province of Papua remained in force.“We are disappointed that this matter remains unresolved and concerned about the negative impacts for all stakeholders, especially our workforce and the local economy,” said Freeport chief executive Richard Adkerson.Reports earlier this week claimed Freeport would be given a temporary export permit while it continued discussions with Jakarta over new mining regulations.Shares in Freeport fell 0.5 per cent $16.71 in early trading in New York.Indonesia wants to increase export duties and force all mining companies to convert their current contracts to special operating licences, an IUPK. Mining companies are also being asked to build or complete smelters in five years, and foreign operators must sell up to 51 per cent stake in their assets to locals.Freeport is not willing to convert to an IUPK unless it retains the same rights and level of legal and fiscal certainty contained in its current contract.The reason for its caution was evident in the company’s recent fourth-quarter earnings release where it revealed it was facing $469m in water taxes and penalties in Papua province dating back to 2011During a post-results phone call with analysts Mr Adkerson said this was a “clear-cut” example of why Freeport had to protect its current rights.“That’s what would happen to us if we want to a license without having any investment stability agreement. Under a licence, you’re subject to prevailing laws and regulations and any government can come in and impose taxes, fees, import duties, et cetera, et cetera, water taxes, surfaces taxes, vehicles taxes,” said Mr AdkersonGrasberg is the world’s second-biggest copper mine and also the lowest cost because it also produces a significant amount of gold. Freeport says it will be forced to slash production if the ban is not lifted by the middle of February – the date by which the company will have used up all of its storage.Lower production from Grasberg could further tighten the copper market if workers at another big copper mine go strike.This week miners at Escondida in Chile rejected a pay offer from BHP Billiton and now look likely to take industrial action.In a recent report, analysts at Macquarie said 77,000 tonnes a month of copper supply were at risk from the respective problems at the two mines. Copper was trading at $5,816 a tonne on Friday.

Titular: Freeport clears last hurdle in sale of Congo copper mine
Texto: Copper miner Freeport-McMoran paid $33m to the Democratic Republic of Congo’s state miner Gecamines to resolve a dispute over its $2.65bn sale of the largest copper mine in the country.The settlement removes the final hurdle for the mine to be sold to China Molybdenum, giving the Chinese company a prized copper asset at a time of rising prices for the red metal.The payment was Freeport’s share of a settlement agreement reached with Gecamines, China Moly, and the other parties involved in the sale of the Tenke Fungurume copper and cobalt mine, Freeport said in its earnings statement.In November Gecamines filed a case at an international arbitration court in Paris in an attempt to stop Freeport from going ahead with the sale of its majority stake in the mine. It claimed it had not been adequately consulted on the sale of Tenke, in which it holds a 20 per cent stake.The remaining share of Tenke was sold in November to a Chinese private equity firm, BHR Partners. On Sunday China Moly said it had signed an agreement with BHR to support its acquisition of the stake to ensure “the transaction completes successfully.” It also said it had a right to purchase BHR’s stake in the future if it decided to exit.Gecamines did not immediately respond to a request for comment through its public relations agency.

Titular: Freeport to cut copper output unless Indonesia lifts export ban
Subtitular: US miner issues warning as it reduces debt and unveils weaker than expected results
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan, the world’s largest publicly listed copper producer, hailed the success of its debt reduction programme as it reported weaker-than-expected results and warned that output from its giant Grasberg mine would be cut unless an export ban in Indonesia was lifted.The US-listed miner said it had reduced net debt to $12bn in the year to December after selling a string of assets including oilfields in the Gulf of Mexico and a major African copper project.“During 2016, we took aggressive actions in response to market conditions to restore our balance sheet strength,” said chief executive Richard Adkerson. “I am pleased to report that we were successful in reducing our net debt by over $8bn during the year.”Freeport launched its deleveraging plan a year ago after its share price plunged on concerns about the company’s ability to service a large debt pile during savage commodity markets that have now partially recovered.Its shares have risen by more than 300 per cent over the past year to $16 but the company is now facing fresh challenges in Indonesia, where the government has just revamped its mining laws.Jakarta wants all foreign companies to a sign a new mining licence, commit to building smelters and agree to sell a 51 per cent stake in their mines to local owners. Until they do, they will not be allowed to export ore or in Freeport’s case copper concentrate from Grasberg, its most important asset.However, Freeport is unwilling to convert its contract of work to a new operating licence unless it can get the same level of legal and fiscal certainty it has under its existing agreement. It has threatened to cut jobs and investment if it cannot reach a deal.Grasberg in Indonesia’s Papua province is the world’s second biggest copper mine and also runs at the lowest cost because of the gold it also produces. Freeport wants to transition Grasberg from an open pit to underground mine, a project that will cost billions of dollars.Mr Adkerson said he had been given indications by Jakarta that Freeport would be allowed to resume copper concentrate exports while it negotiates converting its contract of work to a new mining licence.But he warned copper output would be cut significantly if the ban was not lifted by the middle of February — the date by which Freeport will have used up all of its storage.“This situation is likely to get worse before it gets better,” said Christopher LaFemina, analyst at Jefferies. “It is bullish for copper but will create continued volatility in the share price.”Shares in Freeport were down 4.5 per cent at $16.25 in New York trading on Wednesday.Freeport reported net income of $292m in the three months to the end of December, against a loss of more than $4bn a year earlier when it recorded a number of one-off charges.Adjusted earnings per share were 25 cents. That figure was below analysts’ average estimate of 34 cents because of difficulty accessing high-grade ore at Grasberg.For 2016 as whole Freeport reported a loss of $4.15bn after taking more than $4bn of impairments against its oil and gas assets.The company expects to produce 4.1bn pounds of copper in 2017, assuming the Indonesian ban is lifted. Freeport also has assets in the US and South America.Indonesia’s export ban and the possibility of a strike at a major copper mine in Chile has helped drive the price of copper, used in everything from wiring to power grids, close to $5,900 a tonne on Wednesday. Overnight, workers at Escondida rejected the latest wage offer from mine operator BHP Billiton.

Titular: Freeport threatens job cuts over Indonesian mining export ban
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan, the world’s largest publicly listed copper producer, has threatened to reduce its workforce and suspend future investment at its giant Grasberg mine if the Indonesian government does not a lift an export ban.The US-listed company said its Indonesian subsidiary would consider legal action if it failed to reach an agreement with Jakarta, which has just revamped its mining rules. The comments came as Freeport reported a fourth quarter profit.Indonesia wants all foreign mining companies to sign a new mining license and commit to building smelters. In return they will be allowed to continue exporting ore, or in Freeport’s case copper concentrate.However, Freeport is unwilling to convert its contract of work to a special operating license unless it can get the same level of legal and fiscal certainty it has under its existing agreement.Freeport said on Wednesday that unless the ban was lifted its Indonesia arm, PT-FI, would have to cut output to match available smelting capacity, or by 40 per cent. Freeport owns around 91 per cent of PT-FI and the Indonesian government the rest.“Under this scenario, PT-FI would be required to take near-term actions to reduce its workforce, significant reduce costs and suspend future investments on its underground development projects and new smelter,” Freeport said in its results statement.Grasberg is the world’s second biggest copper mine and also the lowest cost because of the gold it produces as a by-product. Freeport wants to transition production from an open pit to underground mining, a project that will cost $18bn.Indonesian’s export ban and the possibility of a strike at a major copper mine in Chile has helped drive the price of copper, used in everything from wiring to power grids close to $5,900 a tonne.In the three months to the end of December, Freeport reported net income of $292m, against a loss of more than $4bn a year earlier when it recorded a string of charges.Net debt fell was $11.7bn, putting the company on target to reach a target of $10bn by the end of the year.“During 2016, we took aggressive actions in response to market conditions to restore our balance sheet strength,” said Freeport chief executive Richard Adkerson in a statement.Over the year to December, Freeport reported a loss of $4.15bn after taking more than $4bn of impairments against oil and gas assets it has now sold.

Titular: Reversal of Indonesia’s mineral ore policy threatens to spark opposition
Subtitular: Impact on global nickel market likely to be limited, political fallout may be greater
Texto: Indonesia’s surprise decision last week to lift a ban on unprocessed mineral exports for five years unsettled investors, especially Chinese companies that had invested in the country on the assumption that Jakarta was intent on building up its domestic processing capacity.Indonesian Smelter and Mineral Processing Association (ISPA) chairman R Sukhyar told FT Confidential Research that the policy reversal “clearly violates” the country’s 2009 mining law and that the Chinese Chamber of Commerce was “very upset”. Mr Sukhyar is a former director-general of minerals and coal at the energy and mineral resources ministry and was involved in designing the regulations that set up the export ban in 2014.ISPA remains undecided on whether to file a legal challenge, saying it needs more time to consolidate a position among members. AP3I, another industry association, said it had decided against legal action and prefers dialogue with the government. It will meet vice-president Jusuf Kalla this week.This restrained response probably stems from expectations that annual quotas on unprocessed mineral exports, required by the new policy, will be small. We understand it will be 5.2m tonnes for nickel ore — a modest level given a national mining capacity of 60m tonnes. This suggests that the impact on global metal prices will be limited. Indonesia exported 60m-70m tonnes a year before the ban was implemented in 2014.We believe the quota is modest because the government wants to secure supply for domestic nickel processing and refining facilities, the input capacity of which is expected to reach 37.5m tonnes next year.A larger quota of 20m tonnes is expected for bauxite ore, against national output capacity of roughly 50m tonnes, with annual domestic demand of only about 3m tonnes.Any legal challenges are therefore likely to come from academics, environmental activists and civil society groups, which view lifting the ban as detrimental to the environment and the development of downstream metal industries.Ahmad Redi, a law professor and expert on natural resources and environment policies, is leading a coalition of lawyers, environmental activists and non-governmental organisations that will file a legal challenge at the Supreme Court as early as next week.While such a complaint may be supported by precedent –— in 2014 the Constitutional Court rejected a request for judicial review from the Indonesian Mineral Entrepreneur Association of annul provisions in the mining law that require domestic mineral processing and refining — cases in the Supreme Court sometimes get delayed in definitely. Nor is the court, in our view, immune to political pressure.Indeed, Indonesian politics is at a sensitive juncture. Opposition to President Joko Widodo’s government is gaining momentum. Ultra-nationalists and radical Islamic movements will claim the policy reversal favours foreign corporate interests at the expense of local people and the environment.Our latest quarterly survey of political sentiment found respondents less optimistic about Indonesia’s political prospects than they were at the start of 2016 (see chart). Those surveyed expected the political situation to become more volatile, particularly as Jakarta and 104 other regional governments shift to an election footing next month.Respondents nevertheless gave a more positive assessment of the president’s recent performance, with the majority holding a positive view (see chart).The policy shift could become a “lightning rod” issue, however, as it virtually assures Freeport MacMoran can continue its operation in Papua until 2041. Freeport is seen by ultra-nationalists as a symbol of US imperialism.Under the policy change announced on January 12, companies such as Freeport and Amman Mineral Nusa Tenggara (previously Newmont Nusa Tenggara) must convert their Contract of Work (CoW) status into a so-called Special Mining Business Licence (abbreviated locally to IUPK) if they want to continue exporting copper concentrates for the next five years.In an email to FTCR, Freeport said it would accept the conversion of its contract into a mining licence but was seeking assurances from the government that it would protect the company’s investments and offer guarantees on some tax issues. Conversion includes the requirement that Freeport divest itself of a 51 per cent stake in its Indonesian subsidiary to local entities by the 10th year of production under the new licence, up from a previously agreed 30 per cent. Freeport MacMoRan has already sold 9.4 per cent of the venture, leaving a further 41.6 per cent to be sold.The expiration of Freeport’s mining licence will be in 2021, the same date as under its CoW. The company will then have the right to renew the licence twice, with each further term lasting 10 years.There are two complications, however – one financial, the other political – that bode ill for mining companies in Indonesia more generally.Financiers are likely to treat a licence as less bankable than a contract, thereby elevating credit risk. With a CoW, the company stood shoulder-to-shoulder with the government as signatories.Meanwhile, the conversion from a CoW to an IUPK will not be straightforward, despite a provision in the new policy that gives the energy and mineral resources ministry a maximum of two weeks to approve or reject a licence application.The coalition of NGOs led by Mr Redi is set to challenge this provision at the Supreme Court, arguing that the government cannot approve such licences unless the House of Representatives has first designated the area to be mined as under central authorities’ management – what is referred to as a National Reserve Area.If this challenge succeeds, IUPK applications could only be considered for areas pre-qualified by the House. Parliament’s chequered record of approving new legislation does not engender much confidence that such a process would be smooth.FT Confidential Research is an independent research service from the Financial Times, providing in-depth analysis of and statistical insight into China and Southeast Asia. Our team of researchers in these key markets combine findings from our proprietary surveys with on-the-ground research to provide predictive analysis for investors.

Titular: Copper prices touch month high as dollar slips
Texto: The price of copper hit its highest level in more than a month before retreating, boosted by a weaker US dollar and concerns about output of the industrial metal from Indonesia, home to one of largest copper deposits on the planet.Copper for delivery in three months on the London Metal Exchange rose as much as $122 to $5,844 a tonne as the US currency continued to weaken in the wake of Wednesday’s extraordinary press conference President Elect Donald Trump.But it fell back after Indonesia said companies including Freeport McMoran, operator of the giant Grasberg mine, would be allowed to export semi-processed copper if they agreed to new mining rules.Indonesia banned exports of unprocessed ore in 2014 in an effort to boost industrial development and increase the value of its raw materials.But Jakarta provided a three-year extension to producers of concentrate – dry copper feedstock – on the condition they build domestic smelters. That grace period expired on Wednesday, potentially threatening exports from the country.US-listed Freeport has put construction of its smelter on hold because of uncertainty over mining rights at Grasberg, which produced around 550,000 tonnes of copper last year.On Thursday morning Indonesia’s government announced long-awaited changes to its mining policy which could pave the way for an agreement with Freeport, which has plans to develop an underground mine at Grasberg.Energy and Mineral resources minister Ignasius Jonan told reporters in Jakarta that companies including Freeport would be allowed to export concentrates but only if they agreed to new mining licenses and committed to building smelters.In the wake of those comments copper fell back and was up just $36.50 at 5,760 a tonne.Freeport could not be reached for comment.Separately, trading on the LME’s electronic trading system was halted five hours on Thursday because of network and connectivity problems. Traders said that might have accounted for some of the volatility in prices.“Volumes have picked up substantially this morning despite the market only trading from 6.00am,” said Marex Spectron, a London-based commodities brokerage.

Titular: Indonesian ore export ban reversal unlikely
Subtitular: Mining law expected to tighten from January 2017 despite intense industry lobbying
Texto: Indonesia’s government is garnering praise from international investors for its pro-business stance, and the growing strength of President Joko Widodo augurs well for future economic reforms.
