But mining and energy policy continues to cast a cloud over the investment environment.Almost three years after implementation, Indonesia’s 2014 ban on the export of several metal ores (including nickel, bauxite and copper) has failed to achieve its stated objective of spurring investment in domestic refining capacity in bauxite and copper, although it has had some success in nickel.This mixed success reflects the fact that Indonesia’s 2009 mining law — which outlined the 2014 ban — failed to take account of the different characteristics of each mineral, in terms of where the greatest value-add lies in the supply chain.Investment flows into Indonesia’s mining sector tumbled as a direct consequence of the law (see chart), while exports of minerals have shrunk to negligible levels. Chinese importers — the main source of demand — have turned to Malaysia to source bauxite and to the Philippines for nickel.Moreover, the policy’s restrictions are set to become even more onerous for the industry: from January 2017 only shipments of fully refined metals are allowed, tightening from the current law that also allows partially processed metals.Government officials have sent conflicting messages about the likelihood of a reversal of the ban, but we think it will remain largely in place. FT Confidential Research recently spoke with Luhut Pandjaitan, coordinating economic minister for maritime affairs (see box) — who oversees the Energy and Mineral Resources Ministry — and believe that the government will:The minister oversees a wide range of policy portfolios, including: maritime resource management; natural resource management; infrastructure development; human resource development; and science and technology.The portfolios were previously managed by different coordinating authorities. The reshuffle of portfolios was aimed at reducing the supervisory burden shouldered by the Coordinating Economic Ministry.Mr Pandjaitan’s authority on this and other energy policies has grown in recent months. Although Igansius Jonan, a former transport minister, was unexpectedly awarded the position of energy and resources minister in mid-October following a reshuffle, we believe Mr Jonan’s lack of experience means it is Mr Pandjaitan who calls the shots.One reason why backtracking on the nickel export ban does not make sense is that the current policy has spurred investment. About 20 companies, many Chinese, have committed to investing $6bn in processing facilities over the past five years. Such investments have resulted in the complete construction of 12 smelting facilities (see chart).China remains short of domestic supplies of nickel ore, while Indonesia is one of few global suppliers. Chinese companies have agreed to comply with the ruling in order to secure supply chains.Another reason is that investing in nickel smelting in Indonesia is commercially attractive. Nickel mining costs just 2-3 per cent of its ultimate market value. Loading large barges for processing in China is inefficient relative to producing onshore in Indonesia and transporting finished products. “This efficiency advantage of onshore refining might have reduced slightly in the wake of the ongoing collapse in shipping costs, but not by too much,” says Julian Hill, a consultant at Deloitte Indonesia.As a result, we expect total nickel smelting input capacity to reach 33.9m tonnes annually by 2017 and approximately 37.5m by 2018 — accounting for roughly 95 per cent of current mining production. However, there is still room for further investment — in both nickel smelting and stainless steel production — as total annual capacity probably exceeds 60m tonnes.We also expect nickel production to fall in the Philippines following President Rodrigo Duterte’s crackdown on mining operations, which could divert further Chinese demand towards Indonesia.Bauxite is a different animal. Indonesia’s share of global bauxite supply is much smaller than for nickel, while China has a considerable domestic supply. Malaysia has also stepped up its production (see chart).There is also a significant surplus of bauxite refining capacity in China and globally. Since 2014 only two companies have invested in Indonesian alumina processing: Indonesia Chemical Alumina and Well Harvest Winning.Indonesian bauxite producers, such as state-owned Aneka Tambang, have been lobbying the government to relax the ban on bauxite exports, with up to 80 per cent of the country’s current bauxite mining capacity lying idle as a result of current policy. Output has plummeted (see chart).However, legal obstacles mean policy is unlikely to change. Unlike both nickel and copper, bauxite ores already have high metal concentrations (up to 30 per cent), meaning that processing it into concentrate before alumina refining is unnecessary. Given that the mining law bans the export of “unprocessed” minerals from 2017, there is no legal wriggle room to incentivise smelter development by allowing bauxite miners to invest in processing for concentrate, a policy currently implemented in the copper sector. As a result, the government legally has no other option but to allow exports of refined products only.Copper is different again. Production of the metal is largely accounted for by two large foreign-invested projects: Newmont in Nusa Tenggara and Freeport Indonesia in Papua. Government royalties from Freeport alone have totalled nearly $15bn over the last 20 years.An amendment to the existing law allows producers to export raw copper ore on condition they pay a 5 per cent export tax and show proof of plans to begin refining. Companies such as Freeport have generally complied, but have also quite deliberately delayed investment. Freeport’s plans are mired in uncertainty while it tries to secure an extension of the contract for operations at its giant Grasberg mine on Papua beyond 2021.The commercial case for copper refining — as opposed to processing — in Indonesia remains unconvincing, since processing copper ore into concentrate generates over 90 per cent of the market value of the end-product, compared with less than 10 per cent for nickel and bauxite. Copper concentrate accounts for the vast majority of copper export value (see chart).Copper is also highly politicised. President Widodo has refused to negotiate an extension of Freeport’s so-called contract of work, which the company wants to extend until 2041.Freeport is, in theory, required gradually to sell down more of its majority ownership to domestic operators. As a result, while it has earmarked $15bn for mine expansion and $2bn for a planned smelter, this remains on hold until there is greater policy clarity, which may not come until closer to 2019.Yet the government’s ability to force Freeport to comply is limited. An abrupt halt to Freeport’s operations would result in massive lay-offs in restive Papua, where the mine is the single largest private employer.We also think the government will be forced to continue to allow copper ore exports to continue, due to the impact a total ban would have on the recent $2.6bn acquisition of an 82.2 per cent stake in Newmont by a consortium comprising local mining magnates and Medco Energi, a company with personal ties to the ruling PDI-P party. FTCR’s conversations with sources close to the Newmont deal revealed that the acquisition was allegedly agreed on the basis it could continue exporting raw ore beyond 2017.Jakarta would have to amend the 2009 mining law in order to allow copper concentrate exports to continue. The Indonesian Mining Association told FTCR that, given the limited time available before the tighter 2017 regulations come in, the only realistic option is to issue a ministerial regulation. We think this is likely, in spite of possible legal challenges. Failure to reach a consensus would result in the sector being left in limbo for another year or two and jeopardise the Medco acquisition.These uncertainties could add to longer-term fiscal pressure on the government, though, unlike with oil and gas, the share of profits from the mining sector going into fiscal coffers has been comparatively small. That said, non-tax government revenue from the mining sector rose 27.5 per cent last year to Rp37.6tn ($2.78bn), despite a poor industry-wide environment.—FT Confidential Research is an independent research service from the Financial Times, providing in-depth analysis of and statistical insight into China and Southeast Asia. Our team of researchers in these key markets combine findings from our proprietary surveys with on-the-ground research to provide predictive analysis for investors.

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan chief vows to complete debt reduction plan
Subtitular: Miner’s borrowings ballooned with contentious purchase of oil assets
Texto: The chief executive of Freeport-McMoRan, the world’s largest listed copper producer, has vowed to stay with the company and complete a plan to slash its big debt load following the worst commodities downturn in a generation.Richard Adkerson said Freeport was now better positioned for an eventual recovery in copper prices after a series of asset sales.“I am committed to seeing this thing through,” said the 69-year-old company veteran.Freeport’s debt crisis can be traced back to $20bn of contentious oil and gas acquisitions in 2012, including the purchase of McMoRan Exploration, which took the Phoenix-based company back to its roots as an energy producer.James “Jim Bob” Moffett, then chairman of Freeport and chief executive of McMoRan Exploration, had long eyed reuniting mining and oil and gas operations under one company, following the 1994 split of McMoRan Exploration from Freeport.But the 2012 deals angered Freeport investors, who thought the company was focused on mining copper, and Mr Adkerson, who was chief executive at the time of the deals, made clear then that he realised he had a job to do to explain the strategy.Mr Adkerson has had a much tougher time coping with the consequences of the diversification strategy.As Freeport continued to invest in hydrocarbons, its net debt ballooned to more than $20bn by the end of 2015, just as falling oil and copper prices eroded the earnings needed to sustain the company’s borrowings. The spotlight on Freeport increased when Carl Icahn, the activist investor, disclosed an 8.5 per cent stake in the company, and took two seats on the board.As the commodity price rout persisted into 2016, Freeport’s shares sank to a 16-year low of below $4 in January, placing the company under severe pressure to implement plans to cut its debt load.“In my core I believed we had strong enough assets to see us through, but how we were going to [reduce debt] at that point was really not clear,” says Mr Adkerson.The solution to cutting Freeport’s borrowings sharply was to ramp up its asset disposal programme, including by putting its oil and gas business up for sale.In May, Freeport agreed to sell its largest African copper mine, called Tenke in the Democratic Republic of Congo, for $2.65bn to China Molybdenum, a Chinese natural resources group.Then in September Freeport announced a $2bn deal to dispose of its deepwater oil and gas assets in the Gulf of Mexico to Anadarko, the US energy producer — a transaction publicly supported by Mr Icahn.“All [the] indications are he [Mr Icahn] and his directors share our strong positive view about the future of the copper business,” said Mr Adkerson.Now, with Freeport’s net debt down to $17.9bn, from $20.4bn a year ago, and $5.2bn of asset sales agreed, Mr Adkerson is calling an end to the company’s downsizing.Last month, Freeport reported a quarterly net profit for the first time in two years. If the copper price stays between $5,000 and $5,500 per tonne — it is currently at about $6,000 after a surge last week — Freeport is on course to reduce net debt to between $8.4bn and $9.5bn by the end of 2017.Freeport’s target is for net debt below $10bn by the end of next year. “While we have a lot of work . . . we feel we proved our mettle this year,” says Mr Adkerson.But while Freeport’s shares have rallied 269 per cent from their January lows, the stock is up only 106 per cent so far this year — lagging well behind mining companies that are more diversified in their output, such as Anglo American and Glencore.Moreover, the China Molybdenum and Anadarko deals are yet to close. The Chinese transaction has been delayed by a dispute with Gécamines, the state-controlled mining company in DRC, which has filed a complaint at an international arbitration court. Meanwhile, Freeport’s bondholders are demanding higher fees and guarantees before they approve the Anadarko deal.Freeport says the Gécamines’ claim has no legal basis, and bondholder consent is not a condition of its transaction with Anadarko.Still, completing one of these deals before the end of 2016 is crucial to Freeport avoiding problems with credit lines, say analysts.“Freeport must close $3bn of asset sales by December 31 in order to avoid tripping a . . . covenant, says Morgan Stanley. “While we think there is a strong possibility Tenke slips into 2017, we expect Gulf of Mexico to close despite bondholder litigation.”Arguably the most pressing issue facing Freeport is the future of its Grasberg copper and gold mine in Indonesia — the crown jewel in the company’s portfolio.The company is locked in talks with the Indonesian government to try to secure long-term mining rights at Grasberg beyond 2021, and is unwilling to step up investment until it does.Mr Adkerson says it is in “everybody’s interest to resolve” the various issues around Grasberg.“I keep saying that because the government literally has more than a 50 per cent participation in the profitability and cash flows from Grasberg, so whenever there’s something that affects Freeport, it at the same time has impact on the government,” he adds.Meanwhile, Mr Aderkson will be hoping the recent surge in copper prices is sustained.The red metal — used extensively in household wiring and electricity networks — was lagging behind other industrial metals until two weeks ago.Amid signs the worst of the commodities downturn is over, Mr Adkerson’s mood has improved markedly since last year.At the London Metal Exchange conference in 2015, he used a sorrowful country and western song, “If you’re going through hell”, to highlight the mining industry’s plight.At this year’s conference this month, he borrowed a refrain from The Beatles. “It’s been a hard day’s night and we’ve been working like a dog,” he sang to laughter from the audience at London’s Grosvenor House hotel.Freeport-McMoRan’s ill-timed re-entry to the oil business four years ago did not just fuel its debt crisis but ultimately led to a reshaping of its senior management team and board.Following the deals to buy McMoRan Exploration and Plains Exploration & Production, running of the enlarged company was split between three men — Freeport founder James “Jim Bob” Moffett, Jim Flores, the head of oil and gas and former top manager at Plains, and chief executive Richard Adkerson.Today, only Mr Adkerson remains at Freeport.After 13 years as executive chairman, Mr Moffett stepped down in December, months after two representatives of activist investor Carl Icahn joined the Freeport board. Mr Moffett was replaced by the company’s lead independent director, Gerald Ford, who was named non-executive chairman.Four months later Mr Flores left the company after the oil business was restructured.“The people in our company and our board, who were in favour of doing this deal thought it was a good deal at the time, but it was one which had its challenges from the very start,” says Mr Adkerson.“Many of our shareholders wanted to see Freeport remain a pure copper company, to remain relatively unlevered and that all changed.”Blackrock’s Evy Hambro, one of the most influential investor voices in the mining world, slammed the deals in 2012, saying it was “incredibly disappointing” that the company’s management had decided to “break the trust” placed in them by shareholders.“I haven’t heard anything on this [conference] call that in any way justifies why these companies should be put together,” said Mr Hambro, echoing the thoughts of other investors who questioned the case for diversification, and the close connections between Freeport and McMoRan.At the time of the deals, Mr Moffett was chief executive of McMoRan as well as being chairman of Freeport.

Titular: Gecamines vows to pursue dispute against Freeport
Texto: The chairman of Gecamines, the state-owned mining company in the Democratic Republic of Congo, is determined to hold the line in its dispute with Freeport McMoran over the planned sale of a stake in the country’s biggest copper project.During an interview with the Financial Times, Albert Yuma Mulimbi said Gecamines would continue to oppose the deal until its position as owner of the country’s mining rights was acknowledged by Freeport, writes Henry Sanderson in London.“Gecamines is the owner of the mining rights, not the state. Gecamines is the only one to decide what to do with the mining rights,” said Mr Mulimbi.“If they want to sell they have to compensate the pre-emption rights of Gecamines,” said Mr Mulimbi, who was in London meeting potential investors.As part of a debt reduction plan, Freeport announced in May that it had sold its stake in the offshore vehicle that owns 80 per cent of the Tenke Fungurume project to China Molybdenum for $2.65bn.The proposed sale drew an immediate and angry response from Gecamines, which owns the remaining 20 per cent of the project. The state-owned miner said it had not been informed about the planned change of indirect ownership and therefore its position as owner of the country’s mineral rights had been overlooked.Last month, it went to the International Court of Arbitration in Paris and filed a complaint against TF Holding, the Bermuda-based company through which Freeport and its partner Lundin Mining own the mine. Unless the court is able to authorise the transaction, Gecamines says the deal should be blocked.“It’s so ridiculous to think they can sell that without having an agreement with Gecamines. It’s just a nonsense,” said Mr Mulimbi, who claims the company has the financial backing to buy Freeport’s stake in the mine.“We’ll see who is right, the only way to stop this arbitration is for Gecamines to stop it and we’re not going to stop it,” he said. “We’re 100 per cent confident we’ll win the arbitration,” he said. “100 per cent.”For its part Freeport, which is trying to shore up its balance sheet, claims the sale to China Moly does not violate any agreements.“The transaction is done in offshore entities that are shareholders in Tenke Fungurume,” Freeport chief executive Richard Adkerson, also in London, told the Financial Times on Tuesday. “Literally nothing has changed within the country.“Gecamines is not a party to these offshore companies, and our legal advisers have a strong view that they have no rights to these companies. They are asserting otherwise and that’s why they have filed arbitration,” explained Mr Adkerson.Congo is one of the world’s biggest producers of copper, but most of the metal is mined by international companies rather than Gecamines. Mr Mulimbi wants to change that by working with foreign investors to develop new projects.His aim is to return the company to its former glory – in the 1980s, it was one of the biggest mining producers in the world as it worked with foreign investors to develop new projects. It aims to produce 125,000 tonnes of copper a year in three years, from 19,000 tonnes in 2015.The company is also auditing all major mining projects in the country, after 15 years of getting little or no dividends from foreign companies, said Mr Mulimbi.

Titular: Copper miner Freeport swings back to profit
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan suggested it could deal with its debt burden from growing cash flows and did not reveal further asset sale plans as it reported a return to quarterly profit.The world’s largest listed copper producer has agreed $6.6bn of asset sales this year but has still not concluded the largest deal, the $2.65bn sale of its Tenke mine in the Democratic Republic of Congo to China Molybdenum, which was announced in May, writes James Wilson in London.Reporting third-quarter net income of $217m on Tuesday, Freeport said it expected to book $5.2bn of gross proceeds from Tenke and other deals by the end of the year.Freeport is trying to deal with a net debt burden that stood at $17.9bn at the end of the third quarter, compared with about $19bn three months earlier.Freeport said it would continue to aggressively manage its costs and capital spending and said it was focused on retaining a “high-quality portfolio of long-lived copper assets positioned to generate value as market conditions improve”.With improvements to mines at Cerro Verde, in Peru, and Grasberg, in Indonesia, Freeport “expects to generate substantial cash flows for debt reduction,” the company said.Since mid-September Freeport, which is an oil producer as well as copper miner, has also announced at least $2.6bn of deals to sell oil and gas assets in the Gulf of Mexico and in California. Both deals are among those expected to close by the end of the year.Lundin Mining, Freeport’s joint venture partner at Tenke, has not said whether it will exercise its right to match China Moly’s offer for Freeport’s stake, having already several times pushed back the deadline for a decision.Reports from Congo have also suggested that Gecamines, the state mining company that has a share of output from Tenke, is seeking to challenge the deal. Freeport – which is selling its 80 per cent share in a joint venture that controls Tenke – has previously dismissed the idea that Gecamines has any say in who it sells to.The $217m of net income reported for the third quarter compares with a $3.8bn loss 12 months earlier when Freeport reported $3.7bn of impairments to its oil and gas assets.Richard Adkerson, Freeport’s chief executive, said:Our actions during 2016 position us to achieve our objectives of restoring our balance sheet strength and focusing our strategy on our industry leading portfolio of high quality, long-lived copper assets. Our announced asset sale transactions totaling $6.6 billion combined with significant free cash flow generation in the coming quarters will enable us to achieve our debt reduction targets.Freeport’s shares have risen 50 per cent this year but that has underperformed most mining peers. Shares in Anglo American, for example, have risen 260 per cent in London.

Titular: Freeport sells onshore California oil and gas assets
Texto: US mining giant Freeport-McMoRan said it agreed to sell its onshore California oil and gas assets to private energy company Sentinel Peak Resources California for up to $742m.The deal consists of $592m in cash at its closing, which is expected in the fourth quarter of 2016, and an additional $50m per year between 2018 and 2020 if Brent crude oil averages $70 per barrel or higher. The properties generated an average of 28.6 thousand barrels of oil per day in sales volume, and $400m in revenue, for the 12 months ended June.Freeport said it “does not expect to record a material gain or loss on the transaction.”The announcement is the latest in a string of asset sales across the world as the miner aims to cut debt amid sluggish demand for commodities. Sales includes oil and gas assets in the Gulf of Mexico for $2bn, a stake a copper mine in Arizona for $1bn, and a stake in an African copper business for $2.65bn.After losing nearly a quarter of its market value over the past year, Freeport shares rose 1.6 per cent to $9.79 in premarket trading.

Titular: US natural resource stocks under pressure
Subtitular: All three benchmark indices in the red on Wednesday
Texto: US-listed natural resource companies came under particular pressure in a poor day for US stocks as commodity prices fell by the most in over three weeks and put pressure on equities.The S&P materials index fell 1.2 per cent on Wednesday, making it the second-worst-performing sector of the US equity gauge, paring its advance this year to 11.6 per cent.The broader index dipped, too, extending a streak of trading sessions without a move bigger than 1 per cent to 33 days as markets have been listless over the summer.US stock market indices have been slowly but sedately grinding higher in recent months, as investors await more clues on where corporate earnings and economic growth is heading, but encouraged by the Federal Reserve’s cautious stance and compelled to jump into high-dividend stocks due to rock-bottom bond yields.Wednesday’s stock market decline was led by miners and natural resources companies such as Newmont, Freeport-McMoRan and Alcoa, which fell 7.7 per cent to $39.85, 7.5 per cent to $11.08 and 4.4 per cent to $10.04, respectively.Commodities have enjoyed a healthy rally this year, clawing back much of the losses of recent years, but Bloomberg’s main natural resources index slipped 1.2 per cent on Wednesday, its worst performance since August 1.The slide was led by a decline in oil prices, with West Texas Intermediate and Brent crude falling 2.8 per cent to $46.80 and 1.9 per cent to $49, respectively.The decline was extended by data released on Wednesday unexpectedly showing that US energy inventories rose last week.The Energy Department said US crude stocks rose by 2.5m barrels, compared with expectations of a 495,000 barrel drawdown, while gasoline inventories ticked higher by 36,000 barrels, missing forecasts for a 1.3m barrel decline.The crude oil price decline weighed on energy companies in the S&P 500, sending the industry index down 0.3 per cent.12 out of 68Tech companies in the main US stock market gauge that rose on WednesdayThe biggest fallers were the industry’s weaker members, such as Anadarko, Williams Cos and Chesapeake, which fell 3.4 per cent to $54.16, 1.8 per cent to $28.06 and 3.1 per cent to $6.26, respectively. However, bigger energy majors like Occidental, ExxonMobil and Chevron edged higher 1.1 per cent to $77.72, 0.3 per cent to $88.02 and 0.5 per cent to $102.20, respectively.In point terms, Apple was the biggest contributor to the S&P 500’s decline, with the world’s biggest company by market capitalisation slipping 0.8 per cent to $108.03 to shave half a point off the index by itself.IBM also contributed to an underwhelming day for technology stocks, falling 0.8 per cent to $159.05. In fact, only 12 of the 68 technology companies in the main US stock market gauge climbed on Wednesday, taking the index 0.5 per cent lower on the day after hitting a 16-year high on Tuesday.The S&P 500 declined 0.5 per cent to 2,175.4, the Dow Jones shed 0.4 per cent to 18,481.5 and the Nasdaq fell 0.8 per cent to 5,217.7.

Titular: Freeport pulls IPO of energy unit
Texto: Copper miner Freeport-McMoRan has pulled the initial public offering of its oil and gas unit as the price of crude oil has tumbled.Freeport-McMoRan Oil & Gas said in a regulatory filing late on Friday that it was withdrawing its IPO registration, but that it may still launch a private offering.The energy exploration and production group, which is wholly owned by Freeport-McMoRan, had initially filed for the IPO last summer. However, the price of US crude oil has tumbled about 20 per cent since then.Freeport-McMoRan has also struggled amid a broader decline in the price of commodities, including copper. Its shares are off by almost 50 per cent over the past 12 months.

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan gains ground on broker upgrade
Subtitular: Energy sector given a boost from crude price forecasts
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan was one of the leading gainers on the S&P 500 on Monday after analysts at Cowen & Co boosted their price target on the stock.Freeport shares jumped 6.1 per cent to $11.05, after analysts at Cowen lifted their price target on the stock to $15 — the highest on Wall Street — from $10, and maintained their “outperform” rating, noting that the company had “made impressive progress in the deleveraging progress”.Earlier this month Freeport said that it had struck a deal to sell its stake in a vast Congo copper mine to China Molybdenum CMOC for $2.65bn in cash as it stepped up efforts to reduce its debt burden.The company also said it was in exclusive talks to sell its interests in Freeport Cobalt, its Finnish mine-to-market solution business for cobalt products, and the Kisanfu Exploration project in Congo, to CMOC for $100m and $50m respectively.“We believe management remains steadfastly focused on right-sizing the balance sheet for the current environment,” Anthony Rizzuto, an analyst at Cowen, said. “There has been considerable debate as to the appropriate next step for [Freeport]. This could take the form of further outright asset sales, minority interest transaction, or even an equity issuance.”Freeport shares have advanced 63 per cent so far this year, with their performance at the start of the week also buoyed by a broader rally among miners.Oil prices received a shot in the arm after analysts at Goldman Sachs upgraded their crude price forecasts. That in turn ignited a rally in shares of energy companies, with the S&P 500 energy sector rising 1.6 per cent and posting the biggest gains along with the materials sector on the benchmark index.At the close in New York, the S&P 500 had advanced 1 per cent to 2,066.66 while the Dow Jones Industrial Average also gained 1 per cent to 17,710.71. The Nasdaq Composite rose 1.2 per cent to 4,775.46.Gold miners climbed on the back of a stronger physical price as the precious metal surged as much as 1.2 per cent to $1,288.83 an ounce earlier in the day, following soft economic data out of China.Shares in Newmont Mining advanced 4 per cent to $35.42, Barrick Gold climbed 2.7 per cent to $18.91 and Goldcorp rose 3 per cent to $18.49. Miners held their advance even as gold pared its gains, ending the day 0.1 per cent higher at $1,274.66 an ounce.“The miners are benefiting from the general sentiment that bad data out of China could draw another round of stimulus,” said Jeremy Sussman, an analyst at Clarksons Platou Securities. “Miners tend to do well when data suggests a degree of uncertainty.”Elsewhere, Apple shares advanced 3.7 per cent to $93.88 after Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway disclosed a $1bn plus stake in the iPhone maker.Shares in the world’s largest company had declined 14 per cent so far this year as of last week after the company disclosed is first quarterly revenue drop in 13 years and its first drop in iPhone sales.Anacor Pharmaceuticals surged more than 57 per cent to $100.67 after Pfizer said it would buy the company for $5.2bn.mamta.badkar@ft.comTwitter: @mamtabadkar

Titular: Energy, Apple help US stock rally
Texto: A rally in crude prices and Apple shares helped the S&P 500 close in the green for the first time in four days.The S&P 500, which has posted three consecutive weekly losses, closed 1 per cent higher at 2,066.66 on Monday, with material and energy stocks leading the benchmark index.Oil advanced after analysts at Goldman Sachs lifted their crude outlook citing supply disruptions and strong demand. The S&P 500 energy index finished the day 1.6 per cent higher. Meanwhile, a more than 6 per cent rally in shares of Freeport-McMoRan helped the S&P 500 material sector log gains of 1.6 per cent.Elsewhere shares in Apple, the world’s largest company, ended the day 3.7 per cent higher at $93.88, after Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway disclosed a $1bn plus stake in the iPhone maker. Apple exerts more influence on the Dow, which is a price-weighted index.

Titular: China Molybdenum: changing tune
Subtitular: Miner’s newly acquired assets are transformational
Texto: China Molybdenum’s corporate anthem needs an update. Its current theme — the sun rising over the hills of Luoyang — is now much less global than the company itself. Over the weekend, the Hong Kong- and Shanghai-listed company, with a market value of $7.5bn, said it had a deal to buy assets from Anglo American and Freeport-McMoRan for $4.2bn. On Monday, the Hong Kong shares opened after a week’s suspension. They rose 8 per cent.The new assets are transformational. Last year, China Moly (usually referred to as CMOC) earned more than half of its revenues and three-fifths of its gross profit from molybdenum and tungsten, elements used in making steel and alloys. Copper accounted for most of the balance. Freeport-McMoRan’s Democratic Republic of Congo copper and cobalt assets alone will nearly quadruple CMOC’s earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation. Its copper reserves and resources will septuple. The company’s reliance on steel will be significantly reduced, but it is not simply shifting towards copper. Cobalt is used in rechargeable batteries — such as those used in electric vehicles — and the Anglo American assets include minerals for use in fertilisers.Even amid the steel downturn, CMOC can afford the purchases. It has net cash of more than $700m. Last year, despite falls of 30 per cent in the prices of molybdenum and tungsten (and 20 per cent in copper) it managed a net profit and positive operating cash flow. It has enviably low operating costs; just above $4/lb in moly, far lower than the $7/lb achieved by world number one producer Freeport-McMoRan.The diversification is welcome. There are motivated sellers, and while concerns bubble around commodity speculation in China, more stimulus is expected to spur demand. Meanwhile, residential property starts have been picking up with a recovery in prices. So long as that continues, the company ditty will only get more upbeat.Email the Lex team at lex@ft.com

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan mired in Indonesian uncertainty
Subtitular: US company is struggling to secure a contract extension at vast Papua copper and gold mine
Texto: Richard Adkerson calls Grasberg the most complex mine in the world, and it is difficult to argue with Freeport-McMoRan’s chief executive.Situated 4km above sea level among the soaring peaks of Indonesia’s eastern Papua province, Freeport’s Grasberg mine bores into rain-soaked land prone to earthquakes as well as separatist violence. Tens of thousands of people work alongside huge diggers and trucks at what is one of the world’s largest copper and gold assets, with reserves worth almost $100bn at today’s prices.This explains why Grasberg has been the foundation of Freeport’s place as the world’s largest listed copper mining company for almost 30 years. But now that control is mired in uncertainty, with Freeport struggling to gain approval from the Indonesian government for an extension to its Grasberg contract, amid nationalist desire to control more natural resources in Southeast Asia’s largest economy.“We have a current need to get this resolved,” says Mr Adkerson in an interview with the Financial times. “There is growing pressure, growing concern and a growing need for us to act.”With the mining sector braced for a long commodities downturn, the dispute is an illustration of how the balance of power may be shifting between natural resources companies wanting to protect investments and governments demanding a greater share of falling revenues. And in Indonesia the question of whether to extend Freeport’s contract at Grasberg has become a test of the administration of President Joko Widodo and his pledge to court foreign investment.The agreement allowing Freeport to mine at Grasberg expires in 2021 and Freeport insists it has the right to renew this “contract of work” for two more decades, to 2041. But while Freeport last year received assurances from Sudirman Said, the Indonesian mining minister, about an extension, nothing is finalised.Rizal Ramli, one of the most outspoken members of Mr Widodo’s cabinet, insists Freeport has been given no assurances on its contract, saying: “They have to change the way they operate in Indonesia.”Freeport, which is seeking to cut its large debt load amid the commodities downturn, says $5bn of planned investment over the next five years at Grasberg is at risk.So far Freeport has invested on the basis of assurances from the government, but Mr Adkerson says: “In today’s world, where shareholders are questioning the company on capital spending . . . we are experiencing increasing shareholder concern about our continuing to do that.”Freeport’s figures make Grasberg’s significance clear. Last year, even with commodity prices at multiyear lows, the mine contributed $3bn, or 20 per cent, of Freeport’s revenue; this year should be more lucrative, with copper output expected to almost double and gold production to be 50 per cent higher.Grasberg is assuming increased importance to Freeport as the company sells other key assets to reduce its borrowings. On Monday, it announced an agreement to sell its Tenke copper mine in Africa for $2.65bn.But Grasberg’s importance also shows why the mine is such a lightning rod in Indonesia for critics.Among other things, Freeport has been strongly criticised by environmental groups and some investors over the way Grasberg’s waste is discharged into a local river.“Of all the companies that operate in Indonesia [Freeport] is the one that is most vilified, from nationalists to environmentalists,” says Paul Rowland, a Jakarta-based political analyst. Public scrutiny of Freeport “means it’s very difficult to put together an agreement with them”, he adds.After Jakarta banned miners from exporting unprocessed ore in 2014, Freeport struck a deal to expand smelter capacity and pay higher royalties and export duties.Freeport has also pledged to divest up to 20 per cent of its local unit. At the moment the miner owns more than 90 per cent of PT-FI, the local company that runs Grasberg, with less than 10 per cent in state hands.Mr Adkerson says an initial public offering locally of PT-FI could help Freeport be seen as more Indonesian. But as with much connected with Grasberg, the two sides are at odds.The Indonesian government has said the sale of a 10.64 per cent stake in PT-FI should be worth $630m, but Freeport says fair market value would be closer to $1.7bn. A recent report by Deutsche Bank analysts estimates the 10.64 per cent stake could be worth $1.2bn to $1.7bn.Freeport is not the only miner concerned with Grasberg. Rio Tinto helped to fund part of the mine’s development and is therefore set to get a 40 per cent share of output from 2021 — but only if the contract with Indonesia is renewed.Ultimately Freeport could seek international arbitration, but Mr Adkerson says: “We continue to work to avoid having to resort to that dispute resolution process — we do not believe that would be positive for Indonesia or for our company.”Mr Widodo’s government appears divided on how to deal with Freeport’s contract extension, and critics say the case has exposed the president’s weaknesses.Conscious of the adverse commodities environment, the government has pledged to revise its mining regulations this year.Sujatmiko, a mining ministry spokesperson who goes by one name, says Jakarta is reviewing the obligation on mining companies to develop processing and refinery facilities, as well as the timelines set to renew contracts.“We realise that the global climate on investment in the mining sector has significantly changed compared to the period when the Indonesian mining law was set,” he adds.Others in the government are less willing to acknowledge the miner’s requests for early resolution of Grasberg’s future.Luhut Panjaitan, a former general and close ally of Mr Widodo, has insisted discussions on the contract extension can begin only in 2019 and implored Freeport to “respect” local regulations.“This is more about politics,” says Erwan Teguh, head of research at CIMB Securities in Jakarta. “For [Mr Widodo] to say ‘I will stick to the law and say I can only negotiate with you in 2019’ — politically that makes [more] sense for him than succumbing to a lobby.”Late last year a political scandal highlighted the difficulties Freeport-McMoRan faces in Indonesia as it pushes to safeguard its right to operate the Grasberg copper and gold mine.Amid rising tensions between Freeport and the Indonesian government, the speaker in the lower house of parliament was accused of trying to extort a stake in the US mining company’s local unit in return for help in extending its contract in the country.A televised investigation by the House of Representatives’ ethics committee put the issue at the centre of public debate, with secret tapes that allegedly recorded Setya Novanto’s conversation with Freeport executives.Although Mr Novanto said his comments that Freeport should award shares in its local unit to President Joko Widodo were made in jest, he resigned from his position of speaker in the House of Representatives in December, and the scandal was termed Indonesia’s “Watergate moment” by political analysts and foreign media.Given that Sudirman Said, the mining minister, filed a complaint about Mr Novanto, some political analysts say the parliamentary investigation lent credibility to Mr Widodo’s government, showing high-level corruption would no longer be tolerated.Mr Widodo, a furniture salesman turned politician, has a reputation for clean governance and won the presidential election in 2014 on an anti-corruption platform. Few in Jakarta ever believed Mr Widodo was involved in the alleged extortion.But sceptics say the saga reflects deep divisions within Mr Widodo’s cabinet, where there are signs of growing nationalism, with some officials eager to curtail Freeport’s power in the remote Papua province.“It is very important for the president to control all of this, to show his commitment and control his ministers,” says Marwan Batubara, executive director of Indonesia Resources Study, a research body.

Titular: Freeport sells key copper mine for $2.7bn to China Molybdenum
Subtitular: US mining company aims to cut its debt load through disposals, including an important African asset
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan on Monday outlined plans to sell its largest African copper mine to China Molybdenum for $2.65bn, in the US mining company’s most decisive step so far to reduce its $20bn debt load.The sale of the Tenke Fungurume mine in the Democratic Republic of Congo will be seen as one of the mining industry’s biggest forced sales after a steep commodity downturn that has pushed several companies to take drastic action to shore up their balance sheets.It is the second large acquisition within two weeks by China Molybdenum, a Chinese natural resources group that said this month it wanted to expand its global presence. CMOC last month agreed to buy Brazilian assets from Anglo American, another miner with a large debt load, for $1.5bn.Freeport is the world’s largest listed copper miner, and also made an expensive and contentious expansion into oil and gas in 2012, but last year’s plunge in commodity prices put pressure on the company to reduce its debts.Richard Adkerson, chief executive, is willing to consider offloading big assets, and Freeport in February sold a 13 per cent stake in its Morenci copper mine in the US to Sumitomo Metals of Japan for $1bn.“Since the start of 2016, we have announced over $4bn in asset sale transactions,” Mr Adkerson said on Monday. “We are committed to our immediate objective of reducing debt while retaining a large portfolio of high quality assets and resources and a leading position in the global copper industry.” Freeport recorded net debt of $20bn at March 31.The Tenke mine produced 204,000 tonnes of copper last year, generating revenue of $1.4bn and earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation of $513m, according to CMOC.Steele Li, executive chairman of CMOC, said: “Tenke is well positioned to generate strong cash flow throughout the commodity cycle and, by virtue of its substantial mineral endowment, to continue producing high-grade copper for decades to come.”Freeport controls 56 per cent of Tenke, one of the five big mines in its portfolio.A further 24 per cent of Tenke is owned by Canada’s Lundin Mining, which has three months in which to exercise a right of first refusal to buy the stake Freeport is proposing to sell to CMOC. The remaining 20 per cent is owned by Congo’s state mining group.Fraser Phillips, analyst at RBC Capital Markets, said the price for Tenke implied a flat long-term copper price of $2.57 per pound, compared with $2.94/lb in the Morenci deal.“The lower implied valuation for Tenke likely reflects the fact that Sumitomo was an existing shareholder in Morenci and the much higher geopolitical risk in the DRC,” he added.Tenke was developed by Phelps Dodge before its $26bn acquisition by Freeport in 2007.CMOC may pay a further $120m to Freeport if the prices of copper and cobalt — an industrial metal secured as a byproduct of mining at Tenke — reach certain levels by 2019.In a further potential deal with CMOC, Freeport is in talks with the Chinese group over a sale of more cobalt assets for $100m, including a refinery in Finland. Cobalt is used in batteries in mobile phones and electric vehicles.CMOC’s $1.5bn deal for Anglo’s niobium and phosphate assets in April came after it bought the Northparkes copper mine in Australia from Rio Tinto in 2013.

Titular: Freeport to sell Congo copper mine for $2.65bn
Texto: Freeport McMoRan has struck a deal to sell its stake in a vast Congo copper mine to China Molybdenum (CMOC) for $2.65bn in cash as the US miner and oil producer steps up efforts to reduce its debt load.Plunging oil and copper prices have affected Freeport’s ability to pay down its large debt burden. Net debt stood at more than $20bn at the end of March, compared to the company’s market capitalisation of $15.4bn.In response, the company has cut its oil and gas workforce and embarked on an asset disposal programme.Under the terms of the deal announced on Monday, Freeport will be selling its 70 per cent stake in TF Holdings, a Bermuda holding company that indirectly owns an 80 per cent interest in Tenke Fungurume Mining – a vast copper mining project in the south-eastern Katanga province of the Democratic Republic of Congo.Freeport could receive an additional $120m if prices for copper and cobalt reaches a certain level between 2018 and 2019.This is unlikely to be Freeport’s last deal with CMOC. The company said in a statement that it is in exclusive talks to see its interests in Freeport Cobalt, its Finnish mine to market solution business for cobalt products, and the Kisanfu Exploration project in Congo to CMOC for $100m and $50m respectively.Last month, CMOC also snapped up one of Anglo American’s largest Brazilian business for $1.5bn.CMOC, which is listed in Shanghai and Hong Kong, is one of the world’s largest molybdenum and tungsten producers, and Australia’s fourth largest producer of copper.The Chinese company’s key operating assets include Sandaozhuang molybdenum-tungsten mine and facilities located in Luoyang, China as well as the Northparkes copper-gold mine located in New South Wales, Australia.

Titular: Freeport to cut quarter of oil jobs
Subtitular: Efforts to find buyer for crude business stall
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan is cutting a quarter of the workforce in its oil and gas division after failing to secure a buyer for the business.On Tuesday, the US copper miner and oil producer — which has been trying to reduce its debt by $20bn — posted a $4.2bn net loss for the first three months of the year, as commodity prices continued to fall.Freeport is among the miners facing severe financial pressure because of the sharp decline in prices, and the strain of supporting high levels of debt. It had increased its borrowing significantly in 2012, as it sought to gain greater exposure to oil and gas through two deals that angered some shareholders.Freeport is now trying to agree deals to sell assets and cut debt, announcing $1.3bn of transactions involving its copper projects in the first quarter. But while the miner expects talks over more asset sales to yield results by June, it said efforts to sell its entire oil and gas business — which has onshore and offshore US operations — had stalled.“Further weakening in oil and gas prices and negative credit and financing market conditions . . . had a significant unfavourable impact on the process,” Freeport said. “A number of parties have interest in select assets . . . in the interim, [we are] taking immediate steps to reduce oil and gas costs further.”On a conference call with investors, Richard Adkerson, chief executive, said it was “a tough market”.“We looked for potential buyers aggressively,” he said. “We just concluded that the values that would be available did not reflect the long-term value of those assets.”A 25 per cent cut to the oil and gas division’s workforce — which will result in a $40m charge in this quarter — will now follow Freeport’s restructuring of the management of that business. It had operated largely as a standalone subsidiary of Freeport since the 2012 acquisitions of Plains Exploration and McMoRan Exploration.James Flores, the former chief executive of Plains who became chief executive of Freeport Oil & Gas, left the business this month along with other senior managers. His unit was “being restructured as an operating division”, Freeport said.Freeport’s $4.2bn quarterly net loss included $4bn of charges, mainly linked to cuts to the carrying values of oil and gas assets. That compares with a $2.5bn loss in the same period of 2015. Stripping out charges, Freeport reported an adjusted net quarterly loss of $197m.Freeport had $20.8bn of debt and $330m of cash on its balance sheet at the end of March.Mr Adkerson said he was confident asset sales would be agreed. “We are much more confident today than we were during the first quarter when the market was in such a concerning situation,” he said, noting a “scarcity of quality assets in copper”.While copper prices have fallen, most mining groups continue to believe the commodity has relatively strong long-term growth potential, given expectations for supply and demand.“We are putting our highest priority on our balance sheet . . . we would look for opportunities involving any of our assets,” Mr Adkerson said. “We want to get this thing done . . . we have a real sense of urgency.”Freeport shares fell 3 per cent early in US trading.

Titular: Freeport to axe 25% of oil and gas workforce
Texto: Freeport McMoRan is cutting its oil and gas workforce by 25 per cent as it grapples with more than $20bn of net debt.The US copper miner and oil producer posted a $4.2bn net loss for the first three months of 2016, including net charges of $4bn, compared with a $2.5bn net loss in the same period a year ago.Plunging oil and copper prices have affected Freeport’s ability to pay down its large debt burden. The company is trying to sell assets to pay down borrowing, writes James Wilson in London.In the first quarter Freeport struck deals to sell $1.3bn of mining assets. But the Arizona-based group said its efforts to sell its oil and gas business had been bogged down. The company said:Further weakening in oil and gas prices and negative credit and financing market conditions during first-quarter 2016 had a significant unfavorable impact on the process. While the process did not identify a buyer for the entire oil and gas business, a number of parties have interest in select assets, and FCX continues to engage in discussions with parties interested in potential asset or joint venture transactions.Last month Freeport said James Flores, chief executive of its oil and gas business, would depart along with a trio of other senior executives. The group had run Freeport’s oil and gas business since the miner acquired Plains Exploration in 2013 – one of the deals that contributed to Freeport’s debt burden.“The newly structured oil and gas management team is actively engaged in managing costs and developing plans to preserve and enhance asset values. FCX expects to record a charge of approximately $40 million in second-quarter 2016 associated with workforce reductions and other restructuring costs,” Freeport said on Tuesday as it announced the 25 per cent workforce cut.

Titular: Antofagasta drops final dividend as copper price slide bites
Subtitular: Mining group follows rivals as it builds capacity to take advantage of future recovery
Texto: Antofagasta will not issue a final dividend following a steep fall in earnings, becoming the latest copper producer to sharply adjust its payout to investors following a slide in the price of the metal last year.Pre-tax profits from the miner’s core business fell from $1.5bn to $259m, with a fall of almost 10 per cent in the volume of copper sales adding to the pain of a 24 per cent fall in price during the year, according to the 2015 annual results.Antofagasta said its recommendation not to pay a final dividend was in line with its policy to pay out at least 35 per cent of annual earnings, which was achieved with the interim dividend.Shares in the group fell 11 per cent after the news on Tuesday morning.Within the past few months copper miners including Freeport-McMoRan, Glencore and Anglo American have suspended dividend payments while Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton have decided to abandon longstanding ambitions not to cut the payout for investors.Antofagasta spent $1bn last year to buy a half-share in the Zaldivar copper mine in Chile from Barrick Gold. The FTSE 100 miner further increased its focus on its core business by selling a water utility in Chile.“The year was one of change and the group has emerged stronger, more focused on its core business and operating at significantly lower costs,” said Diego Hernandez, chief executive.This year Antofagasta said the contribution from Zaldivar and the ramp-up of its Antucoya project could push output to its highest annual level, while operating costs should fall to 2012 levels. Antofagasta has been battling rising costs for power and water in Chile.Each of its mines was generating operating cash flow, Mr Hernandez said.“We know that copper is a cyclical industry and as a result of the actions that we have taken over the past year we will be positioned to benefit from the recovery when it comes,” he said. “In the meantime, our focus is on optimising our operations and projects under construction to cut costs and free up cash flow whilst retaining the flexibility to accelerate investment for future growth if circumstances are appropriate.”Antofagasta’s net annual income fell from $851m to $702m, including $602m related to the sale of, and earnings from, its water business. Net earnings from continuing operations fell from $422m to $5.5m.Sales fell 34 per cent to $3.4bn while pre-tax profits from continuing operations fell from $1.5bn to $259m, and operating cash flow was down 66 per cent to $858m.Antofagasta said it expected its share of Zaldivar’s output to be at leat 50,000 tonnes, with $15m to $20m of synergies achieved from integrating the mine into its business.Net debt at the end of last year rose to $525m after the Zaldivar purchase compared with net cash of $315m at the end of 2014. Antofagasta said it would take out a loan to finance 50 per cent of the $1bn purchase price “to preserve the group’s financing flexibility”.

Titular: JC Penney retail chain jumps after beating forecasts
Subtitular: Materials, energy and financials make gains on muted day for stocks
Texto: Shares in JC Penney, the department store in the middle of a turnround, rallied on Friday after the company reported stronger-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings.The Texas-based retail chain jumped 14.7 per cent to $9.59 after the company reported adjusted earnings of 39 cents a share, on sales of $4bn. That compared with analysts’ expectations for earnings of 21 cents a share, on sales of $4bn.However, the company’s net loss widened to $131m, or 43 cents a share, compared with $35m, or 11 cents, a share in the year-ago period.The retailer said that its selling, general and administrative (SG & A) expenses decreased by $218m, or 270 basis points, compared with the previous year.“Although it looks like a big bottom-line beat . . . the entire beat came on SG & A, which in our view isn’t the highest quality,” said Paul Lejuez, an analyst at Citi, but he noted that the beat was “likely to scare some shorts”.“Still, the company seems to be making some improvements to business, which, when combined with easier comparisons, is likely to generate reasonably good results in the near term,” he said.Same-store sales, a key industry metric, advanced 4.1 per cent in line with forecasts.JC Penney has been a bright spot in the department-store sector — with same-store sales declining 4.8 per cent at Macy’s, 2 per cent at Dillard’s and 7.1 per cent at Sears Holdings — amid the rise of ecommerce and competition from off-price retailers such as TJX Cos.Marvin Ellison, chief executive, noted that JC Penney continued to “win market share in a competitive environment”.JC Penney also said it expected adjusted earnings per share to be positive in 2016.Daniela Nedialkova, an analyst at Atlantic Equities, said it was “a faster than expected return to profitability”.JC Penney has worked to reinvent itself after a failed turnround led by Ron Johnson, former Apple executive, alienated customers. The retailer has since brought back its popular coupons and discounts.JC Penney shares have advanced 44 per cent since the start of 2016.Elsewhere, the S&P 500 materials sectors rallied 1.4 per cent, outpacing the broader market, as the price of copper rose to the highest level of 2016.Freeport-McMoRan, a copper miner that has been pressured by low commodity prices, rallied 4.4 per cent to $7.43. The stock is still down by almost two-thirds over the past 12 months.Energy stocks also performed well on the back of a rise in the price of US crude oil.Transocean, which operates offshore oil rigs, jumped 5.1 per cent to $8.65. Meanwhile, exploration and production company Marathon Oil added 8.7 per cent to $8.03.At the close of trade, the S&P 500 had retreated 0.2 per cent to 1,948, the Dow Jones Industrial Average shed 0.3 per cent to 16,639.9, and the Nasdaq Composite crept up 0.2 per cent to 4,590.5.Wall Street sentiment was given an earlier lift from data showing that the US economy capped 2015 on a stronger footing than initially thought, along with a separate report showing that the Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation gauge rose to the highest level in three years.Materials, energy and financials, all sectors that are seen as sensitive to the economy, made gains. Meanwhile, utilities, consumer staples and telecommunications, all defensive sectors, fell.

Titular: BHP Billiton slashes dividend as profits slide
Texto: Anglo-Australian miner BHP Billiton axed its interim dividend by 74 per cent as it seeks to protect its credit rating amid a commodities slump that has chipped away at the company’s bottom line.BHP announced that it is adopting a dividend policy that provides a minimum 50 per cent payout of underlying attributable profit at every reporting period. The Board has now agreed to pay an interim dividend of 16 cents a share in the first half, from 62 cents a share.This brought an end to BHP’s commitment to a progressive payout policy, under which the company was to maintain or raise its dividend when it announced interim results, write Mamta Badkar, James Wilson and Jamie Smyth.Jac Nasser, chairman, said “we have not made these changes lightly” and noted:The changes to the dividend policy announced today reflect the Board’s assessment of the outlook for commodities and the increased financial flexibility this demand. While the continued development of emerging ecnomies will underpin longer-term demand growth for commodities, we now believe the period of weaker prices and higher volatility will be prolonged.Ratings agency Standard and Poor’s cut its rating on the miner to ‘A’ from ‘A+’ and put the ratings on creditwatch negative this month noting that it could downgrade BHP’s ratings after its earnings, depending on the announced dividend policy.A swoon in commodity prices has prompted some of the world’s largest miners, including Glencore, Freeport-McMoRan and Anglo American, to suspended dividend payments.The news came alongside a 92 per cent drop in underlying profits of $412m from continuing operations in the six months to the end of December, compared with $4.9bn in the year ago period. This widely missed analysts’ expectations for $727.2m.The miner reported a net loss for the first half of its financial year of $5.7bn compared with income of $4.3bn in the same period last year.A drop in the price of iron ore, copper and oil has weighed on the miner and prompted it to writedown more than $7bn pre-tax (or about $4.9bn after tax) on its US shale assets last month.BHP said it is implementing a company wide reorganisation and a management shake up. Iron ore boss Jimmy Wilson and oil head Tim Cutt are leaving. Mike Henry and Daniel Malchuk are handed wider operational responsibility over a suite of assets in Australia and the Americas respectively.“Slower growth in China and the disruption of OPEC have resulted in lower prices than expected,” said Andrew Mackenzie, BHP chief executive. He said the new dividend policy and transparent capital management framework were part of a strategy to manage volatility.BHP shares have also been pressured after its Samarco dam in Brazil burst last year leaving more than a dozen dead and polluting the nation’s second-largest river system.BHP’s shares in Australia have declined more than 40 per cent over the past 12 months.

Titular: Beaten up energy stocks lead US rally
Texto: The energy and materials sectors led US equities sharply into the black on Monday on the back of a rise in the price of crude oil and industrial metals.The bounce in crude came amid hopes that the glut of crude supply may ebb as producers respond to low prices.The International Energy Agency said in a report on Monday that US shale production may fall over the next two years as oil producers scale back investment. Friday offered the latest evidence of the retrenchment as a survey showed the the number of US oil rigs had dropped to the lowest since December 2009.Saudi Arabia and Russia also said last week that they would agree to freeze oil output at current levels if other big producers agree to such a move.US crude oil prices rallied 7.1 per cent to $31.75 a barrel, having risen 21.9 per cent since hitting the lowest level since 2003 on February 11. Brent, the international benchmark, climbed 5.3 per cent to $34.77 a barrel.The advance pushed the S&P 500 energy index up 1.8 per cent. Among the companies posting large gains was Apache, an exploration and production company, which tacked on 5.2 per cent to $39.26. The shares are still down 40.7 per cent over the past 12 months.Chevron, one of the US oil makors, rallied 2.3 per cent to $88.51.Investors also pushed up mining stocks as the price of aluminium and copper logged solid gains. Peter Boockvar, chief market analyst at The Lindsey Group, said that industrial metals may be “putting in a bottom” after facing heavy losses over the past year amid concerns about the pace of global economic growth.Freeport-McMoRan, a copper miner, leapt 12.4 per cent to $7.78, cutting its 12-month decline to 62.3 per cent. Alcoa, an aluminium producer, rose 10.9 per cent to $8.73.

Titular: S&P may cut Icahn Enterprises to junk
Texto: Standard & Poor’s warned on Friday that it may cut Icahn Enterprises’ credit rating to junk amid investment declines across the holding company’s portfolio.S&P said it put Icahn Enterprises’s “BBB-” rating on credit-watch negative amid “declining investment values in the firm’s portfolio”.The company, which is the publicly-traded vehicle for billionaire Carl Icahn’s investments, has lost “at least” $1.4bn on its investments compared to their values as of September 30, 2015, S&P said.S&P added that while it only has direct visibility into Icahn’s publicly-traded holdings, it reckons its private investments “may have also lost value in the fourth quarter and so far in 2016 due to declining markets and the significant deterioration in commodity-related investments (including Chesapeake, Cheniere, and Freeport-McMoRan).”The New York-based ratings company also warned that the firm has begun to “maintain less cash at the holding company than it has historically.”S&P said that it sees an at least 50 per cent chance it will lower Icahn’s rating over the next 90 days. Levels below “BBB-” are considered to be speculative-grade, sometimes referred to as junk.

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan sells Arizona mine stake to Sumitomo for $1bn
Subtitular: Deal is latest sign of US copper miner’s need to shore up balance sheet
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan is selling a stake in an Arizona mine for $1bn, in a sign of the indebted US copper miner’s urgent need to shore up its balance sheet to respond to the commodities price rout.Freeport’s sale of a 13 per cent stake in the Morenci mine to Japanese copper producer Sumitomo follows the miner’s pledge to step up the pace of debt reduction through asset sales.Sumitomo already owns 15 per cent of Morenci and the deal will cut Freeport’s stake to 72 per cent. The mine produced around 400,000 tonnes of copper last year for Freeport and was the group’s largest single source of the metal.Freeport is the world’s largest listed producer of copper but its problems from the falling price of the metal have been compounded by controversial transactions four years ago to step up its exposure to oil and gas. The deals massively increased Freeport’s debt, leaving it more exposed as the commodity cycle has turned.The mining industry is being most affected by the economic slowdown in China, which became by far the largest source of commodities demand over the past decade. The slowdown has hit demand for minerals used in construction and industry.In a statement on Monday, Richard Adkerson, Freeport’s chief executive, said the deal with Sumitomo “represents an important initial step toward our objective to accelerate debt reduction and restore our balance sheet, while retaining a portfolio of high-quality assets and resources”.Indebted miners are trying to sell assets but are very reluctant to entertain offers for their best mines unless their financial circumstances become desperate. Larger miners such as Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton are hunting for copper acquisitions, which will boost growth once the cycle recovers, but will only consider those that are large, low-cost and in safe jurisdictions.Sam Walsh, Rio’s chief executive, last week said that assets so far offered for sale by distressed companies were “distressed for a reason”.Shares in Freeport have rebounded from lows a month ago but are still down almost three-quarters over the past 12 months.

Titular: BHP dividend policy puts it at risk of rating cut – S&P
Texto: BHP Billiton could suffer another ratings downgrade if it does not abandon its so-called progressive dividend policy.The warning from Standard & Poor’s will add to speculation that the world’s biggest resources company by market value is preparing to cut its payment to shareholders, which last year cost more $6bn.Lowering its rating on BHP to ‘A’ from ‘A+’ on Monday, S&P said Anglo-Australian mining company could be cut another notch to ‘A-’ if it sticks with a pledge to keep continually raising its dividend, writes commodities editor Neil Hume.S&P said in a statement:If the company remains committed to its progressive dividend policy, while its cash flows are pressured by lower commodity prices, we could lower the ratings by another notch.At this stage, we have no certainty on the company’s response to the challenging market environment.BHP is due to file interim results on 23rd of February and many analysts think the company will cut its dividend and slash spending levels in order to bolster its financial position.BHP’s chairman Jac Nasser told investors at the company’s annual general meeting in November that the strength of the company’s balance sheet must be the main priority. That means keeping a solid A credit rating.A number of the world’s largest miners, including Glencore, Freeport-McMoRan and Anglo American, have already suspended dividend payments as they try to survive the downturn in prices.“BHP Billiton has the strongest credit rating in the sector and remains committed to maintaining its strong balance sheet through the cycle,” the company said in a statement.S&P said it had downgraded BHP and placed it on review for another downgrade because of falling commodities prices and the increasingly uncertain outlook for demand as China’s resource hungry economy slows. BHP is a large producer of iron ore, copper as well as oil and gas.

Titular: Coach sales boost helps lift S&P 500
Subtitular: Accessories retailer raises its outlook for operating income
Texto: Coach shares jumped on Tuesday after the handbags and accessories retailer said its revenue rose for the first time in 10 quarters as the turnround at the company continued.Shares climbed 9.9 per cent to $33.31 after the New York-based company said sales increased 4 per cent to $1.27bn in its fiscal second quarter, in line with analysts’ estimates. Same store sales, a key industry metric, fell 4 per cent in North America but were modestly better than expected.The retailer said revenues were boosted by its acquisition of Stuart Weitzman last year, with boots in particular selling well in the US, and a strong showing in Europe and mainland China.“We view the strength of Stuart Weitzman against a backdrop of unseasonably warm weather as impressive and see this business as adding stability to the model and a lever for growth over the long term,” Randal Konik, an analyst at Jefferies, said.This came alongside a 7 per cent decline in profits to $170.1m or 61 cents a share. Adjusting for one-time items, earnings of 68 cents per share topped forecasts.Coach also said it was raising its outlook for operating income, without specifying the amount, and maintained its revenue forecast for the year.The results “reflect the most significant progress to date on our transformation plan despite the difficult retail environment globally,” Victor Luis, chief executive, said. Mr Luis has tried to revive sales at the retailer, which has seen increased competition from brands like Michael Kors, even as years of heavy discounting hurt the brand’s image. The retailer’s shares fell nearly 13 per cent last year.Sprint shares advanced 18.7 per cent to $2.99 after the US mobile carrier reported a second consecutive quarterly net gain in customers.The Kansas-based company, which has sought to stem customer losses by engaging in a costly price war, reported a net gain of 366,000 of so-called “postpaid” phone users — those who are billed for their service on a recurring monthly basis — during the third quarter. That compares to the year ago quarter when it lost 205,000 of these customers.These efforts however ate into the company’s quarterly results, with Sprint reporting a 10 per cent drop in sales to $8.1bn, missing analysts’ forecasts. Net losses narrowed to $836m or 21 cents a share, from $2.4bn or 60 cents a share in the year ago period. Analysts had forecast a loss of 26 cents a share.Shares in Freeport-McMoRan advanced 6.6 per cent to $4.20 after the copper miner announced additional measures to reduce its debt and said it was in talks with “third parties regarding potential transactions”.Arizona-based Freeport said its loss widened to $4.1bn, or $3.47 a share, and sales fell nearly 28 per cent to $3.8bn as the ongoing slump in commodities took its toll on the company’s results. Adjusting for one-time items however, the company reported a profit of 7 cents a share.Shares in trucking company Swift Transportation jumped 21.1 per cent to $16.56 after it reported better than expected fourth-quarter earnings.Energy stocks led the way on the benchmark S&P 500 as crude prices rallied.By markets close, the S&P 500 gained 1.4 per cent to 1,903.63, the Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 1.8 per cent to 16,167.23 and the Nasdaq Composite rose 1.1 per cent to 4,567.67.mamta.badkar@ft.comTwitter: @mamtabadkar

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan extends list of assets for sale
Subtitular: World’s largest listed copper miner looks to cut debt by $5bn-$10bn amid ‘serious challenges’
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan is extending the list of assets it is willing to sell as the deepening commodities rout makes it more difficult for the US copper and oil producer to deal with its $20bn of debt.The world’s largest listed copper miner admitted that it was facing “serious challenges” and was looking to make between $5bn and $10bn of debt cuts through possible mine sales as well as an evaluation of options for its oil and gas business.“Our clear and immediate objective is to restore [the company’s] balance sheet,” said Richard Adkerson, chief executive. Freeport said it was “actively engaged” in talks over possible deals, which could be sales or joint-venture arrangements.The US group on Tuesday announced a $12.2bn annual loss for 2015, almost all stemming from writedowns to the value of its oil and gas assets.Freeport placed a big bet on oil and gas in 2012 with two controversial energy deals worth $20bn, which pushed up its debt just ahead of the commodities downturn. The group has pledged to return its strategic focus to mining, with a spin-off of oil and gas under consideration.Freeport owns some of the world’s largest copper mines, and sales of its crown jewel assets would be of huge interest to larger miners with stronger balance sheets, including Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton. Both are keen to expand in copper to secure assets ahead of any cyclical recovery.In spite of the downturn, however, few of the mining industry’s most attractive assets — those mines with the largest resources and lowest costs — have been put up for sale.$12.2bnFreeport-McMoRan’s annual loss for 2015A slowdown in the Chinese economy, the world’s largest commodity consumer, and plunging copper and oil prices sent Freeport shares down by more than two-thirds in 2015. Copper is down 30 per cent since the end of 2014 and crude is down 47 per cent.Capital spending cuts, a suspension of its dividend and the exit of chairman James Moffett have followed, while Carl Icahn, an activist investor, has also been pushing Freeport to trim expenses. Freeport also raised $2bn of equity during 2015.“We are facing serious challenges because of what is going on in the marketplace and the situation with our balance sheet,” Mr Adkerson acknowledged. “The situation has developed in a negative way very quickly and aggressively and we are responding to it.”The company’s loss for the quarter widened to $4.1bn, or $3.47 a share, from $2.9bn for the same quarter a year ago. This was Freeport’s fifth consecutive quarterly loss. Revenues sank to $3.8bn from $5.2bn.Freeport’s borrowings are relatively high, with net debt of 4.67 times earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation, compared with a ratio of about 2.75 for the S&P 500 materials sector. Its net debt rose from $18.4bn at the end of 2014 to $20.2bn at the end of last year.

Titular: Freeport eyes more cost cuts as loss deepens
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan, the US copper and oil producer, has become the latest energy company forced into fresh cost-cutting measures as the commodities rout deepens at the start of 2016.The Phoenix, Arizona-based company said on Tuesday that it’s evaluating options for some of its mining assets, while continuing to examine alternatives for its oil and gas assets. The company is also idling three deepwater drill ships.The spectre of a deeper slowdown in the Chinese economy, the world’s largest commodity consumer, sent Freeport shares down by more than two-thirds in 2015. Capex cuts, a suspension of its dividend and the exit of its chairman James Moffett have all followed. Carl Icahn, an activist investor, has also been pushing Freeport to trim expenses.In a statement, Freeport said “in response to further weakening in market conditions in fourth-quarter 2015 and early 2016, Freeport today announced additional initiatives to accelerate its debt reduction plans and is actively engaged in discussions with third parties regarding potential transactions.”Its loss for the quarter widened to $4.1bn, or $3.47 a share, from $2.9bn for the same quarter a year ago. This was Freeport’s fifth consecutive quarterly loss. Meanwhile, revenues sank to $3.8bn from $5.2bn.The miner’s borrowings are relatively high, with net debt of 4.67 times its earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation, compared with a ratio of about 2.75 for the S&P 500 materials sector. The company said in December that it had reached an agreement with lenders that would lift this ratio to 5.9 times in the first half of 2016.For those keeping score: Freeport is the second worst performing stock on the S&P 500 this year, with its shares down 42 per cent in 2016.Its shares bounced 5.8 per cent in pre-market trading.

Titular: Energy stocks follow sliding oil price
Subtitular: Big banks hurt by concerns over Fed’s rate rise timing
Texto: The energy sector fell further on Wednesday as US crude oil prices slid to their lowest level since September 2003.The S&P 500 energy sector dropped 2.9 per cent, far deeper than the 1.2 per cent drop for the broad S&P 500 index. The decline brought the sector’s 2016 loss to more than 14 per cent.Among the biggest decliners in the sector were oil exploration and production companies. Devon Energy tumbled 8.05 per cent to $21.59, while Murphy Oil lost 3.11 per cent to $15.87. Williams Companies, a large energy infrastructure company, dropped 6.4 per cent to $14.77, but eased by the close to finish 1.84 per cent down at $15.49. Chevron, one of the biggest US energy companies, fell 3.10 per cent to $78.98.Materials companies also struggled. Freeport-McMoRan, the copper miner, fell as much as 10.1 per cent to $3.59 a share — the lowest level in more than 15 years — but bounced back to close up 2.78 per cent at $4.07.Many large banks performed poorly on Wednesday amid growing concerns that global financial market turmoil could cause the US Federal Reserve to slow its plans for raising interest rates further this year. Banks favour higher rates since it boosts the return they can generate on loans.JPMorgan Chase, the biggest US bank by assets, fell 2.63 per cent to $55.51, Bank of America lost 3.86 per cent to $13.69 and Citigroup declined 3.46 per cent to $40.49.Twitter, the social media company, was another notable decliner at one stage, but its shares rebounded to close 4.13 per cent up at $17.38.The stock is trading well below its $26 initial public offering price from November 2013, and at a fraction of its lifetime high of $74.73 struck that year.Shares in Square, a mobile-payments company run by Twitter chief executive Jack Dorsey, recovered their losses to close up 0.21 per cent at $9.49.IBM also faced heavy selling after the technology company issued a downbeat profit outlook for 2016. It has struggled to offset declines in its legacy computing units as it shifts into the era of cloud computing. Its shares closed down 4.88 per cent at $121.86.Netflix, one of 2015’s high-fliers, came under pressure after the video streaming site posted disappointing US subscriber growth figures in its quarterly results released after the closing bell on Tuesday.
