Federal Funds futures now imply the US central bank will not lift rates until March 2016.The material sector was the only industry to remain in negative territory after the late-day rally, as investors took fright at turmoil in Chinese equities and gold and copper prices slid.Newmont Mining Corp, the gold producer, was the steepest faller on the S&P 500, sliding 6 per cent to $22.41, while Freeport-McMoRan, the copper and gold producer, dropped 3.3 per cent to $17.25, adding to Monday’s 3 per cent decline.Chipmaker Advanced Micro Devices dropped 15.4 per cent to $2.09 after it warned on sales and cut guidance after the market close yesterday. Computer graphic chipmaker Nvidia shed 1.9 per cent to $19.79.Additional reporting by Pan Yuk.

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan: dealmageddon
Subtitular: A spectacular demonstration of how big acquisitions can destroy value
Texto: We all know that acquisitions often destroy value. How to prove it, though? It is notoriously hard to argue a counterfactual. Any number of things might have happened had the deal not been done. Congratulations to Freeport-McMoRan, then, for demonstrating the point with spectacular certainty.This week, the commodities conglomerate filed an IPO prospectus for its oil and gas subsidiary. The offering will unwind its foray into hydrocarbon exploration. Freeport, then a copper and gold miner, spent $19bn in 2012 buying two oil and gas explorers: its former affiliate McMoRan Exploration, and Plains Exploration and Production. After Freeport made its case for the deal to investors, one of them captured the general mood by remarking: “Congratulations on one of the worst teleconferences I’ve ever heard to justify a deal”.Freeport shares dropped by a fifth that day, and that was before the crash in commodity prices. The group recently slashed its dividend and capital spending to conserve cash. It has net debt of $19bn against a market capitalisation of $21bn.The 2012 deals prompted litigation, too. Freeport’s chief executive and other members of the board were big shareholders in the struggling McMoRan. Plains also happened to be McMoRan’s largest shareholder. Shareholder lawsuits alleged Freeport bought Plains simply to ensure support for a rescue of McMoRan. Freeport and its banker Credit Suisse settled the complaints for over $150m.Freeport management argues that a separate listing will result in a better valuation for the energy unit, allowing it to raise capital more cheaply. If oil is about to enjoy a long rally, a separate listing may be savvy. But the IPO is an admission that it never made sense to conjoin mining and oil and gas production.Freeport management is not chastened. The new company, Freeport-McMoRan Oil & Gas, will have a dual-class share structure. Freeport will retain the super-voting shares, ensuring that it maintains complete control of a company that it never should have owned at all.Email the Lex team at lex@ft.com

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan weighs up selling minority stake in oil unit
Subtitular: World’s largest listed copper producer grapples with large debt load and commodities downturn
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan is eyeing selling a minority stake in its oil and gas subsidiary as the world’s largest listed copper producer grapples with its large debt load and a commodities downturn.A possible initial public offering of stock in the oil and gas business could take place late this year and would highlight the standalone value of the oil and gas business, Freeport said on Thursday.The idea of an IPO follows previous declarations by Freeport that it would look at bringing in partners to part-fund capital spending, but the US-listed miner and petroleum producer said that it intended to retain control of the oil and gas business and would continue to explore alternative options.Freeport joins some of the world’s other large miners in considering radical restructuring in response to the commodities downturn. BHP Billiton is on the verge of spinning off unwanted assets into a new listed company, while Vale of Brazil is also considering an IPO of its base metals business.Freeport on Thursday announced a $2.5bn quarterly loss for the three months to March 31, primarily because of impairment charges on oil and gas assets and deferred tax arrangements.The first-quarter loss, which compares with $510m of net income in the same period a year ago, comes after Freeport slashed its dividend by more than 80 per cent in March. The company also posted a $2.9bn quarterly loss for the last three months of 2014.Freeport spent heavily to bulk up its oil and gas business with two big acquisitions for a combined $20bn in 2012. Freeport had been vowing to cut its debt load last year, and made some divestments, before admitting that its targets were unachievable given the weakness in copper and oil markets.Total net debt stood at almost $20bn at the end of March, Freeport said, slightly higher than at the same time a year earlier.Freeport vies with Chilean state-owned miner Codelco as the world’s largest copper producer, with operations in Africa, the Americas and Indonesia.Revenue for the three months to March 31 came to $4.2bn, down from $5bn in the same period a year earlier, although Freeport’s copper and gold output increased.The average sales price during the quarter for Freeport’s copper was 13 per cent lower than a year earlier. Gold was 9 per cent lower.On the oil and gas side, Freeport’s cash operating margin — its revenues less its cash production costs — more than halved.

Titular: Freeport retreats after dividend cut
Subtitular: Healthcare and utilities led the S&P 500 lower
Texto: US copper producer Freeport-McMoRan slipped after cutting its dividend in a move it described as a “prudent” measure amid an uncertain outlook for commodity prices.The Arizona-based company cut its quarterly dividend to 5 cents a share from 31.25 cents following a 13 per cent drop in copper prices since their July peak.Some market participants, however, had expected that a cut would be less likely, since copper prices have bounced off their five-year lows in January.Mining copper was Freeport’s main business until it spent nearly $10bn on two oil and gas producers in 2013 while crude was trading at loftier levels.“The reduction in the dividend is a prudent measure to strengthen our balance sheet during a period of volatile market conditions,” said James Moffett, chairman of the company.Analysts at Jefferies described the cut as “sensible” as it saves the company $1.1bn of cash on an annualised basis but said the size of the cut was larger than expected.“The company is not entirely out of the woods yet as macro risks clearly remain but this dividend reduction is a step in the right direction and could indicate a bottom in Freeport shares,” said Christopher LaFemina, an analyst at Jefferies.Shares of Freeport-McMoRan, which declined 41 per cent in the past year, fell 1 per cent to $19.15.Shares of Whiting Petroleum fell nearly 20 per cent to $30.90 after it played down the prospect of a “significant” deal involving the company but said it would sell shares to repay debt.Earlier this month, Whiting emerged as a potential candidate for a takeover after it hired bankers to sell itself. In a filing with US regulators, however, Whiting said the company was not “pursuing any significant strategic transaction at this time”.The news came alongside plans to sell 35m new shares and raise $1.75bn in convertible bonds.Chesapeake Energy was given a boost after the company cut its budget further. The Oklahoma City-based company cut its 2015 capital budget by $500m to a range of $3.5bn to $4bn on Monday, amid the drop in crude prices.Chesapeake had already lowered its budget for capital expenditures by more than a fifth from a year earlier, expecting in February to spend between $4bn and $4.5bn this year.In 2014, the company’s capital expenses before acquisitions totalled $5.8bn.The company said it would also lower its rig count 55 per cent from a year earlier to between 25 to 35. Chesapeake shares advanced 1 per cent to $14.26.A higher than expected rise in February new home sales boosted homebuilder shares on Tuesday. PulteGroup climbed nearly 2 per cent to $21.94 and shares of Lennar climbed 2 per cent to $50.44.Overall healthcare and utilities led the S&P 500 lower after a rally in technology stocks gave up its gains.The S&P 500 fell 0.6 per cent to 2,091.50, the Dow Jones Industrial Average decreased 0.6 per cent to 18,011.14 and the Nasdaq Composite slid 0.3 per cent to 4,994.73.mamta.badkar@ft.comTwitter: @mamtabadkar

Titular: Financials and techs fall amid defensive turn
Subtitular: Utilities the sole beneficiary after big US stocks retreat
Texto: US investors piled out of cyclical sectors in a defensive turn that dealt a blow to the consumer discretionary, financial and technology industries and erased the S&P 500’s gains for the year.A sharp rise in the dollar against its largest trading partners, as well as renewed concerns over negotiations between Greece and its creditors, weighed on US stocks.The shift out of cyclical sectors on Tuesday sent more than four in five issues within the S&P 500 lower.Shares of Micron Technology fell more than 3 per cent to $27.61, Genworth Financial slid 4 per cent to $7.15, Freeport-McMoRan slipped 4 per cent to $18.84 and Citigroup fell 3 per cent to $51.23.Interest rate-sensitive utilities proved the sole beneficiary of the day’s rout, rising 0.2 per cent.Water and electricity providers have fallen out of favour since two blockbuster jobs reports increased the possibility that the Federal Reserve could lift rates in the coming months.Entergy rose 1 per cent to $75.48 and Exelon advanced 0.1 per cent to $32.13.New issuance also exacerbated dynamics in the market, strategists said, increasing selling pressures as investors bought into block and follow-on offerings over the past week.“Clearly there is a message being sent about risk assets and that message is probably that we’re going into a period of time where you’ve got some big macro risks,” said Joseph Spinelli, head of single stock trading for the Americas at Deutsche Bank.“The biggest one around the US market probably is what the Fed has to say and whether or not they change their language.”Debate has centred on when the Fed will change the language and eliminate the word “patient’ from its statement — which many economists say could occur on March 18.That could be followed by a rate rise as early as June, some investment banks wager.The divergence between Fed policy and that of the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan has weakened the euro and yen against the US dollar, creating a headache for US multinationals.Companies within the blue-chip S&P 500 index earned about 46 per cent of revenues abroad and a majority have already warned that profits and revenues will be hit by the stronger dollar.Investors have instead turned to European equities, which have far outperformed their US counterparts this year.Mutual funds and ETFs invested in large-cap US stocks have recorded $35bn worth of withdrawals since the year’s start, according to fund tracker EPFR.“The US market is an easy target right now — it’s the worst performing of the major developed markets,” Mr Spinelli added.“With that as the backdrop, you have a situation where a fund flow dynamic exists. As we talk to institutional clients, they’re highly convicted that with quantitative easing, Europe and Japan are a much easier bet than the US is.”The S&P 500 slid 1.7 per cent to 2,044.16 while the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 1.9 per cent to 17,662.94. The technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite fell 1.7 per cent to 4,859.79.eric.platt@ft.comTwitter: @ericgplatt

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan hit by falling copper prices
Subtitular: Company reported Q4 loss of $2.85bn and sales fall of 11%
Texto: A fourth-quarter loss amid sliding copper prices weighed on shares of Freeport-McMoRan, pressuring the broader material sector on Tuesday.The Phoenix, Arizona-based company reported a loss of $2.85bn, or $2.75 a share, in the three months ended December 31. That compared with a profit of $707m or 68 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Sales fell 11 per cent from a year earlier to $5.23bn.Adjusted earnings of 25 cents a share fell short of Wall Street forecasts for 35 cents a share. The company took a $3.1bn charge in the quarter tied to a goodwill impairment of its oil and gas assets.Freeport and other materials and energy companies have fallen as copper hovers near five-year lows and as oil prices have more than halved from a 2014 high.The company said fourth-quarter consolidated copper sales of 972m pounds were lower than the 1.14bn sales it reported in the same period a year ago.“As we enter 2015, we are implementing a series of initiatives to reduce capital and operating costs to maintain financial strength during a period of weaker commodity prices while preserving a strong resource position and a portfolio of assets with attractive long-term growth prospects,” the company said.Freeport now expects its capital expenses to decline to $6bn in 2015, driven by a 34 per cent cut in oil and gas spending. It has also initiated efforts to secure third-party funding for a “significant portion of its oil and gas expenditures”.Shares of Freeport-McMoRan fell 6 per cent to $18.38 and are down 44 per cent in the past year. Rival Southern Copper declined 2 per cent to $26.98 while Alcoa slipped 1 per cent to $15.92.Microsoft shares fell 9 per cent to $42.56 after executives forecast fiscal third-quarter results below Wall Street projections. Analysts with Nomura downgraded its rating on the stock to ‘neutral’ from ‘buy’, expecting a “tougher transition” ahead.Analysts have warned that the tech sector could face a difficult earnings season as the dollar strengthens. The industry earns 57 per cent of sales outside of the US, more than any other sector, data from S&P Dow Jones Indices show.Profits in the three months to the end of December fell 11 per cent to $5.8bn, or 71 cents a share. Revenues advanced 8 per cent to $26.5bn.The quarter’s results included $243m of integration and restructuring expenses, or roughly 2 cents per share, as well as a 4 cent negative impact relating to an IRS audit adjustment. Adjusting for those items, Microsoft earned 77 cents a share, 2 cents ahead of forecasts.“Underlying trends in Windows and Office suggest a more challenging transition ahead, at least through our fiscal 2016 time horizon, likely exacerbated by tougher comparisons for the next two — three quarters that benefited from the PC refresh cycle associated with the end of support for Windows XP,” Rick Sherlund, an analyst with Nomura, said.Investors sold off positions in the tech sector following Microsoft’s results. Shares of Hewlett-Packard fell 4 per cent to $37.36 while Cisco declined 4 per cent to $26.90.The broader market declined on a string of earnings misses, with companies such as Procter & Gamble blaming a stronger dollar for lacklustre results.The S&P 500 declined 1.3 per cent to 2,029.55 while the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.7 per cent to 17,387.21. The Nasdaq Composite slid 1.9 per cent to 4,681.50.

Titular: Materials lead US equities lower
Subtitular: Freeport-McMoRan crushed by copper slide
Texto: Materials dragged the S&P 500 down on Wednesday, falling 1.2 per cent, as copper prices fell to their lowest levels since 2009, prompted by heavy selling in China.In the past 12 months, the materials sector has returned less than 2 per cent and was one of the worst performing sectors on the US benchmark, after energy and telecom services.Copper producer Freeport-McMoRan was the worst performing stock on the US benchmark as prices for the industrial metal fell 2.6 per cent on the London Metal Exchange to $5,860 a tonne.Analysts at TD Securities said falling copper prices could reflect the unwinding of another copper-backed financing trade in China. Shares of Freeport fell nearly 11 per cent to $18.74 and are down 48 per cent so far this year.While Wednesday’s sell-off was tied to the decline in copper prices, Nomura analysts said they were surprised that the company’s stock had been tracking crude prices in the last six months. The company was also “highly levered to oil and gas prices through its producing assets in the Gulf of Mexico and California”, analysts at Nomura said.Alcoa shares fell 5 per cent to $14.95, shares of Nucor Corp fell 3 per cent to $44.41 and shares of Allegheny Technologies fell 5 per cent to $28.52 amid the slump in materials stocks.Speaking at the Automotive News World Congress on Tuesday, Tesla’s chief executive Elon Musk said demand in China was slowing, as sales were affected by concerns about too few chargers, pushing Tesla shares nearly 6 per cent lower to $192.69.“We believe this is a short-term challenge which should be resolved as Tesla builds out its supercharger network (there are currently around 32 supercharger stations in China) and continues to establish brand value in China,” Ben Kallo, an analyst at Baird, said. Mr Musk also said that he expected the company to achieve profitability by 2020.GameStop shares advanced 11 per cent to $36.21, after the video game retailer reported a 5.8 per cent increase in new software sales in the nine-week holiday period ended January 3. The software sales were driven by an over 94 per cent increase in next-generation titles such as Activision’s Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare and Rockstar’s Grand Theft Auto V.Viacom shares fell 6.7 per cent to $67.80, after analysts at Citi downgraded the stock to “sell” from “buy” and lowered their price target to $62 from $88 on concerns that Dish Networks would drop Viacom’s channels.JPMorgan shares fell 3.5 per cent to $56.81 as the US bank reported a decline in fourth-quarter profits.US stocks sold off on Wednesday as retail sales for December fell more than expected and amid concerns about the health of the global economy.The S&P 500 slipped 0.6 per cent to 2,011.27, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.1 per cent to 17,427.09. The Nasdaq Composite eased 0.5 per cent to 4,639.32.mamta.badkar@ft.comTwitter: @mamtabadkar

Titular: Oil slump drives surge in energy bonds
Subtitular: Companies look to refinance existing debt obligations
Texto: A slew of energy companies have come to the US debt capital markets in the past couple of days in spite of a rise in borrowing costs, seeking to refinance or pay off existing debt amid a slump in oil prices.Almost $17bn in energy debt has been sold in the US since the start of the November, according Dealogic. This week alone Chevron offered $4bn in six-tranches on Monday to repay commercial paper, while energy and mining company Freeport-McMoRan sold $3bn in bonds in part to refinance existing debt, according to S&P LCD data.Last week almost $10bn of energy bonds were sold, including a $3bn offer by ConocoPhillips also intended for refinancing purposes.Other energy-related deals in the pipeline for the coming days include offerings by Canada-based Canbriam Energy and a new loan facility for C&J Energy Services, an independent provider of hydraulic fracturing.“In absolute terms, borrowing costs have increased only marginally for most energy companies in spite of the sell-off in energy bonds,” said Adrian Miller, director of fixed income strategy at GMP Securities.“But the use of proceeds is key here. These companies are no longer borrowing to fund expansion. They are borrowing to pay back debt or refinance it. And they are trying to do this as quickly as possible.”Energy bonds have been under pressure in the past couple of weeks amid a slump in oil prices, which have dropped more than 25 per cent since June.The drop in bond prices has been particularly severe for companies with lower credit ratings, which carry a higher probability of default. The sell-off has helped push yields on the bonds to their highest level in more than one year.New extraction techniques and high oil prices boost US oil productionThe shale boom that has created a surge in US oil and gas production has been financed in part through a steep increase in sales of low-rated debt in the past decade. Energy bonds account for almost 16 per cent of the $1.3tn junk bond market, according to Barclays data, having accounted for just 4.3 per cent in 2004.Investors are worried that a further drop in oil prices could put pressure on the highly indebted companies in the sector and potentially trigger a wave of debt restructurings, which has not been seen since the depths of the financial crisis.Junk-rated energy bonds have been the worst-performing group in the high-yield market, with negative returns of 1.3 per cent in the past month, while the broad market gained 1.2 per cent, according to Barclays indices.The drop in bond prices pushed yields on junk-rated energy bonds to 6.9 per cent at the start of the month, the highest level since July 2013, according to Barclays.“For some investors these ‘downdrafts’ bring an opportunity to buy back some of these energy bonds at a discount,” said Mr Miller. “Some of these deals, especially the higher rated ones, may do well.”

Titular: Strike action by miners boosts copper
Subtitular: Planned stoppages at mines in Peru and Indonesia add to supply concerns
Texto: Copper moved higher on Monday as reports of strikes at two big mines added to concerns about tight supplies of the red metal.Copper for delivery in three months on the London Metal Exchange firmed 0.7 per cent to $6,730 a tonne after workers at Peru’s biggest copper mine, Antamina, said they would go on an indefinite strike next month. The mine produces around 30,000 tonnes per month, according to union leaders.Grasberg, a mine owned by Freeport-McMoRan in Indonesia, is also undertaking a month-long strike beginning next week.“These two strikes could “remove” 84,000 [tonnes] of mined copper supply through year-end, assuming zero inventories are processed/shipped and the Antamina strike continues through until the end of the year,” said BMO Capital Markets.Copper has fallen around 9 per cent this year on expectations the market would move into surplus. However, the excess metal has yet to materialise. At the same time, China’s demand has remained strong for power lines and copper used in household goods.For that reason some analysts believe the price could rally in the final months of 2015.Rising commodity prices over the past few years have spurred China to refine more metal at home. China’s refined copper output last month was the highest level since 1990, according to national statistics.Lower prices could entice China’s State Reserve Bureau to make strategic purchases, according to David Wilson, analyst at Citi. Current prices are the lowest in renminbi terms since the financial crisis, he said.“Moreover, the SRB’s budget has been expanded over the past two years, and year-to-date purchases remain far lower than the over 1m tonnes purchased during the financial crisis,” he said in a report.China would be entering a complicated market. Data show up to 79 per cent of copper warrants are being held by one market participant, according to analysts. Much of the copper is held in warehouses in New Orleans, which is owned by a division of Glencore, the commodities group.The impression of a tight market has been exacerbated by the low level of stocks held on LME-controlled warehouses. This has allowed a single buyer to control around half of the copper held in the exchange’s warehouses.Yet calculating true demand is complicated because metal can move out of those warehouses yet still not reach the end user. Instead it is just stored in other warehouses that are not required to report data. That enables the holder to hold on to the metal and sell when prices are higher.

Titular: Congo renews push for Grand Inga dam, an African white elephant
Texto: On a wooden stake planted in Africa’s equatorial forest, a small hand-painted sign reads: “Here will be erected the water intake of the Inga 6 power plant.”The hopeful claim refers to the latest plan to realise one of Africa’s largest – and longest stalled – white elephants: Grand Inga, the world’s biggest hydropower dam, not far from where the Congo river flows into the sea.Located in the far western extreme of the Democratic Republic of Congo, several dams and hydropower plants would deliver 42,000MW – nearly twice the size of the world’s largest power station, the Three Gorges Dam in China. If built, it would double the electricity production capacity of Africa in one stroke and resolve what Jim Yong Kim, president of the World Bank, calls Africa’s “energy apartheid”.Grand Inga has for decades been the stuff of dreams. Now, say its World Bank backers, it is the stuff of cogent plans. One sign of Grand Inga’s growing momentum is that it has prompted an unprecedented offer from China to work alongside the US to finance big infrastructure projects in Africa.“Energy is the development of a country,” says Richard Kapia Boshinga, director of the state power company, Snel, standing on a narrow bridge at the Inga rapids. “It’s got to work.”Still, the project faces obstacles as great as its dimensions. Even if Washington and Beijing opt to collaborate, it remains hostage to shaky financing. It is also beset by opposition from environmental groups, poor management and the uncertainties of working in one of the world’s least developed and most corrupt countries.“We think the whole project will cost more than $50bn, but who will invest money like that in Congo?” says Albert Mbafumoya, senior adviser in the office of the prime minister.Two dams – Inga 1 and Inga 2 – already exist, but are in a sorry state. First conceived by Belgian colonialists and built more than 30 years ago under dictator Mobutu Sese Seko, five of their 14 turbines no longer turn, producing only 1,000MW for a country the size of western Europe.The lack of power is hurting miners in the Katanga region of southern Congo, where some facilities are losing the equivalent of a month of annual production due to blackouts.The many previous efforts to develop the site, where the river’s broad brown waters narrow to little more than 100m after gushing down over 15km of rapids, have all stalled. But Congo has this time adopted a plan that some financiers believe might work: a seven-phase effort to build Grand Inga in increments.The incremental approach might lessen the objections of environmentalists, who have warned that the impacts could range from loss of species and agricultural land to coastal erosion and releases of methane gas.The smaller pieces would also be less daunting to finance, starting with Inga 3, which would cost $12bn and deliver 4,800MW.The government in Kinshasa hopes that the World Bank and the regional African Development Bank among others will commit a quarter of the funds. That still leaves nearly $9bn to come from other sources, including the US, China and the private sector.Jan Walliser, an official at the World Bank, says the third phase of Inga looks feasible. But he cautions: “Private investors will not step in until enough electricity can be sold to creditworthy customers – which is why exports to South Africa and sales to the mining sector have to be looked at to make it a viable investment.”South Africa last year agreed to purchase 2,500MW from Inga 3 as well as a chunk of subsequent stages. Kinshasa also hopes the domestic mining sector will take 1,300MW and the rest of Congo another 1,000MW. But the country has a poor record in paying its electricity bills, making it difficult to raise money for a project that cannot guarantee payback.Private investors will not step in until enough electricity can be sold to creditworthy customers – which is why exports to South Africa and sales to the mining sector have to be looked atMr Mbafumoya, the senior adviser, put it bluntly: “Our population doesn’t pay.”After years of delay, mining companies are applying plasters to the existing infrastructure rather than waiting for Inga 3. Glencore, the miner-cum-trader that has several big projects in Katanga , and its partners are lending $368m out of its own pocket to rehabilitate the turbines of Inga 2 as a way to increase electricity production.Freeport-McMoRan, which has a $3bn copper and cobalt mine in Katanga, is lending Snel $220m to build a smaller local power plant. On a recent visit to the mine, the control room charted four blackouts in a single day.“Future expansion will be dependent on our ability to get incremental power, and reliable power,” says Bill Harris, the mine’s president.Moïse Katumbi, the governor of Katanga, agrees. From his office in Lubumbashi, Katanga’s capital, he estimates miners could be digging 1.5m tonnes a year of copper right now, up from the current 0.99m t/y, were it not for the power shortages.“The problem for Inga,” he says, “is that the project took so long.”

Titular: Lead jumps to highest in eight months
Subtitular: Recent rally in base metals prices shows no sign of ending
Texto: Lead ballooned to an eight-month high on Friday as the recent rally in base metals prices showed no sign of ending.The price of the soft metal, used mainly in the manufacture of automobile and motorcycle batteries, has lagged behind some of its peers recently, and before this week was down for the year. But it broke into positive territory on Thursday, and a further 1.3 per cent gain took the price to $2,266 a tonne, for three-month delivery on the London Metal Exchange.Industrial metals have benefited from improved investor sentiment towards commodities in recent months. The sector received a further boost from data published on Thursday in China that showed factory activity expanding at the fastest rate in 18 months.China consumes more than 40 per cent of the world’s base metals output.Copper had another strong week, rising for the fifth week out of six, to $7,133 a tonne on the LME. The red metal has now gained 11 per cent since mid-March, when concerns about the Chinese economy sent prices tumbling. The price did, however, dip by 0.5 per cent on Friday, on news that Freeport-McMoRan, the top copper producer in Indonesia, had reached an agreement with the government there that should allow the resumption of copper concentrate exports.Nickel, the star performer among metals in 2014, rose 3 per cent this week to $19,180 a tonne. Used to manufacture stainless steel, nickel has soared 38 per cent this year, after ore exports were banned in Indonesia, a major global supplier.Continued concerns about mine supply stocks and falling warehouse inventories saw zinc make further gains last week. The metal, which is used as a protective coating for iron and steel, rose 4 per cent over the week to trade at $2,387 a tonne on Friday. It has risen 16 per cent so far in 2014.Two big Canadian mines closed last year, eliminating a combined 335,000 tonnes of the rust-inhibiting metal from the market, while several ageing mines in Australia and Europe are expected to stop production in 2015, adding to worries about supplies.At the same time, zinc inventories have fallen sharply. LME warehouse stocks have dropped 30 per cent to 653,900 tonnes, the lowest level since December 2010.Elsewhere, aluminium paused for breath, easing 1.26 per cent to $2,000 a tonne. The lightweight metal, used in everything from aeroplane bodies to beverage cans, has rallied 15 per cent since the end of May. Like zinc, it has benefited from falling warehouses stocks but also smelter closures.Norsk Hydro, a major aluminium producer, said this week that low prices had encouraged companies to shut up to 5m tonnes of aluminium capacity over the past few years. According to its chief executive Svein Richard Brandtzaeg, the global aluminium market is in its best shape since the financial crisis.Despite the recent rally, analysts say the outlook for base metals is mixed. In a note this week, Goldman Sachs said that, taking a 12-month view, it was most bullish on nickel, zinc and aluminium. But it was bearish on copper, saying the market was likely to be in surplus this year and also in 2015, when it expected average prices of $6,400 a tonne.

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan close to Indonesian deal
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan is on the verge of signing a deal with Indonesia that will lift curbs on exports from one of the world’s largest copper mines.The copper miner was among foreign companies hit by a ban on exports from Indonesia since the start of this year after the government decided more metal should be processed within the country rather than shipped as concentrate.Freeport said on Wednesday it expected a memorandum of understanding to be signed “imminently” with the government to allow exports to resume in August. Freeport would pay a $115m bond to underpin a commitment to develop a smelter. The company would also agree to higher royalty payments on gold and copper from the Grasberg mine.“We are encouraged by our discussions with the Indonesian government toward reaching a near-term agreement,” the company said.This year the mine has been operating at about half its normal rate, with some of its output being smelted locally.Freeport and Newmont Mining, the US gold miner, were the largest foreign miners hit by the Indonesian export ban, which also significantly tightened the world supply of nickel. Newmont has halted operations and this month filed an arbitration claim against the government to try to overcome the export restrictions.International mining companies hope incoming president Joko Widodo can build better relations but Mr Widodo has said he will stick to the export ban.Freeport said it assumed exports would resume next month but said it would otherwise bring in plans to reduce operating costs, defer capital expenditure and cut its workforce.In its second-quarter earnings Freeport said net income was flat at $482m, or $0.46 per share, compared with the same period in 2013. Revenues rose from $4.3 to $5.5bn.Freeport, one of the few miners that also has extensive oil and gas interests, shuffled part of its portfolio in the quarter, selling holdings in Texas’s Eagle Ford shale to Encana for $3.1bn and putting part of the proceeds into buying deepwater Gulf of Mexico assets.

Titular: Copper on the rebound as sentiment shifts
Texto: Just a few months ago, the best-known base metal was looking like the least loved. Copper, first mined 10,000 years ago and used extensively in construction and electrical applications, tumbled 10 per cent in the first quarter of the year to $6,430 a tonne, and hit its lowest level since 2010.The fall was sparked by events in China, which consumes more than 40 per cent of global copper supply. The country’s first domestic bond default raised fears about the economy, and the possible unwinding of financing deals using copper as collateral. With a surge in mine production anticipated this year, further price falls seemed possible. Thomson Reuters GFMS, a metals research firm, said in its annual industry survey in April that copper could test $6,000 a tonne this year. Goldman Sachs forecast a year-end price of $6,200 a tonne.That now seems a long way away. Despite a blip in June, due to worries about an alleged metals fraud in the Chinese port of Qingdao, copper has rebounded 8 per cent since March. On Wednesday afternoon, at $7,140 a tonne for three month delivery on the London Metal Exchange, the price is down just 3 per cent for the year.Several factors have contributed to the red metal’s rebound. The first is a general shift in investor sentiment towards commodities that has also dragged other metal prices higher, from palladium to nickel and aluminium. Better economic data from China, where factory output is increasing, have also helped.“Around April, a lot of funds were bearish on China,” says Matthew Wonnacott, an analyst at CRU, a commodities consultancy. “Now, the idea that it will have a not-so-bad year has been good for the copper price.”Shifting expectations of supply and demand have worked in copper’s favour too. While Chinese demand in the first quarter was poor, it has since picked up, and year on year growth of about 5.5 per cent appears achievable, according to Vivienne Lloyd, base metals analyst at Macquarie. US and EU consumption has also been healthy.Although mine production is increasing, with two new operations in Chile coming on line in June, supply of refined metal has disappointed.Problems and maintenance shutdowns at smelters in China in the first half of the year have limited refined copper production. In addition, some smelters deliberately pushed through less material while prices were below $7,000 a tonne, according to an analyst at one of the world’s biggest metals traders.“These guys make more money when prices are higher, so they were in no rush to produce,” the trader says. “You can mine as much copper as you like, but you are still dependent on these guys [in China] to turn it into refined product.”As a result, copper analysts are having to change their models. CRU, which had forecast a refined metal surplus of 100,000 tonnes for 2014, now reckons the market will be balanced, and in deficit if China’s State Reserves Bureau “takes a chunk out of the market” for its stockpile, as it does periodically.“The surplus narrative is not as strong as it was at the start of the year,” Mr Wonnacott says.Additional support for the copper price has come from new laws in Indonesia, which are designed to spur local manufacturing. The government’s ban on mineral ore exports in January mainly had an impact on producers of nickel and bauxite. But copper miners have also been affected by higher export taxes. This is important because Indonesia produces a lot of “clean” concentrates that contain few impurities and are in high demand in China. Neither Freeport-McMoRan, which operates the Grasberg mine, one of the world’s biggest, nor Newmont’s, with its Batu Hijau mine, have exported copper concentrate under the new legislation.A compromise on the export taxes is still possible but the presidential election has pushed the issue down the government’s list of priorities. As a result, Newmont has shuttered its mine and taken the Indonesian government to international arbitration.“Indonesia has a lot to do with the [copper] price rising,” says George Cheveley, a fund manager at Investec Asset Management. “There continues to be uncertainty as to when we will see exports. Reports in recent days suggest a settlement may be close but we have heard this before.”It is not all good news for copper bulls. With higher prices, and few scheduled closures, Chinese smelters are expected to increase production later this year. Stephen Briggs, an analyst at BNP Paribas, says a sustained rally above $7,000 a tonne is not justified.Analysts at Macquarie agree, writing in a report that “our outlook for the copper price is for a downturn” in the second half of the year.

Titular: Newmont halts Indonesia mining operations
Texto: US mining group Newmont has halted operations at its Indonesian gold and copper mine and will put 3,200 workers on leave with reduced pay from Friday, after it failed to reach a compromise with the government over export restrictions.Indonesia is a key global supplier of metals and a law implemented in January banning exports of raw minerals unless companies build processing plants has thrown the industry into turmoil.The measure, which is designed to promote industrial development in southeast Asia’s biggest economy, has forced many producers to shut down, sending the global price of nickel soaring and prompting threats of legal action from companies including Newmont.The US miner and its counterpart Freeport-McMoRan, which operates a much larger copper and gold mine in Indonesia, both claim that the export restrictions breach their contracts of work and have been locked in negotiations with mining officials for months to find a workaround.Officials and industry executives have said the government and the companies were close to a deal under which the miners would agree to build a copper smelter and be allowed to resume exports if they pay a small export tax.If there was a complete cessation of exports out of Indonesia, it would make a significant difference to the global marketBut Newmont said on Thursday that with its storage facilities full and talks still inconclusive it was no longer able to continue mining operations.“We have taken numerous steps to help resolve the export issue and support the government’s desire to increase in-country smelting,” said Martiono Hadianto, president director of Newmont Nusa Tenggara, the group’s local subsidiary. “However, despite our best efforts, we have not been able to export copper concentrate since January and we still do not have an export permit.”The discussions have been complicated by Indonesia’s upcoming presidential election on July 9, with incumbent Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono stepping down after reaching the two-term limit. Both presidential candidates, Prabowo Subianto and Joko Widodo, have indicated they will keep the mineral export ban in place.Newmont said on Thursday that it was putting 80 per cent of the 4,000 employees at its Batu Hijau mine, on the island of Sumbawa, on leave with reduced pay, leaving a skeleton staff responsible for “care and maintenance” at the site.Freeport has warned previously that the export ban would force it to cut production by 60 per cent, resulting in 15,000 job losses and costing the government an annual $1.6bn in lost royalties and taxes.But Mr Hadianto said he was hopeful that “continued dialogue with the government will lead to resolution in the near term”.Jim Lennon, a metals consultant for Macquarie, the investment bank, said the Newmont shutdown was unlikely to have an immediate impact on the international copper market given that Indonesia only produces about 1.5 per cent of global supply.By contrast, Indonesia accounts for about a quarter of global nickel and prices of that metal have soared by more than 40 per cent since the export ban came into force.Mr Lennon added that there could be long-term consequences if Newmont and Freeport do not iron out their differences with the Indonesian government soon. “If there was a complete cessation of exports out of Indonesia, it would make a significant difference to the global market,” he said.“But there is a widespread expectation that they will reach a deal on a smelter soon and will resume exports.”

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan to sell Texas shale assets to Encana for $3.1bn
Subtitular: Arizona-based group to use half of proceeds to pay down debt
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan is to sell shale gas assets to Encana in a $3.1bn deal as the resources group pays down debt.Freeport said its sale of more than 45,000 acres in the Eagle Ford shale in Texas would also help it to invest more in extra deepwater assets in the Gulf of Mexico. The assets being sold produced 53,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in the first quarter of this year, Freeport said.Encana, of Canada, said the deal would approximately double its oil production and would help a strategy of diversifying. “We’re replacing natural gas production with high margin oil and liquids production,” said Doug Suttles, Encana’s chief executive.The assets in the deal produced operating cash flow of $327m in the first three months of the year, Encana said.Freeport had said last month that it was looking for faster ways to cut its net debt of more than $19bn and said it was in talks over possible asset sales and joint ventures. It wants to make “significant” debt reductions by the end of 2016.About half of the net $2.5bn of after-tax proceeds from the Eagle Ford sale would be used to repay debt, Freeport said, while the remainder would be used for its deepwater investments.James Flores, chief executive of Freeport’s oil and gas division, said the Gulf was a strategic growth area with “industry leading margins, high impact long-term growth opportunities and superior investment returns”.Tony Robson, analyst at BMO Capital Markets, said: “While the financial markets may like the sale, the high margin oil-rich Eagle Ford was a key part of [Freeport’s] energy production profile. Selling a key asset to allow for debt reductions and help fund capex sends very mixed signals to investors.”The Arizona-based group is best known as the world’s largest private sector copper miner but is one of the few big miners that has diversified into oil and gas. BHP Billiton, the world’s largest miner by market capitalisation, is investing $4bn annually to raise its own US onshore shale production to 200,000 bpd by 2017, much of it from the Eagle Ford shale.In a presentation Encana said the assets it was buying from Freeport were in the Karnes Trough, considered “the core of the core of the Eagle Ford”. Encana said it would ramp up drilling activity this year after the acquisition closes.

Titular: Gold miners suffer as bullion price dips
Texto: Gold miners suffered declines as the price of the precious metal sank below its 200-day moving average and began Tuesday on track for its biggest one-day fall since October.Shares in half a dozen gold producers that trade in New York and Toronto fell in early trade while the S&P/TSX Global Gold Index shed almost 2 per cent on the day to close at 182.86.The decline in gold prices comes as the US economy ratchets higher, commodity strategists at Barclays say.While tension in Ukraine had lifted prices, better than expected inflation and retail sales figures in the US have tempered that momentum.“Gold may have benefited from Ukraine tensions this week as well, but our baseline macro expectations remain the same,” Barclays commodity analyst Christopher Louney said.“In China, physical demand for gold remains lacklustre as the monthly average volumes traded on the Shanghai Gold Exchange continue to grind lower.”Gold futures for physical delivery in June fell as much as 3 per cent to $1,288.44 before paring losses.Shares in Newmont Mining declined 2.34 per cent to $23.84, Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold dipped 0.86 per cent to $33.01 while Barrick Gold fell 1.51 per cent to end the day at $18.55.Technology and biopharmaceutical stocks remained under pressure – inching the Nasdaq Composite closer to correction territory – as investors continue to rotate out of high-growth and riskier equities.Strategists at a handful of investment banks have blamed frothy valuations for the sudden rout, which have sent the Nasdaq Biotech index officially into a bear market.RBC Capital Markets analyst Robert Sluymer said many stocks and indices were trading near key support levels, which could point to a short rebound. Broadly, however, investor shifts seem to point to further weakness, he says.“Although a short-term trading focus generally does not mesh well with most institutional fund managers’s management style, we expect that shorter, more volatile multi-week rotations are likely to persist through the second quarter and into the third,” Mr Sluymer said.Tesla shares declined 2.11 per cent to $193.91, Facebook fell 3 per cent before recovering to close slightly higher at $59.08 and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals slipped by 0.67 per cent to $288.08.Coca-Cola led the benchmark S&P 500 after the company reported adjusted earnings that matched Wall Street expectations.First-quarter profits fell to $1.62bn, or 36 cents a share, from $1.75bn, or 39 cents a share, in the same quarter in 2013.Revenues declined 4 per cent to $10.6bn. When adjusting for certain items, Coca-Cola said it earned 44 cents per share.The Atlanta-based company said volumes of sparkling beverages in the North American market fell 1 per cent during the quarter.On a call with analysts, chairman and chief executive Muhtar Kent said he was determined to “accelerate” sparkling beverage growth by increasing marketing efforts as well as making new investments to support its brands.“These strategies to accelerate sparkling growth are solid and we expect to see improving results throughout the year,” he said.Shares in Coca-Cola rose 3.72 per cent to close at $40.17.Aaron’s, the US retailer that specialises in renting and selling furniture, was under pressure on Tuesday after the company rejected a takeover proposal and announced it had purchased a retail credit financing firm.The company has agreed to pay $700m for Progressive Finance Holdings, a maker of software used by retailers in the controversial so-called “lease to own” part of the retail market.Aaron’s, which has a market value of about $2.1bn, also rebuffed a takeover offer from private equity firm Vintage Capital. Shares in the company declined just over 4 per cent to end at $29.24.Overall, US equity indices shook off early declines to end the day slightly higher. The S&P 500 rose 0.68 per cent to 1,842.98 while the Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 0.55 per cent higher at 16,262.56. The Nasdaq Composite was up 0.29 per cent to close at 4,034.16.

Titular: Copper miners eye increase in output
Subtitular: Prices for the red metal fell to lowest level since 2010 last week
Texto: Copper producers plan to expand mine capacity and output to record levels again this year, underlining potential additional downward pressures on prices, which have fallen steeply recently.Prices for the red metal tumbled last week to the lowest level since 2010, amid signs of sluggish demand and the building up of inventories in China, by far the largest market for copper and most other metals. The copper market is closely watched as a gauge of global economic health.Global copper miners – of which the largest are Codelco of Chile, Freeport-McMoRan, Glencore Xstrata and BHP Billiton – plan expansions of mine capacity that would add between 1.1m tonnes and 1.3m tonnes of copper annually to the market until 2016, according to data provider SNL Financial.Such increases would be roughly equivalent to the annual output of Escondida, the world’s largest mine, which provides about 5 per cent of world supply.“Mined copper supply is starting to expand at a faster pace than demand after a long period of constrained and disrupted output growth,” said Rio Tinto in its annual report published on Friday.The expansion plans highlight how copper is one of global miners’ most favoured metals for investment, given expectations of robust demand over the longer term.However, a number of the expansion plans may have to be delayed or revised if the current weakness in the market persists.The planned capacity expansion would follow an increase of more than 6 per cent last year in worldwide copper output, which was significantly higher than the trend of previous years. Almost all the world’s largest copper miners expanded production.Tim Huff, an analyst at RBC Capital Markets, said: “We think a lot of intended projects are going to come through on time and there will be a surplus of mine output this year and next, although there is always the probability that some will arrive more slowly than intended.“The major companies have the greatest capability to deliver projects. It is the smaller mining companies that are probably most likely to face delays.”The increases expected during 2014 would be led mainly by growth at so-called “greenfield” mines – those built from scratch. Rio is ramping up one of the world’s largest new copper mines, Oyu Tolgoi in Mongolia, which started production last year. Other big mines starting are Peru’s Toromocho, owned by Chinalco, the Chinese group, and Ministro Hales, run by Codelco, the Chilean state miner.Paul Dewison, an analyst at SNL, said not all of the mine capacity expected to be added in the next few years would necessarily lead to higher output. “Especially if current prices are below break-even for the mines concerned, we see much lower mine output growth than the sum of intended projects minus losses from depleting mines,” he said.Ignace Proot, analyst at Bernstein Research in New York, said the marginal cost of copper production should support the current price level for a couple of months.“We should not be too worried about the current low price and I believe that a price support level based on the cost curve will soon exist . . . We will gradually see China’s physical metal demand increasing,” Mr Proot said. “The demand fundamentals for copper remain intact.”

Titular: Indonesia slaps ban on mineral exports
Texto: Indonesia has implemented a hotly contested ban on the export of unprocessed minerals after agreeing last minute carve-outs that are expected to grant a temporary reprieve to the country’s biggest foreign miners, Freeport McMoRan and Newmont.The government claims the requirement to process ore domestically will boost industrial development but mining companies and economists have argued that the move will instead lead to mass lay-offs and shrink export revenues at a time when Indonesia is already suffering from a widening current-account deficit.The ban, which was first written into law in 2009, was scheduled for introduction on Sunday. Eleventh-hour negotiations between mining companies and the government resulted in ministers giving an impromptu press conference just before midnight at the house of President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, outside Jakarta.“Starting from midnight on January 12 2014, the export of raw minerals or ore is banned,” said Jero Wacik, the minister for energy and mineral resources. “The goal is in line with the law, to increase the added value.”But the ministers said that in order to minimise job losses and damage to the local economy in mining areas, there would be temporary exemptions for those companies who plan to build smelters and those who were exporting certain types of already “concentrated” products, such as Freeport and Newmont.However, full details of the last-minute compromise are yet to emerge, underlining the policy confusion that has deterred many companies from investing in Indonesia’s mining sector, despite its great potential.The ban could add to pressure on Indonesia’s fragile financial position, costing it several billions of dollars in export revenue when it is already suffering a large current-account deficit, importing more than it exports. This has weighed on the rupiah, one of the world’s worst-performing currencies last year.Mining executives warned that, especially with parliamentary and presidential elections due in April and July respectively, the mining regulations could well be changed again in the coming months.“We can work with most regulatory regimes around the world but it is the constant change in Indonesia from export restrictions to divestment rules that makes it so tough,” said one senior mining executive in Jakarta. “It is no longer set up for major new mines that take years and require billions of dollars of investment up front like Freeport’s Grasberg and Newmont’s Batu Hijau.”Indonesia is a major player in global metal markets, accounting for around 20 per cent of world nickel supply and 10 per cent of aluminium supply, and the wrangling over the ban has been closely watched by traders around the world as well as by manufacturers in China, who rely on Indonesian nickel ore for stainless steel production and Indonesian bauxite to make aluminium.Nickel prices in London jumped by 3 per cent on Friday in anticipation of the ban, which is expected still to be applied to nickel ore and bauxite, which is mostly by produced by small Indonesian miners unable to bear the cost of building smelters.Poltak Sitanggang, chairman of the Indonesian mineral mining association, a lobby group for small miners, said thousands of workers had already been sent home because companies were struggling to cope with the uncertainty.“Some banks asked miners to repay loans before January 12 and some have already had difficulties with their buyers and suppliers because of this regulation,” he said. “We support the government in wanting to add more value but we don’t support this sudden stop. We also don’t understand why Newmont and Freeport have been given exemptions but not small Indonesian miners.”

Titular: Pricing shift in $2bn-a-year cobalt market sets post-Libor trend
Texto: When politicians fret about price benchmarks, they are unlikely to be thinking about cobalt. But the niche market for the metal, used in batteries and high-performance alloys, may show the way forward for price discovery in a post-Libor world.The $2bn-a-year cobalt market is in the midst of an upheaval. After more than two decades during which the cobalt industry has used the price assessments of journalists at Metal Bulletin as a benchmark for transactions, the market is now shifting to adopt the London Metal Exchange contract.Freeport-McMoRan, one of the world’s largest miners and refiners of cobalt, last month announced that from the beginning of next year it will no longer use Metal Bulletin prices. “We believe there is general acceptance among customers and suppliers to move to LME based pricing for cobalt,” said David Elliott, senior vice- president at Freeport.Others are following more quietly. ENRC, another top-three producer, is also planning to introduce an element of LME pricing into its contracts from next year, traders say, selling its cobalt using a weighted average of the LME and MB prices.“We’re at a tipping point,” says Guy Darby, founder of cobalt trading house Darton Commodities and a former chairman of the Minor Metals Trade Association. Between them, Freeport and ENRC account for more than a quarter of global mine production of cobalt.The cobalt industry’s shift has been years in the making and has a number of drivers. But traders and industry executives say it has been catalysed by regulators’ recent scrutiny of benchmarks and drive for exchange-based pricing.While commodities such as copper, cotton and corn have been traded on exchanges for more than a century, others have been slower to develop.It was not until the 1980s that aluminium producers gave up trying to sell their metal at an announced price and adopted the LME contract, while the price of iron ore – one of the world’s most important raw materials – was set in annual negotiations between three dominant suppliers and their customers until 2010.Cobalt itself was sold at the so-called “African Producer Price” set by Gécamines of Congo and ZCCM of Zambia until the early 1990s, when the MB index was launched.But benchmarks based on producer announcements, negotiations, or gathering of market information by so-called “price reporting agencies” such as MB have come under scrutiny as regulators have investigated one market after another, from Libor, to foreign exchange and oil.“People are definitely moving away from producer pricing and survey pricing to exchange-based pricing,” says Robert Fig, business development executive at the LME. “It’s a culture that’s spanning every commodity at the moment.”The move towards the LME is also the result of several factors specific to the cobalt industry, however.For a start, the move has in part been driven by dissatisfaction among some market participants with the MB index that predates the regulatory furore over benchmarks. Liquidity in the spot European cobalt market has been thin in recent years, traders say, leading some to question the reliability of the MB index.“A $2bn-plus industry needs to get beyond being priced by one journalist sitting in London,” says Mr Darby.Moreover, the LME launched cobalt trading in 2010, giving companies nearly four years to become comfortable with the contract, a situation that could not easily be replicated in other markets.And not everyone is convinced the cobalt industry will switch to LME pricing straight away.While Freeport, ENRC, and Votorantim of Brazil are leading the push towards the LME, other large producers are sticking with MB for now, traders say, arguing that the LME contract is still too illiquid. The largest miner and trader of cobalt is Glencore Xstrata.Raju Daswani, managing director of MB, says he does not believe the shift to LME pricing in cobalt is yet “conclusive”, but adds that MB will respond to the industry’s evolution by publishing cobalt “premiums” – or price differentials based on the LME market. “Our job is to listen and move with the times.”“These things don’t happen overnight,” says an executive at a leading producer, estimating that it could be three to five years before the LME contract is universally adopted. But he adds: “It is inevitable that LME will become the benchmark for the whole industry.”As such, the cobalt market may offer a sign of things to come for other larger markets such as iron ore and coal, says Colin Hamilton, head of commodities research at Macquarie.“It’s a natural development of a lot of these markets,” Mr Hamilton says, pointing out that the iron ore and thermal coal markets are already moving away from journalistic indices towards screen-traded pricing. “The fact that the regulators are taking a point of view on these things will accelerate the process.”

Titular: Supply of copper set to outstrip demand
Texto: Leading copper miners and traders have said they expect supply to outstrip demand next year as a wave of new projects begins production, a development that suggests prices will continue falling for the benchmark industrial metal.The price of copper, used in electrical wiring, has fallen 30 per cent from record highs in 2011 amid slowing Chinese demand and rising supply.The shift into surplus marks a dramatic change from market trends of the past decade when surging Chinese growth combined with chronic mine underperformance to drive copper prices higher. The metal became emblematic of the so-called “commodities supercycle” and triggered windfall profits for miners such as Codelco and Freeport-McMoRan and major exporters such as Chile, Peru and Zambia.But Hernan de Solminihac, Chilean mining minister, predicted that next year “prices will drop a little” because of an increase in supply, with new projects in Chile, Peru, Indonesia and Mongolia all adding to global output. Thomas Keller, chief executive of Codelco, the world’s largest copper miner, said he expected the market to see “a small surplus as a number of new projects come into production”.The implication is likely to be lower copper prices, said Gu Liangmin, head of copper at Minmetals, the Chinese state-owned mining and trading group. He predicted that the metal would trade in a range of $6,500-$7,500 a tonne next year, compared to current prices of $7,100, already down 10 per cent so far this year.The expectation of a shift into surplus in the copper market was echoed by many of the traders, analysts and hedge fund managers assembled in London for LME Week, the largest annual gathering of the metals and mining industry. For the first time since 2008, investors polled by Macquarie did not pick copper as their favourite metal for next year.However, few expect a collapse in prices, as a recovering global economy lifts copper demand. “The surplus we are forecasting is very modest,” Mr Keller of Codelco said, predicting a “really marginal” oversupply of 300,000-400,000 tonnes, compared to annual consumption of more than 20m tonnes.“We should continue to see prices moving around current levels,” he said.Indeed, not everyone believes that the oversupply will be long-lived: the mining industry has a long record of under-delivering on promised production.Mr de Solminihac said the trajectory for copper prices beyond next year would depend on how much of the expected supply really materialises – a significant uncertainty as miners review their spending plans.Diego Hernández, chief executive of London-listed copper miner Antofagasta, predicted that after two years of surplus in 2014 and 2015 the copper market would return to a “tight supply-demand balance”.

Titular: Copper hits three-year low
Texto: Industrial metals tumbled with copper hitting a three-year low as traders feared that China’s liquidity squeeze could dent demand in the world’s top metals consumer.The spike in short-term lending rates in China, together with softer data on the economy, has rattled metals and mining investors.China is the world’s largest consumer of industrial metals, accounting for 40 per cent or more of global demand for each, and the economic slowdown has inspired many funds to bet against the sector.Copper for delivery in three months on the London Metal Exchange tumbled as much as 3.4 per cent to $6,613 a tonne on Monday morning – the lowest since July 2010.The shares of mining companies including Rio Tinto, Vale, Anglo American and Freeport McMoRan each fell by more than 3 per cent.“There are no buyers out there,” said Jake Greenberg, metals and mining specialist at Jefferies. “These are aggressive moves after aggressive moves.”Copper traders had already been nervous about credit availability in China after the government promised in May to crack down on the use of copper as collateral to obtain financing.Goldman Sachs described the unwinding of these financing deals as a “bearish risk” that “complicates our near-term bullish copper view”.In addition, the broader flight from risk following the US Federal Reserve’s suggestion that it would begin to taper its asset purchases has caused the dollar to strengthen – putting pressure on the dollar-denominated prices of commodities.The People’s Bank of China’s comments over the weekend that liquidity was at a “reasonable level” despite a jump in benchmark interbank interest rates was enough to trigger a broad sell-off.Beyond copper, other metals also plunged to fresh multiyear lows.Benchmark LME aluminium prices hit a four-year low of $1,772.25 a tonne while platinum fell 3.9 per cent to a 2½-year low of $1,321.25 a troy ounce and nickel slid towards last week’s four-year low of $13,630 a tonne.The tumble in metals prices is putting pressure on miners and smelters.Aluminium and nickel prices are trading well below the levels at which analysts reckon the highest cost producers are losing money while South African platinum miners are now contending with sharply falling platinum prices as well as the possibility of strikes.
