Titular: Indonesia orders Freeport to shut mine pending cave-in probe
Texto: The Indonesian government has ordered Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold, the US mining group, to halt production at its copper and gold mine in Papua province for three months while it completes an investigation into a fatal cave-in at an underground training centre.Twenty-eight people died in the incident at the Grasberg site on May 14 – one of the worst-ever mining disasters in resource-rich Indonesia. The government announced the shutdown on Monday after another worker died over the weekend in an unrelated accident.Grasberg, one of the world’s biggest copper and gold deposits, has been plagued by problems, including a shutdown caused by a strike in 2011 and a succession of fatal shootings.Dede Suhendra, a senior official at Indonesia’s ministry of energy and mineral resources, said production would be halted for three months while a government team investigates the cause of the May disaster and explored the risks of other such incidents.“There must be a financial impact but the workers’ safety is more important,” he said.Analysts said the company had yet to declare “force majeure”, which implied it was still able to meet its contractual obligations from its stockpile. The shutdown has yet to impact copper prices significantly, with global supplies still thought to be sufficient and most analysts having factored in the potential for such “disruption losses”.Freeport is the biggest single taxpayer in Indonesia, contributing $2.4bn to the state coffers in 2011.The May incident raised concerns among environmentalists and trade unions about the company’s ambitious plans to accelerate underground mining as its exhausts the supplies from the main open pit at Grasberg.Freeport is planning to invest $715m a year to expand its underground mining capacity over the next five years.Virgo Solossa, the head of the company’s Indonesian trade union, which represents 18,000 of the mine’s 24,000 workers, said they supported the government shutdown.A spokesman for Freeport Indonesia, of which Freeport owns 91 per cent and the Indonesian government 9 per cent, said the company was “not producing concentrates at this time” and was “awaiting government approvals to restart operations”.David Wilson, a metals analyst at Citi in London, said prices had yet to react to the shutdown in Indonesia.“Everyone is focusing on the bigger picture at the moment, looking at macro issues rather than fundamentals,” he said.Freeport Indonesia sold 716m pounds of copper and 915,000 ounces of gold in 2012 and was hoping to increase sales substantially this year to 1.1bn pounds of copper and 1.2m ounces of gold.Analysts said the company may struggle to meet these targets because of the shutdown. Freeport declined to comment.Shares of the US miner, which is spending $20bn on acquisitions to deepen its oil and gas exposure, were up $0.14 at $31.19 in pre-market trading in New York, only slightly lower than on May 14, when they closed at $31.57.Additional reporting by Taufan Hidayat in Jakarta

Titular: Copper higher as no end seen to Grasberg closure
Texto: Worries about tighter supplies pushed up copper prices to a six-week high as a production outage at Indonesia’s Grasberg, one world’s largest copper mines, looked set to continue.Operations at Grasberg, the mine owned by Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold in the province of Papua, were suspended last week after a tunnel collapsed in an underground training centre, leading to 28 fatalities. Richard Adkerson, chief executive of the Arizona-based miner, landed in Indonesia this week, with the company announcing that it was too early to say when production would resume.The output stoppage at Grasberg follows a landslide at Kennecott Utah Copper’s Bingham Canyon Mine last month, and the recent shutdown of India’s two top copper smelters.The red metal, which hit an 18-month low last month of $6,762.25 a tonne, has since risen 11 per cent on worries about supply. Copper for three-month delivery on the London Metal Exchange hit $7,533.75 a tonne before paring its gains to $7,450 on Wednesday.Morgan Stanley said the supply surplus worries which had been weighing on copper prices for the first five months of the year were receding. “The bear’s stranglehold on copper is showing signs of easing,” said the bank.The tragic deaths and 10 injuries would further complicate Freeport’s negotiations with the unions, said analysts. Freeport has had difficult labour relations at its Grasberg mine and has struggled with strikes. “In our view, the real issue for this company/operation and the copper market is the effect this accident will have on subsequent labour contract negotiations, particularly in regards to safety issues,” said Morgan Stanley.The last major strike at Freeport occurred during the last round of contract negotiations in 2011 and lasted for three months and resulted in a production loss exceeding 100,000 tonnes.On the demand side, although the latest Chinese trade data pointed to refined copper imports at the lowest levels for two years, analysts said trading indicators suggested that physical markets in China remained tight.Premiums on physical copper remained high, while copper for immediate delivery in Shanghai were higher than futures prices, indicating firm demand. Levels for stocks in warehouses were also falling, said Barclays, adding that “this should lend support to prices in the short term, though Chinese buying could start to run out of steam in July/August”.

Titular: Thunderbird targets women in mining communities
Subtitular: School to deliver management lessons to female entrepreneurs in Latin America
Texto: An online programme that uses interviews, quizzes and television dramas has been created by Thunderbird School of Global Management in the US, to teach business skills to women in Latin America.Thunderbird’s latest programme targets women in mining communities in Chile and Peru who own small or medium-sized businesses and need support to grow and increase their income. It will be run in partnership with Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold. an international mining company and Bluedrop Performance Learning. Thunderbird hopes the programme will reach 3,400 women over a five-year period.The course will build on the success of a programme Thunderbird launched last year which uses telenovelas or television drama as a way of delivering business education to female micro-entrepreneurs in Peru.Core management topics covered in the programme, DreamBuilder: the Women’s Business Creator, include business planning, accounting, financial reporting, branding, pricing, customer service, human resources and goal setting. Participants can complete the 12 classes of the programme at their own pace before creating their own online business plan.The mining communities of Tierra Amarilla, Copiapό, Caldera and Calama in Chile and Arequipa in Peru have high levels of unemployment, poverty and households headed by women. Freeport-McMoRan has invested in computers and internet access in these communities and Thunderbird hopes that the programme will have a positive impact on each community.The programme is part of the school’s Thunderbird for Good initiative which focuses on educating female entrepreneurs in developing countries and has trained more than 75,000 women in 25 countries since it was created in 2005.www.thunderbird.edu

Titular: Indonesian mining policy: backtracking elegantly
Texto:
When is a new policy not a new policy? When it’s introduced by the Indonesian government, which has a tendency to rush out new measures with minimal consultation, sparking protests from those affected and eventually leading officials to backtrack with all the elegance of Michael Jackson doing the moonwalk.The latest example is the government’s ban on the export of raw minerals, which was meant to force mining companies to build costly smelters and processing plants by 2014 as part of a broader goal to produce more “value-added” products in Indonesia.The proposal sent foreign mining executives from the likes of America’s Freeport McMoRan and Newmont, which operate vast gold and copper mines in the country, into paroxysms of panic and rage. They claimed it was unfeasible to build big smelters in Indonesia at such short notice and that the country lacked the power capacity and the demand for such facilities.And now there are signs that officials from Indonesia’s ministry of energy and mineral resources are backtracking.At an Australian mining conference in Jakarta this week, Susilo Siswoutomo, the vice minister, suggested that mining companies need not make large new investments in order to meet the new requirement to process their minerals.“The word ‘process’ does not mean you have to build a smelter. We don’t want people to export our land but sometimes all you need to do is wash [the minerals] or separate the mud.”The tone of his speech, in which he insisted that Indonesia wanted to attract more foreign investors to its under-explored mining sector rather than scaring them away, was somewhat reassuring to mining executives in the room.Like people suffering bereavement, foreign investors facing tough new nationalistic policies in emerging markets tend to go through five stages of grief: denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance.Most foreign miners in Indonesia are still in the bargaining phase and, if the government does water down its requirements for processing, perhaps they can avoid the depression.Jero Wacik, the minister of energy and mineral resources, accepted recently that it would be impossible for many companies to meet the 2014 smelter requirement and promised to help miners find “loopholes” to get around the law.But, while these more supportive noises might be appreciated, Indonesia-based executives at Freeport and Newmont may find it hard to persuade their directors and legal counsel at head office to back multi-billion dollar investments based on such muddy compromises.Related reading:
Indonesia limits foreign ownership of mines, FT
Tax spurs Indonesia mine investors fears, FT
Whiff of incompetence over Indonesia garlic policy, beyondbrics

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan: metal-morphosis
Subtitular: Miner’s bid to diversify into oil and gas is causing drag on share price
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold – rough week to have those metals in your company name. Prices for both have plummeted. Freeport’s shares were down 3 per cent on Monday on reports that China’s economy, and by implication copper demand, was slowing. So Thursday’s earning report was somewhat anticlimactic. Sales, as expected, were down year over year as higher copper sales volume couldn’t compensate falling prices.The real drag on Freeport shares, however, is not metal prices but its $20bn foray into oil and gas. It announced plans to buy Plains Exploration and McMoRan Exploration in December. The stock fell from $38 to $31 then, and has remained around there since.Management believes the company must diversify in the way that BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto already have. Admittedly, buying another miner might not have been wise, with the global economy wobbling and the industry recovering from a decades-long acquisition binge. But oil and gas?The Plains and McMoRan assets are all in the US, a virtue when its foreign mines are in unstable parts of the world. And the cash flow from the new businesses could fund future expansion in copper. It all comes down to whether management can execute, despite increasing Freeport’s net debt from essentially zero to $16bn, not too high compared with $12bn in earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation. But the company projects a combined $7bn of capital expenditures this year alone.Freeport investors who remain unenthusiastic about the venture into energy may have a get-out, courtesy of the targets’ shareholders. Plains investors are clamouring for a higher bid. Half of the price was to be paid in (now much cheaper) Freeport shares, and a newly discovered oilfield has shown promise. McMoRan shareholders are also protesting that its management may not have negotiated top value. Freeport may just be destined to remain a copper company.Email the Lex team in confidence at lex@ft.com

Titular: Copper: supply and demand
Subtitular: As China slows, investors need to target miners at lower end of cost curve
Texto: Copper was supposed to be the metal that could withstand any slowdown in China. Relative geological scarcity, exacerbated by bad weather, earthquakes, permits and declining grades in old mines is a constraint on supply. Reserves in Chile, the world’s biggest producer, are falling by an average 5 per cent a year. Yet the copper price has fallen by 5 per cent since China, the world’s largest importer of the red metal, announced worse than expected growth for the first quarter on Monday.Yet any geological advantage that should support a commodity price is not helped by the wrong mining strategy. The 5 per cent expected growth in copper production this year marks the fastest supply growth in over a decade and still includes supply disruptions such as those at Rio Tinto, according to Wood Mackenzie data. If the slowdown in China continues, this is a problem.Cash costs among the world’s copper miners average around $5,000 a tonne. With prices around $7,100 today, profits are being squeezed – back in 2011 prices were over $10,000. The fall in the price of gold will hurt cash costs further since two-fifths of the world’s copper mines gain some form of byproduct cost credit, says Bernstein. At Antofagasta, for example, credits from by-products such as gold and molybdenum helped to reduce cash costs of mining copper by a quarter last year.In the medium term the slowdown in China is sure to weaken real demand for copper. Especially where the large amounts stored in bonded warehouses compound any excess supply. Unlike steel, copper intensity in China has been constrained by price and as a result remains below that of peak levels in the US, which historically benefited from its own large domestic supplies. Rio Tinto, Freeport-McMoRan and BHP Billiton remain at the lower end of the cost curve. That is where investors should keep their focus.Email the Lex team in confidence at lex@ft.com

Titular: Wall St moves higher ahead of Fed minutes
Texto: JC Penney shares dropped sharply after the struggling department store chain announced that chief executive Ron Johnson will be replaced by his predecessor Mike Ullman. Mr Johnson took over at the company in 2011 and presided over a disastrous fall in sales.Shares initially surged as much as 10 per cent in the after-hours market when news broke out that Mr Johnson had been fired. However, they reversed gains and sold off after the company said Mr Ullman would return as chief executive. The stock fell 12.2 per cent to $13.93 on Tuesday and has lost nearly a third of its market value since the start of the year.Analysts at Morgan Stanley view Mr Johnson’s exit and Mr Ullman’s return as a positive step, but express caution about core challenges.“JC Penney struggles to drive sales with a concentration of private label brands with little to no meaning in today’s market,” the research note said.Rival department stores were down slightly, with Kohl’s down 1.3 per cent to $47.42 and Macy’s was down 0.7 at $43.67.Overall, US equity markets moved higher after initial wobbles, shrugging off concerns over weak quarterly earnings and ahead of the minutes from the Federal Reserve’s policy meeting in March, due on Wednesday.The benchmark S&P 500 index closed 0.4 per cent higher at 1,568.60, after briefly breaking through the previous closing high reached last week. Seven of 10 main sectors finished in positive territory, with materials and financials stocks leading the gains.Robbert van Batenburg, director of market strategy at Newedge, called the recent market rally a “Lance Armstrong rally, powering ahead by artificial stimulants”.“When considering scenarios for a significant pullback in the US stock market, there are two that stand out. The first is that the stock market retraces as it anticipates the end of the current double dose of QE,” he said.“The more concerning scenario is a market correction fuelled by global cross currents, even though the Fed is still in full QE mode. This could create fears that the Fed stimulus is becoming ineffective and could in turn question the sustainability of the economic recovery.”The technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite was 0.5 per cent higher at $3,237.86.As rivalry in the mobile search space heated up, stocks such as Microsoft, Yahoo and Google were in focus. Microsoft rose 3.6 per cent to $29.61 after it teamed up with Nokia and Expedia to file an antitrust complaint against Google.Yahoo shares also rose 1.5 per cent to $23.83. However, Google shrugged off such concerns and closed 0.4 per cent higher at $777.65.The Dow Jones Industrial Average, which tracks 30 blue-chip companies and is a price-weighted index, added 0.4 per cent higher at 14,673.46.Materials stocks were attracting buyers. Mining companies such as Newmont Mining and Freeport-McMoRan were rallying, up 2.6 per cent to $40.03 and 4.1 per cent to $33.76 respectively. Cliffs Natural Resources climbed 8.8 per cent to $20.45.Shares in Alcoa were volatile and was unchanged from the previous closing price of $8.39. Thanks to demand from aerospace and motor manufacturers, the company reported a better than expected 59 per cent rise in first-quarter net income. The aluminium producer’s forecast for just 7 per cent growth in global demand for the metal disappointed, however.First Solar shares soared 45.5 per cent to $39.35 after the world’s largest thin-solar panel maker issued full-year guidance and held a conference call with analysts and investors. The company forecast a long-term profit margin of 20-22 per cent and expected sales of $3.8-$4bn. The dramatic rise in the price was also due to a short squeeze as the nearly 30 per cent of outstanding shares were being shorted up until last week, according to Markit data. The stock has nearly doubled in the past 12 months.St Jude Medical shares fell 1.7 per cent to $41.21 after the stock’s rating was cut to “underperform” by RBC capital.

Titular: Copper price set to fall amid high output
Texto: Copper production is rising at the fastest rate in a decade, prompting investors to bet on a price collapse.The price of copper is key to the profitability of the large mining companies such as BHP Billiton, Anglo American and Freeport McMoran, as well as for the economy of Chile, which derives more than one eighth of its GDP from the metal, and other countries such as Mongolia and Zambia.The inability of the world’s copper miners to boost production in response to soaring Chinese demand has been a key driver of the “super-cycle” of high prices and bumper profits for the mining industry over the past decade.But that trend has recently reversed, as miners’ investments in new supply begin to bear fruit. Copper output in Chile, which accounts for a third of global supply, has been rising strongly in recent months, boosted by the expansion of Escondida, the world’s largest copper mine. Wood Mackenzie, a leading consultancy, expects 2013 to see the biggest percentage increase in global mine production since 2004.Copper prices last week fell to an eight-month low of $7,331 a tonne on the London Metal Exchange. The price of the metal, used in everything from electrical wiring to air-conditioning units, is down 28 per cent from a record high in 2011. Nonetheless, almost all copper mines remain profitable at current prices, leading some to argue that prices could fall further.“A lot of the funds are beginning to see this situation where you’ve got a lot of supply finally coming through and demand is not looking that great,” said Richard Wilson, chairman of metals at Wood Mackenzie.The increase in copper supply will be the focus of Cesco week, the major annual gathering of the copper industry in Chile, which begins on Monday.It has helped to trigger a sharp increase in copper inventory, with stocks of copper at LME warehouses almost tripling since October.That has made many investors bearish: according to data on US contracts from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, investor positioning is the most bearish since 2009.Barclays, traditionally one of the most bullish banks on commodity prices, said that the rise in supply marked the “end of an era for the copper bulls”.Even so, traders believe the market may have become over-pessimistic in the short term as Chinese consumers, who account for 40 per cent of global copper demand, have become more optimistic in recent weeks.Stocks in warehouses around Shanghai – closely-watched by the market as an indicator of China’s need for copper – have fallen by some 50,000-100,000 tonnes in recent weeks, traders say.

Titular: Congo attack hits mineral transport halted after Congo attack
Texto: The largest attack on Congo’s copper mining heartlands in more than a decade has brought provincial movements of minerals to a standstill and forced a night-time curfew in the provincial capital, Lubumbashi.The attack by 300 fighters drawn from a militia seeking independence for Katanga, Congo’s southern mining province, comes as the Kinshasa-based government of President Joseph Kabila is also trying to put down several rebellions in the east, where rebels over-ran the eastern capital, Goma, late last year.Mining companies stopped transporting minerals after the attack, said an expatriate worker based in the province. Glencore and Freeport-McMoRan are among those that have invested billions to develop Katanga’s copper and cobalt deposits.“[We] have to arrest them to see who’s behind them,” Moise Katumbi, governor of Katanga, told the Financial Times on Sunday, adding that the group had surrendered to a local UN peacekeeping force and that the situation was now under control. Residents said a 9pm-5am curfew had been imposed.Witnesses said attackers armed with Kalashnikovs, machetes and bows and arrows entered the town on Saturday, drawing machinegun fire from the army. Photographs seen by the FT showed several dead fighters on the streets of Lubumbashi. According to local estimates at least 35 people were killed in the fighting, said a UN statement.The militia, which the UN named as Mai Mai Kata Katanga (which means “Cut out Katanga” in Swahili) tried to draw on nationalist sentiment and disgruntlement with the Kinshasa-based government.Although the attack on Lubumbashi was ill-planned and underpowered – it included children thought to be under 15 years of age and the fighters had only 30 or so firearms – it was the culmination of three weeks of smaller attacks, say security experts.The UN said similar militias had displaced more than 300,000 people in the province since 2011. They have also been blamed for two armed attacks on the city airport in that period.“This is clearly another major blow for Katanga’s reputation, and Lubumbashi’s, as being safer and calmer than the rest of the country,” said Gregory Mthembu-Salter, a mining consultant who visited the province last month.As it carried out its attack the group carried a red, green and white independence flag recalling a breakaway movement which in 1960, helped by foreign mercenaries and Belgian mining interests, had enabled Katanga to secede from Congo for three years until it was put down by UN forces.“They expected the people to come out and greet them as heroes but no one followed them. If people wanted to support them they would go and loot the shops but nobody went to break anything. They don’t want to destabilise the unity of Congo – they want this province to go forward,” said Gov Katumbi, who played down the strength of the movement.Instead, 245 fighters surrendered to the UN, which has a peacekeeping base in Lubumbashi. The UN said it would hand the rebels over to state authorities, adding that 54 of those who surrendered were injured, 15 of them seriously. It said the city was “calm but tense” after their surrender.Katanga’s wealth is critical to the functioning of Congo, which is one of the world’s least developed countries despite its mineral wealth. Katangans also take leading roles in Congo’s Kinshasa-based government but the province remains under-developed and its people are frustrated that much of its mining wealth is diverted elsewhere.

Titular: Metals old boys’ club loses sole woman
Subtitular: LME highlights dearth of women in mining industry
Texto: The London Metal Exchange is often called an “old boys’ club”.That description just became a little more apt: Bethan Wilde, the only female trader on the LME’s “ring”, is leaving the open outcry trading floor.Ms Wilde’s departure, first reported by Bloomberg, highlights how male-dominated the LME is. While there is one other woman who has been authorised by the LME to trade on the ring – out of about 100 traders in total – Ms Wilde was the only woman who engaged in the exchange’s shouting match on a daily basis.It was ever thus at the LME, which despite modernising rapidly in recent years still has something of the air of an old-fashioned gentlemen’s club. The dress code, although it no longer includes top hats, is strictly enforced. And until its sale to Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing last year, it was one of the last member-owned exchanges in the world.The classic Wolff’s Guide to the LME, first published in 1976, described ring traders as “young professionals – often unkindly referred to as ‘the barrow boys’ – with sharp reflexes [and] leather lungs”.Ms Wilde, 29, told the FT that she had “immensely enjoyed” working on the ring, where she specialised in aluminium trading. “It’s not a position that most women think about taking. It’s the nature of the business: trading on a floor and having to shout at people,” she said.The dearth of women is not limited to the trading floor. The LME’s new “user committee”, selected last month to “represent the interests and views of the exchange’s stakeholders”, is made up of 14 men.Indeed, the lack of women both in the ring and the boardroom reflects the fact that the metals industry in general continues to be almost entirely dominated by men.(On the Nymex floor, according to traders, there are three female traders: one in natural gas, one in platinum and one in oil options.)Although women run the commodities divisions of several of the largest banks in the commodities markets – Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan and Deutsche Bank – none is a metals specialist.And among metals brokers, trading houses, miners and processors, there is only a handful of women at the most senior levels.Cynthia Carroll, the only woman to run a top mining company, is about to step down as chief executive of Anglo American. Elsewhere, Jacynthe Côté runs Rio Tinto’s aluminium business; Kathleen Quirk is chief financial officer of Freeport-McMoRan; and Anita Zeng runs Glencore’s office in China. Among exchanges, CME Group’s head of metals is Harriet Hunnable, while HKEx on Wednesday appointed Liz Milan of the LME to be its head of Asian commodities.“The broader metal market is tilted towards men, and the LME reflects that,” says Chris Evans, head of business development at the LME.The lack of women in the industry is a problem for metals companies seeking women with relevant experience to appoint to their boards. Of the seven companies on the FTSE 100 with all-male boards, five of them (Antofagasta, Glencore, Xstrata, Kazakhmys and Vedanta) are miners.Amanda Van Dyke, chair of Women in Mining, an organisation promoting women in the industry, says that just one in ten miners is a woman, with that figure dropping to one in twenty at the board level. “When you compound finance with metals and mining you get even less women,” she observes.Nonetheless, while the pace of change may to an outsider appear glacial, the industry is slowly becoming more open to women.“Hopefully women will be attracted to get more involved in the metals trade,” Ms Wilde says. “The LME still has got a bit of an old-school mentality but I think it definitely is changing.”“Now there are some women at the junior level,” adds one senior metals industry figure. “Thirty or 40 years ago there were no women at all.”The Commodities Note is a daily online commentary on the industry from the Financial Times

Titular: Freeport boss richer but under attack
Texto: The two corporate incarnations of James “Jim Bob” Moffett, the veteran US oil and mining entrepreneur, have experienced widely varying fortunes this week.As chairman of Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold, the world’s largest listed copper miner, he has had a terrible week. The company’s shares have fallen 19 per cent since Monday, as investors reacted with dismay to its deals to buy McMoRan Exploration and Plains Exploration and Production, two US oil companies, for a total of about $20bn including debt.As McMoRan Exploration’s chief executive, however, Mr Moffett’s week has been much more cheering. Its shares, battered by recent discouraging reports from its flagship Davy Jones well, have risen 96 per cent thanks to the Freeport bid.The good news for Mr Moffett, who owns about 4.97m shares in McMoRan and 3.08m in Freeport, is that he has come out about $15m ahead.That is not a life-changing amount for him; Freeport paid him $33.6m in 2010, cut to $22m last year after the company lost an advisory vote by shareholders on board remuneration.Even so, for Freeport shareholders who have seen almost $7bn wiped off the value of the company, it is a galling twist.Evy Hambro of BlackRock, the fund manager that controls about 11 per cent of Freeport’s equity, said on a call to discuss the deal on Wednesday that the management team had “chosen to break the trust with investors” by diversifying away from copper and gold into oil and gas.Mr Moffett’s response was to point to his record. It was the geological knowledge he had acquired from his background in oil and gas, he said, that had enabled Freeport to find Grasberg, the world’s largest recoverable copper and gold deposit, in 1988.“You guys have made a lot of money off the Grasberg . . . and off of many of the other discoveries,” Mr Moffett said.“So I hope you’re not going to be jumping to conclusions too quick without looking at the history of why we’ve been successful in the past.”Born in 1938 in Louisiana, and educated in Texas, Mr Moffett grew up in the heartland of oil.Raised in Houston by his mother, a single parent, he won a football scholarship to the University of Texas, where he studied geology. He was a first-class scholar as well as an athlete, according to the Horatio Alger Association of Distinguished Americans, which gave him an award for “exceptional humanitarian contributions to society” in 2000.He worked in oil as a roustabout – a manual worker – and then as a geologist before forming McMoRan Oil and Gas in 1969. The 1981 merger with Freeport Minerals, which took him into mining, was followed by a complex series of deals. McMoRan Oil and Gas, the predecessor of McMoRan Exploration, was spun off in 1994, and Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold emerged as the main listed company.The deals to buy Plains and bring McMoRan Exploration back into the fold, his latest examples of corporate reshuffling, may have received a terrible reception. But Mr Moffett is justified in saying that investors who had faith in him at the right time did very well. From a low below $4 in 2000, Freeport’s shares climbed more than tenfold to about $40 at the beginning of December.However, that rise coincided with a long upswing in the price of copper. Oil and gas prices, shaken by the US shale boom, seem unlikely to show a similar performance in the coming decade. Freeport’s shares rebounded a little on Friday, in a sign that the shock may have been wearing off. Still, for Mr Moffett, keeping his shareholders happy in the future looks like being more difficult than he has been used to.

Titular: Letter from Lex – Christmas shopping
Texto: Some companies have started their Christmas shopping early. Baxter spent $4bn buying Swedish dialysis-product maker Gambro, but it was the world’s second biggest copper producer that really splashed the cash. Freeport-McMoRan spent $20bn on two oil exploration & production companies as it diversified into a new industry. That was not the only big oil or mining story. Repsol filed a $10.5bn arbitration request at the World Bank over Argentina’s expropriation of YPF. In mining, Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich took a stake in Norilsk Nickel in an attempt to settle a long-running spat between two other Russian billionaires. In a separate dispute over commodities, Singapore threw its full weight behind trader Olam to fend off shortseller Muddy Waters.Others were also thinking about buying or selling. Cable & Wireless Communications could receive more than $1bn for its telecoms interests in eight islands from Bahrain’s Batelco while Singapore Airlines is looking to sell its 49 per cent stake in Virgin Atlantic. US chipmaker Qualcomm decided to risk $120m by investing in struggling electronics maker Sharp while UK grocer Tesco made a long-overdue decision to withdraw from the US market. In the aerospace & defence sector three European nations raised their stakes in EADS while Rolls-Royce faced the possibility of prosecution over allegations of corruption and bribery in Indonesia and China. Meanwhile the world’s largest company by market capitalisation, Apple, experienced its worst share price decline in four years. Competitor Samsung elevated Jay Lee to vice-chairman in a further step towards one day taking overall control of the company.The banking sector was still preoccupied with fallout from the financial crisis and other scandals. Whistleblowers alleged that Deutsche Bank hid huge losses on derivatives during the height of the crisis to avoid a bailout while UBS was in talks with regulators about penalties for allegedly rigging the Libor benchmark. In the US, Citigroup cut 11,000 jobs while Bank of New York Mellon was drawn further into a dispute over Argentine bondholders. In the UK, banks are still at the mercy of populist politicians, who increased the levy on their balance sheets. At least one bank was looking elsewhere – Barclays agreed a deal to sell its African business to South Africa-based Absa.John Casey, Lex Publisher

Titular: Eighties rerun no party for Freeport investors
Subtitular: Share price has dropped 20% since energy deal was announced
Texto: “The two companies said their combined resources would greatly enhance the strength and growth prospects of both and would enable Freeport-McMoRan to become a substantial independent oil and gas company.”So reported the Financial Times in December 1980, when Freeport Minerals announced its merger with McMoRan Oil and Gas.This week, announcing its re-entry into oil and gas after spinning off its energy unit in 1994, Freeport-McMoRan’s chairman and founder James “Jim Bob” Moffett said the deal would “create a premier minerals and oil and gas business”, enabling the company to build value “through a much larger, well-capitalised platform”.The déjà vu doesn’t stop there. With miners such as BHP Billiton and Vedanta also investing in oil and gas, the mining sector increasingly resembles the oil industry of the 1970s and 1980s.Then, cash-rich oil majors such as Shell, BP and Exxon splashed out on mining assets in an attempt to diversify.But the deals were far from successful. For example, Shell bought Billiton in 1970, only to record a $170m loss when it sold it to Gencor of South Africa two decades later. BP exited the mining business in 1989, selling for $4.3bn a division in which it had invested about $6bn.Is Freeport making a similar strategic error? Its shareholders certainly think so. The share price has plunged almost 20 per cent since the deal was announced, and more than a fifth of the shares have changed hands.The problem is that investors hold Freeport’s shares because they want exposure to the copper market. As Evy Hambro, manager of BlackRock’s mining fund and one of Freeport’s largest investors, said: “Investors obviously have the freedom to diversify their own portfolios by commodity and by geography and don’t need management teams to do it for them.”With its return into oil and gas, Freeport has further narrowed the pool of equities available to investors seeking simple exposure to the mining industry. Indeed, assuming the deals now in the works go ahead, three of the world’s six largest listed mining companies – BHP Billiton, the combined Glencore and Xstrata, and Freeport – will have exposure to and ambitions in energy.Indeed, Mr Moffett and Richard Adkerson, currently chief executive of Freeport, both argued that pure exposure to a single commodity would be a benefit back in 1994, when the company spun off its copper and oil divisions into two separate companies.“You have two pure plays and banks can lend to each company,” Mr Moffett told the Times-Picayune. Mr Adkerson – who in 1994 was finance chief of Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold and chief executive of McMoRan Oil and Gas – said the spin-off had been “driven by a desire to create value for shareholders”.Shareholders have made clear that in reversing the spin-off, Freeport has done the opposite.The Commodities Note is a daily online commentary on the industry from the Financial Times

Titular: Brokers must prepare for unparalleled conditions
Subtitular: Top advisers face grim task of navigating crisis for clients
Texto: The coronavirus pandemic is first and foremost a human tragedy whose scale is yet to be fully comprehended.The resulting economic shock of recent weeks has also created unprecedented disruptions which have left many people confronted with pressing questions about job security, threats to household income, tax liabilities, and the survival of their businesses. Financial advisers now face the task of dealing with many clients who, beyond all this, will probably have suffered sharp falls in the value of their assets.Louise Gunderson, an FT 400 adviser with UBS Financial Services in New York, has vivid memories of the last financial crisis. When the US stock market began dropping in February, the first thing she did was check that her clients had enough cash. “After 2008, I make sure people have at least a year of cash flow available,” Ms Gunderson says.Like many other advisers, Ms Gunderson and her team of seven have spent most of their time in recent weeks reassuring investors about their long-term plans and talking through clients’ personal worries.Against the distressing backdrop of crisis, the eighth annual edition of the Financial Times 400 Top Financial Advisers provides a snapshot of the best professionals at traditional US broker-dealers.The scale of assets under management is important in selecting the FT 400, as is a positive record in growing this figure, which is a measure of client retention and investment performance. But the list also recognises that advisers’ jobs extend to acting as consultants, life coaches and even amateur psychologists.More advisers have advanced industry designations such as those for financial planners, retirement specialists or financial analysts. Some 72 per cent of the FT 400 advisers have at least one such credential, up from 69 per cent last year.Managing client relationships will be more important than ever this year, in the wake of a crisis many commentators say is without modern precedent. Advisers had already been emphasising services besides investing such as longer-term financial planning and tax management.In recent years, a growing number of advisers have also given up assembling their own mix of investments for clients in favour of selecting from an array of model portfolios. These are computer-aided blends of stocks, bonds and funds that are actively managed to the investor’s risk tolerance and financial goals. Some 20 per cent of advisers say they have increased their use of model portfolios over the past year, while only 10 per cent have decreased such use.Managing client relationships will be more important than ever in the wake of this crisisSelecting investments is not financial advisers’ biggest worry, according to our survey conducted in November and December of 2019. Instead, the top challenge cited by 70 per cent of FT 400 advisers is managing their day-to-day operational requirements. That is a change from the prior year when the FT 400 picked meeting client demands as their biggest burden.Operational challenges are only intensifying in response to coronavirus, as nearly all meetings with clients have shifted to phone calls or video-chat services such as Zoom and Skype. Advisers may long for an eventual return to consultations in person, but some say they might continue to use video or screen-sharing technology more often when things return to normal.Any return to normal cannot be predicted. Brokers who offer investment advice are also planning for the new Securities and Exchange Commission “Regulation Best Interest,” that could be the biggest rule change to their business in many years. The new regulation will limit brokers to recommendations that serve their clients’ best interests, and includes new standards for disclosing brokers’ potential conflicts of interest. The rule is scheduled to take effect on June 30. The SEC has indicated it intends to stick to this deadline despite the pandemic and its consequences.As usual, the larger states with higher concentrations of wealth have more FT 400 advisers. New York has the largest number of advisers on the list with 77, followed by California with 67. Florida is in third place with 21, followed by Illinois with 20.Many first-rate advisers missed the list. Competition is tight, so the gap between those who made and missed the cut can be narrow. The advisers in this year’s listing benefited from strong financial markets last year; the average adviser managed $2bn in assets as of June 30, up from the $1.8bn average in the previous year’s list. This year’s markets in June are highly unlikely to provide such a boost.How is coronavirus taking its toll on markets, business, and our everyday lives and workplaces? Stay briefed with our coronavirus newsletter.Sign up hereListed advisers come from 23 broker-dealers, and the best-represented companies are Merrill Lynch (with 18 per cent of advisers) and Morgan Stanley (16 per cent). Wall Street’s dominance is not guaranteed to last for ever, though. Such national brokerages with the broadest array of services, known as the wirehouses, have focused on retaining successful brokers over the recruitment of a high volume of additional advisers.And many successful brokers have been leaving wirehouses to run their own businesses. The four wirehouses, which also include UBS and Wells Fargo, have the smallest concentration of advisers on the list in its eight-year history: 48 per cent of the FT 400, down from 53 per cent the previous year.It is still unclear how the pandemic and its attendant disruptions will affect the long-term changes under way in the financial advice industry. Fortunately for their clients, the top advisers are used to turbulence.

Titular: Apple rises in volatile trading after dip
Texto: Apple, the world’s largest company by market capitalisation, rose in volatile trading after touching its lowest intraday level since March.Shares in the maker of the iPad and iPhone closed 1.4 per cent higher to $546.09 on heavy volume after having dropped to as low as $518.63 in early morning trading.The company’s market cap briefly dipped below $500bn for the first time in months as it initially extended losses a day after its worst single session decline in nearly four years.The company’s shares have fallen 22.2 per cent since reaching their all-time high in September of $702.10.Earlier in the morning, Tim Cook, Apple chief executive, revealed plans for the company to return some of its manufacturing to the US.Mr Cook said Apple would spend $100m next year to shift parts of its Mac computer manufacturing back to the US from China.The rebound in Apple’s fortunes helped to boost information technology stocks on the benchmark S&P 500, which were up 0.8 per cent.The broader US equity market was flat for most of the day before finishing near its highest point for the day. The S&P 500 closed 0.3 per cent higher to 1,413.94.The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite index rose 0.5 per cent to 2,989.27. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.3 per cent to 13,074.04.CME Group, the futures exchange operator, became the latest company to declare a special dividend ahead of potential tax rises next year.Shares in the company rose 1.4 per cent to $55.03 as it declared a payout of $1.30 a share.Richard Repetto, analyst at Sandler O’Neill, said the size of the special dividend was roughly in line with expectations.Deutsche Bank’s US-listed shares fell 1.3 per cent to $45.49 after the Financial Times reported that former employees of the German bank said that it had concealed losses during the financial crisis to avoid a potential government bailout.Shares in Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold continued to come under pressure after it announced plans to re-enter the oil exploration business and take over two companies in deals worth about $20bn.Freeport lost 4.2 per cent to $30.81.Energy sector stocks were 0.3 per cent higher even as benchmark crude prices declined more than 2 per cent on the day.ExxonMobil, the US oil major, reversed early losses to finish 0.3 per cent better to $88.Starbucks, the US coffee retailer, climbed 5.7 per cent to $53.17 a day after the company announced plans to expand its presence in the Americas.The company said on Thursday that it could see greater tax charges in the UK after criticism of its practices earlier in the year.Meanwhile, US wholesale retailer Costco was the biggest loser on the S&P 500. The company, which announced a $7-a-share special dividend last week, was 0.5 per cent lower at $98.47.Shares in Consolidated Edison were 0.1 per cent higher to $56.11 after Michael Bloomberg, mayor of New York City, said the US electricity utility would spend $250m to upgrade its systems.The company was criticised by many residents along the US eastern seaboard after prolonged power outages following superstorm Sandy last month.Akamai Technologies, the IT cloud services company, rose 10 per cent to $39.06 as AT&T, the US telephone group, said it had decided to form a partnership with the company instead of competing with it on content delivery. AT&T shares declined 0.8 per cent to $33.65.Vera Bradley, the US women’s designer company, dropped 11.7 per cent to $23.14 as it lowered its full-year sales outlook.

Titular: Largest Apple share drop in four years
Texto: Wall Street stocks were muted on Wednesday despite the sharpest single day sell-off in Apple, the world’s largest company by market value, in four years.Apple lost 6.4 per cent to $538.81 as the iPhone and iPad maker suffered its steepest decline since December 2008.Analysts attributed this week’s woes for the company’s shares – down almost 8 per cent from Monday – to a number of factors, including diminished expectations that Apple would issue a special dividend before the end of the year.Colin Gillis, tech analyst at BGC Partners, added that fresh data on forecast tablet sales for 2012 released on Wednesday showed that the company was facing stiffer competition from Google.He said: “With an expectation that the current line-up of Apple products will not be refreshed any time soon, investors are concerned about a product vacuum after the holidays. Competition is growing and there is no specific catalyst to provide upside to Apple’s stock at the moment.”The Nasdaq Composite index fell 0.8 per cent to 2,973.70 as the tech-heavy benchmark was dragged down by Apple’s poor performance. Shares in Google were 0.5 per cent lower at $687.82.The S&P 500 was 0.2 per cent higher at 1,409.28. US equities held on to marginal gains as investors set aside worries over a lack of progress in US budget negotiations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6 per cent to 13,034.49.On Wednesday, President Barack Obama met business leaders to discuss his position on the fiscal cliff of spending cuts and tax increases that could hurt the US economy. Earlier this week, Democrats rejected a counter-offer put forward by Republicans.“Despite the ongoing talks, there are still other positives coming out of the economy right now, including strong results from the housing sector,” said JJ Kinahan, chief derivatives strategist at TD Ameritrade.“There seems to be a lot of underlying optimism in the economy and investors are hoping that government doesn’t hurt that by prolonging these discussions.”Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold fell heavily as the US mining group said it would move back into the oil business and acquire two companies for $20bn in a deal first reported in the Financial Times.Shares in Freeport fell 16 per cent to $32.16 as it said the takeovers valued the equity of Plains Exploration and Production at $6.9bn in cash and stock and McMoRan Exploration at about $3.4bn in cash. Plains shares rose 23.4 per cent to $44.50, while McMoRan Exploration shares jumped 87 per cent to $15.82.Facebook shares moved higher as Nasdaq OMX said the social networking site would be added to its Nasdaq 100 index.Shares in the company gained 0.9 per cent to $27.71. The move comes after Infosys, the Indian IT company, said it would shift the listing of its American depositary shares to the New York Stock Exchange last week.Shares in Pandora Media, the internet radio company, fell 17.5 per cent to $7.80 after it said lower advertising would widen its expected full-year losses late on Tuesday.Brian Nowak, analyst at Nomura, cut his price target for the company’s shares by 28.5 per cent to $5. He said: “If the ad environment is weakening, we would expect experimental ad dollars on new media, like Pandora, to be among the first cut.”Financial sector stocks were among the strongest performing industry group on the S&P 500, rising 1.3 per cent.The gains were led by Citigroup, the US bank, which said it would cut 11,000 jobs in an effort to lower costs. Shares in Citi gained 6.3 per cent to $36.46. Bank of America shares were close behind, moving 5.7 per cent higher to $10.46.Shares in Starbucks, the coffee chain retailer, fell 0.7 per cent to $50.79 as it announced plans to expand its presence in the Americas.The company said it is seeking to open 3,000 new stores in the region by 2017, with at least half those stores in the US.

Titular: Freeport returns to oil with $20bn deals
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold has engineered a dramatic re-entry to the oil business with two deals worth a total of about $20bn, buying Plains Exploration and Production and McMoRan Exploration.The deals will see the US mining group pay about $6.9bn in cash and stock for Plains, and about $2.1bn in cash for McMoRan Exploration, net of the 36 per cent of McMoRan Exploration already owned by Freeport and Plains. Freeport will also assume about $11bn in debt.Taken together the moves will create the fifth-largest natural resources company in the US and the fifth-largest mining company in the world, the companies said.Freeport investors punished the company for the deal, sending shares down 14 per cent in early trading. McMoRan Exploration stock was up 86 per cent and Plains shares rose 26 per cent.The move will take Freeport back to its roots as an energy producer and mark a major shift in strategy for the company, creating a natural resources conglomerate with a major foothold in the Gulf of Mexico.James “Jim Bob” Moffett, chairman of Freeport and chief executive of McMoRan Exploration, has long considered reuniting mining and oil and gas operations under one company, following the 1994 split of McMoRan Exploration from Freeport.The tie-up will connect three companies that already know each other well. Mr Moffett for years has both chaired the Freeport board and been chief executive of McMoRan Exploration. Those two companies share an office building in New Orleans. Plains owns more than 30 per cent of McMoRan Exploration, and Plains chief executive James Flores and general counsel John Wombwell sit on the board.The merged company will make about 74 per cent of next year’s earnings before interest, depreciation and tax from mining and the remainder from oil and gas.Plains has oilfields in California and the Eagle Ford shale of Texas, and last month bought a package of fields and platforms in the Gulf of Mexico from BP for $5.5bn. Plains’ acquisition of the BP assets was not the catalyst for the Freeport deal, but made the assets more attractive, according to people familiar with the matter.About 48 per cent of the merged group’s ebitda will come from North America, giving Freeport diversification away from its troubled Indonesian copper mines.McMoRan Exploration, an oil and gas company that was spun out of Freeport in 1994, has been pioneering drilling at extreme depths below sea level in the shallow waters of the gulf. The technique has not yet yielded commercially attractive results but is believed to offer great potential for future production.The terms of the Plains offer are 0.6531 Freeport shares and $25 in cash, worth a total of about $50, for every Plains share, representing a 39 per cent premium to the Plains closing price on Tuesday night.The McMoRan Exploration offer is $14.75 in cash and 1.15 units of a new royalty trust for every McMoRan share. The royalty trust will hold a 5 per cent overriding royalty interest in future production from McMoRan’s ultra-deep oilfields. The cash alone offers a premium of 74 per cent to McMoRan Exploration’s share price on Tuesday night, or 31 per cent to its average over the past month.Credit Suisse advised Freeport’s special committee, while Wachtell Lipton provided legal counsel. Evercore advised the special committee of McMoRan Exploration, while Weil Gotshal provided counsel. Barclays advised Plains, while Latham & Watkins provided counsel. Freeport received $9.5bn in financing from JPMorgan Chase. Cravath advised JPMorgan in arranging the financing.

Titular: Freeport-McMoRan – paying the price
Subtitular: A large part of the appeal is the low US political risk profile
Texto: When you slap two risks together, is the total risk the sum of the two (addition, for those who slept in class) or the product (multiplication)? Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold is about to find out. The miner is pairing the risks of diversifying into a new industry – oil and gas – with those inherent in paying big premiums for acquisitions.The US copper and gold miner said on Wednesday it would spend $20bn on two oil exploration and production companies with operations in the US and the Gulf of Mexico: $16bn in cash, stock and assumed debt for Plains Exploration & Production, and $4bn in cash and stock for McMoRan Exploration (where Freeport chairman James “Jim Bob” Moffett is chief executive). The premiums are 39 per cent and 74 per cent, respectively. No wonder Freeport’s shares crashed 15 per cent.Why would it pay above the odds to diversify away from a business in which it has done well? Freeport’s shares have returned nearly 600 per cent in the decade before the deal was announced. The world’s second biggest copper producer by output may simply be bearish on copper prices, which have risen 380 per cent over that same decade. The supply-demand picture is firm now, with copper inventories hitting lows in the third quarter. But a soft Chinese economy, and miners’ readiness to go ahead with new projects, makes the long-term outlook drearier.The deal’s other appeal is the low political risk profile of US assets, which may let executives and investors sleep soundly at night in ways that Indonesian, African and South American mines do not. But the biggest danger to Freeport’s new venture is American too: the impact of newly accessible US shale oil on global prices. That will depend on how voters and regulators treat hydraulic fracturing, the technology that frees shale oil. Political risk comes in many flavours.Email the Lex team in confidence at lex@ft.com

Titular: Freeport plans return to energy
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold is planning big acquisitions in the oil and gas sector, a multibillion-dollar move that would take the US mining group back to its roots as an energy producer, according to several people familiar with the matter.Freeport is poised to buy a large oil and gas group and McMoRan Exploration, potentially snatching up two publicly traded companies that operate oil rigs in the Gulf of Mexico, these people said.The deals would mark a change in strategy for Freeport, creating a natural resources conglomerate likely to be worth close to $50bn, including debt.The smaller of the two deals is likely to see Freeport acquire McMoRan Exploration, an oil and gas company that was spun out of Freeport in 1994 and has an equity value of $1.4bn.The companies have kept close ties since their split. James “Jim Bob” Moffett is chairman of Freeport, and chairman and chief executive of McMoRan Exploration. Freeport and McMoRan Exploration also share an office building in New Orleans.Freeport is also expected to buy another larger, oil and gas company with assets in the Gulf. One person suggested the larger target had close ties with Freeport executives and could be worth about $10bn, including debt.Freeport has links with Plains Exploration and Production, which recently bought oil and gasfields in the Gulf from BP. Plains also owns a 31.5 per cent stake in McMoRan Exploration while James Flores, chief executive of Plains, sits on the board of McMoRan Exploration.Freeport is the world’s largest publicly traded copper producer but was once a diversified conglomerate with substantial oil and gas operations, before selling those assets to focus on mining. Freeport reported revenues of $4.4bn for the three months to September 30.Freeport’s copper operations generate ample cash, said an industry expert, and the miner has been looking for ways to reinvest profitably. However, expanding the company’s copper operations could increase the group’s exposure at a time when ailing economic growth in China and a series of large new copper projects are dampening the outlook for the price of the metal. The miner’s management has long been interested in oil and gas, another industry source added.However, industry observers said that the deals could surprise some shareholders. The biggest global mining groups have come under pressure to return money to shareholders, rather than invest excess funds in ambitious new projects.Freeport in October reported weaker than expected third-quarter earnings, as the recovery in production and sales at its Grasberg copper and gold mine in Indonesia proceeded slower than expected. The miner was also forced to halt operations at Grasberg last year due to strikes and suffered labour problems at its Cerro Verde mine in Peru.Freeport, Plains and McMoRan Exploration declined to comment.Additional reporting by Ed Crooks

Titular: Copper bears predict impending surplus
Subtitular: The days of the red metal’s scarcity could be nearing an end
Texto: China’s slowing economy could spell the end of copper’s long price rise, combined as it is with rising supply of the metal.Perhaps more than any other commodity, the red metal is emblematic of the decade-long supercycle in commodities prices driven by China’s spectacular growth. Even as other metals have wilted this year, copper prices have stayed high.But a growing number of analysts and traders believe the days of copper’s decade-long scarcity could be coming to an end.“This seems to be something of an inflection point for copper,” says David Lilley, co-founder of Red Kite, a leading metals hedge fund and physical trading house. “The biggest consumer is struggling, and miners are beginning to pick up production.”The International Copper Study Group, an intergovernmental organisation, expects the copper market to be oversupplied by 458,000 tonnes next year – the highest such “surplus” recorded by the ICSG since 2001.Other analysts, traders and mining executives agree that balance of supply and demand is likely to become less strained in the next year or two. Mike Henry, who manages BHP Billiton’s sales of commodities, says the copper market “is likely to be more in balance over the next couple of years than it has been for some time”, although he adds that “the fundamentals of the industry are still strong”.Many came away from the LME week gathering of the metals industry expecting prices to grind lower from current levels just below $8,000 a tonne – although few expect an imminent collapse.If the period of oversupply is sustained, prices could fall lower still, reversing an era of stellar profits for miners such as Freeport-McMoRan and Antofagasta and undermining the economies of large producers such as Chile and Peru.The Chinese slowdown is one important reason for the shift. The country, which accounts for 40 per cent of global copper demand, is moving to a slower, less investment-fuelled phase of growth, making a repeat of the gangbuster years of the early 2000s – when Chinese copper demand grew by as much as 30 per cent in a year – unlikely.Max Layton, metals analyst at Goldman Sachs, says the weakness of the Chinese property industry could lead to a sharp slowdown in building completions late next year, creating “significant downside risk to copper prices in late 2013”.But the most striking shift in the copper market is the rise in mine supply. The apparent inability of the mining industry to raise output has been almost as important as Chinese demand in underpinning high copper prices over the past decade.Now, however, miners are responding. Production from Chile, the world’s top supplier, was up 7.8 per cent year-on-year in the three months to August, according to Cochilco, the state copper commission. The ICSG predicts mined supply of copper will increase by 6.4 per cent next year – the biggest rise since the mid-1990s.“There’s no question that copper supply is on the way up,” says Mark Hansen, global head of metals at Noble Group, the Hong Kong-based trading house. “We could reasonably expect 5 per cent growth next year.”The expectations of more plentiful mine supplies have been reflected in the physical market for copper ore, known as “concentrates”. Smelters are likely to be able to charge higher prices to miners in annual contracts for next year, in an indication of more plentiful supplies, says Peter Willbrandt, chief executive of Aurubis, Europe’s largest copper smelter.“The concentrates market will be more balanced or even in surplus next year,” he says. “We have had tough times in the smelting industry for five years. Now more and more new mines are coming on stream; existing mines are doing well.”Even some of the most traditionally bullish investment banks have toned down their forecasts. Barclays recently said the market could see a “copper-bottomed supply response at last”, concluding that “the tailwind that copper has had for the past six to seven years is starting to abate”. And Goldman is recommending that miners “strongly consider” hedging against a fall in prices.But not everyone believes the copper bull market is over just yet. Crucially, they say, the bears have become over-optimistic about the prospects for mine supply.“How many times have we heard this?” says Jim Lennon of Macquarie. The Australian bank says “pullbacks to supply projects will be the commodity story over the next six months”.Indeed, just this week Freeport-McMoRan pared expectations for its huge Grasberg mine in Indonesia next year.In London last week, Chilean and Peruvian mining executives expressed scepticism about many of the projects slated to start production in the next few years, noting that in some cases there were development problems and in others owners were slowing investment.“If all the projects were coming on stream as announced, we were expecting a surplus from 2014 for five years,” says Diego Hernández, chief executive of Antofagasta, the London-listed Chilean copper miner. Now, though, he expects that after a short period of surplus, the market will return to balance from 2015.“We are still optimistic in the medium and long term because supply and demand will continue to be tight.”

Titular: Copper – keeping up with demand
Subtitular: The dynamics of Chinese demand, monetary easing and supply
Texto: China’s fascination with resource-rich Africa’s treasure knows no bounds. If the metal is red, so much the better: China is the world’s biggest consumer of copper. Last week Discovery Metals, whose main asset is a copper mine in Botswana, brushed off a US$850m offer from private equity group Cathay Fortune. The Australian exploration company wisely left the door open for a higher offer. It must recall the generosity of Minmetals Resources, which paid C$1.3bn in February for Toronto-listed Anvil Mining, a miner in Democratic Republic of Congo.Copper has recovered from its midyear funk to trade around $8,100 a tonne. One reason for this resilience when demand is subdued is that liquid stocks of the metal hit a historic low (put at 2.6 weeks of consumption, by IntierraRMG) in the third quarter. But copper’s price is not just a bet on Chinese demand – or monetary easing programmes.Supply – constrained by weather, earthquakes, permits and declining grades from old mines – also plays a part. The spat between Anglo American and Codelco did not affect supply but labour disruption in Chile did. The world’s top 10 mines produced 600,000t fewer of copper last year than in 2010, Rio Tinto notes. It expects mine closures to cut copper output by 1.8mt in the next five years and declining grades by a further 1.6mt. In other words 3.4mt of new production, equivalent to a fifth of this year’s output, will be required to stand still.Demand in the longer term will be supported by growing electrification in emerging markets in Asia, and motor industry growth in China and India. The outlook emboldened some miners (Anglo, Rio and Xstrata) to go ahead with projects; others (BHP Billiton) slowed them, amid fears of a looming glut. Either way, investors should prefer names with access to high-grade ore and lower cash costs. Wood Mackenzie data put Rio, Freeport-McMoRan and BHP Billiton at the low end of the cost curve. New projects for Xstrata could reshuffle the pack. As ever, the real winners will be those suppliers that best gauge demand.Email the Lex team in confidence at lex@ft.com

Titular: Commodity traders eye distressed assets
Subtitular: The weak market is offering hidden opportunities
Texto: The slump in metals prices could turn out to be a blessing in disguise for some of the world’s largest commodities houses. The trader-cum-producers are vulture buyers that use periods of stress to snap up assets on the cheap.True, low commodities prices will hurt them in the short term. First, their profitability of production assets declines; second, weaker prices reduce the profits of trading. Yet, a weak market does provide a hidden opportunity.Glencore is one of the traders that could profit, and others, including Vitol and Gunvor in energy, are already moving to snap up distressed assets cheaply. Thus, the current slump could help traders expand their fixed asset holdings, helping them move away from their reliance on the middleman business model.Glencore’s experience in the global financial crisis in 2008 is a case in point. Ivan Glasenberg, the 55-year-old South African chief executive, used the sharp drop in copper and other metals prices to purchase stakes in miners running out of cash or struggling to raise finance in the capital market or the banking sector.The trader’s 2008 booty includes some of its most promising assets, such as copper and cobalt mines like Katanga in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Now Glencore is once again circling assets in trouble. For example, the trader is likely to underwrite a rights issue by Australian miner Straits Resources. It is also looking at an aluminium smelter in trouble in Italy owned by Alcoa.If the $70bn merger between Glencore and Xstrata falls through, expect the trader to concentrate in the next few months on acquiring medium and small-sized miners in financial trouble, rather than targeting global miners such as, say, Anglo American and Freeport-McMoRan.Other commodities traders have already captured several prey as the market weakens. Swiss-based Vitol and Gunvor have used the crisis in the oil refining sector earlier this year to buy several large refineries previously owned by Petroplus, the bankrupt Swiss-based refiner, at minimal values.The trend is set to gain pace if commodities prices remain weak because slow economic growth in China and the capital market remains firmly shut. If the financial pain is high enough, some natural resources companies could end up knocking at the door of the commodities trading house for help. If so, the traders could emerge from the current slump with a good collection of assets.The Commodities Note is a daily online commentary on the industry from the Financial Times

Titular: Indonesian mining: Intrepid knocked by new partner intervention
Texto:
Prospecting for gold in emerging markets is never straightforward. But even veterans at Australia’s Intrepid Mines got an unpleasant surprise last Thursday morning when representatives of new investors landed by helicopter at its large mine site in Indonesia, asserted their ownership, and sent all the workers home.“This is one of the world’s best undeveloped copper and gold projects and the biggest exploration project in Indonesia,” Brad Gordon, Intrepid’s chief executive, told beyondbrics. “This was a complete shock to us.”The dispute, which saw the junior miner’s Australia and Canada listed shares tumble by more than 50 per cent on Monday, will add to the growing uncertainty looming over the mining sector in Indonesia, which has been hit by a new wave of resource nationalism and legal uncertainty.Major international mining groups like Freeport McMoRan, which operates one of the world’s largest copper and gold mines in Papua, and Newmont are holding off on multi-billion dollar new investments until they have re-negotiated their terms with the government.Another junior miner, UK-listed Churchill Mining, recently brought an international arbitration claim against the Indonesian government for damages, alleging that it was forced out of a $1.8bn coal project by well-connected local investors.Gordon said that Intrepid’s problems are different as it is in dispute with its Indonesian joint venture partners rather than the government.The mining licences for Intrepid’s Tujuh Bukit project in eastern Java are held by an Indonesian company called Indo Multi Niaga. It has a cooperation agreement with Intrepid that gives it an 80 per cent economic interest in the project.Intrepid recently discovered that new shareholders had taken control of IMN and Gordon says the new investors flew to the mine site on Thursday to send more than 600 workers home.Beyondbrics was unable to reach IMN’s original or new shareholders for comment.With $95m already invested, and the project still at least 30 months from entering production, Intrepid and its investors have much to lose.“In 2010, we were the second-best performer on the Australian Securities Exchange so we’ve gone from market darlings to zero,” said Gordon, with the company’s market capitalisation now equivalent to its cash position, giving no value to its Indonesian project. “The signs aren’t good but we’ll do our best to engage with the new shareholders to come to an amicable solution.”The latest dispute involving a foreign miner in Indonesia will do little to reassure investors.Related reading:
Tax spurs Indonesia mine investor fears, FT
Indonesia limits foreign ownership of mines, FT
Protectionism hits Indonesia’s reputation, FT
Yudhoyono: getting involved in a little Indo-UK mining difficulty, bb

Titular: Freeport cuts outlook as metals prices fall
Subtitular: Large miners face squeeze on margins
Texto: Freeport-McMoRan, the world’s second-largest copper miner, reduced its production outlook for the year as falling metals prices, lower ore grades and higher costs weighed on the group’s second-quarter results.Freeport, which has struggled with strikes at its Grasberg mine in Indonesia, reported net income of $710m for the quarter, down 49 per cent from $1.4bn last year.The group lowered its full-year outlook for production of copper and gold, despite the recovery in production after work stoppages at Grasberg in the first quarter of the year.US-based Freeport now expects to sell 3.6bn pounds of copper and 1.1m ounces of gold this year.The company attributed the reduced numbers to “mine sequencing changes and slower underground ramp-up at PT Freeport Indonesia”.Large mining companies are facing a squeeze on margins, as slowing Chinese growth lowers demand for commodities such as copper, coal and iron ore after years of booming prices, while costs are rising quickly.Freeport achieved provisional pricing for its copper output of $3.53 per pound in the second quarter, down from $4.22 last year.This year’s costs could be higher than expected, at $1.47 per pound of copper, because of a lower offset to costs from sales of gold and molybdenum, used as an alloy because of its heat resistance. In the quarter, cash costs, net of such credits, were $1.49 per pound of copper, up from $0.93 in 2011.The shares rose 5 per cent to $34.68 in mid-afternoon trading, after the numbers came in above Wall Street analysts’ expectations.Like other large miners, such as BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, Freeport is facing calls to justify its plans for capital expenditure. The company expects to spend about $4bn this year, $2.5bn of which is on new projects.On a call with analysts, one shareholder questioned Richard Adkerson, chief executive, about the spending plans, adding that he did not want to “feel subordinate” to capital expenditure.“We will be very disciplined about projects,” said Mr Adkerson. He had previously highlighted the company’s ability to adjust its spending plans if the environment deteriorated.“When I look at our set of assets, we have an ability to [adjust] that is better than many others in the industry,” he said. “We can defer some of these projects if we have to without losing them.”Freeport’s revenues fell 23 per cent to $4.5bn in the second quarter, despite copper sales in the quarter coming in above some expectations at 927m pounds, down from 1bn pounds. Some analysts argue that as the largest copper mines globally, including Grasberg as well as Escondida and Collahuasi in Chile, recover from labour difficulties and weather disruptions experienced last year, the additional supply could weigh on prices for the metal.The company said operations at Grasberg, which ranks among the three largest copper mines in the world, were “approaching normal levels”.

Titular: Resource stocks mirror global economy
Texto: Facebook’s flotation on the US stock market was an entertaining distraction from what has been the worst week for equities this year.As crowds cheered the social media company’s listing on Friday, something more unsettling was happening in an earthier realm. Energy and materials stocks have fallen 9.9 per cent and 10.6 per cent this month, respectively, outpacing the broader S&P 500 index’s decline of 7.4 per cent.The declines of the two industry groups involved in supplying essential raw materials for business show how investors really feel about the direction of the global economy. In short: it looks like slowing down. The share moves also challenge the thesis that a resilient US economy will insulate its stock market from Europe’s unfolding debt crisis.While headquartered and listed in the US, many energy and materials stocks are deeply dependent on economic activity elsewhere and supply commodities largely priced on global markets. ExxonMobil sells two-thirds of its products overseas. So does Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold, the mining titan.So when the rest of the world gets tired – or in the case of Europe, relapses into fever – US investors are not immune from the effects.China last week reported much weaker industrial activity, retail spending and investment in the world’s leading source of incremental raw materials demand. Caterpillar on Thursday unnerved shareholders when it said sales growth of its earthmoving machinery had slowed, especially in the Asia-Pacific region, sending its shares down 4.4 per cent. China consumes 40 per cent of the world’s copper.Then there is Europe. Amid debate over Greece’s future in the eurozone, analysts have been walking through worst-case scenarios. Bank of America Merrill Lynch argues a messy eurozone break-up could wipe another 2m barrels a day from Europe’s weakening oil demand and push Brent down to $60 a barrel. The oil benchmark was trading at $107 on Friday, having lost $20 since March as doubts have grown over global demand.Executives in the world of materials and commodities appear divided about the outlook. Richard Adkerson, chief executive of Freeport-McMoRan, last month told analysts that markets were “very positive” and China’s “fundamental economy appears to be strong”. Freeport’s shares have lost 17 per cent this month.Alberto Weisser, chief executive of New York-listed Bunge, one of the world’s biggest food traders with operations spanning the globe, told a Financial Times panel in New York this week he believed the euro “will stay together. In typical European fashion they will let it go to the cliff, and at the last moment they will do something”.As for China, where Bunge is a leading soyabean importer, Mr Weisser is not worried: “When we talk about 8 per cent growth as a ‘hard landing’, I think that’s a little bit strange.” Bunge’s shares slid with the market in May.Others are pessimistic – even in the US. As Dan DiMicco, chief executive of steelmaker Nucor, told investors last month: “Let’s be completely honest with ourselves. The US economy is not on the path of sustainable and healthy recovery from a Great Recession that began almost four years ago.”The US stock market is still in positive territory for the year, while European indices are in the red. Some strategists are convinced this pullback is more psychology than substance. “It’s somewhat frustrating to me that investors are reading about the doldrums in Europe and knocking US stocks down accordingly,” says Jack Ablin, chief investment officer at Harris Private Bank. He sees the S&P 500 at 1,450 by the year end, up double digits in percentage terms from today.But the performance of materials and energy, two of the S&P’s 10 sectors, shows how any US rebound in 2012 must overcome problems elsewhere.As Wall Street obsesses over Facebook’s listing, millions of users have embraced the company as a social network linking everyone around the world. The companies that supply oil and raw materials to the world face a different set of dynamics. The looming slowdown gives investors every reason to be concerned.

Titular: Tax spurs Indonesia mine investor fears
Texto: Indonesia’s announcement of a new tax on mineral exports helped demonstrate why foreign investors have been wary of investing in the country’s rich mineral resources.The government this month finally laid out the details of a 20 per cent tax on exports of unprocessed metals, including nickel, tin and gold.
