But some analysts focused on the less than stellar performance at Ebay’s core internet auction website business.“We continue to question the sustainability of the recent mid-teens core general merchandise volume growth rates heading to 2012,” said Brian Nowak at Nomura.Car parts manufacturer Johnson Controls slumped 8.4 per cent to $32.60 for the worst performance in the S&P 500 as the company lowered full-year earnings guidance, citing weakness in demand from Europe.But the aircraft part supplier Rockwell Collins climbed 5.5 per cent to $59.96 after the company said it was doubling production of parts for Boeing’s 787 Dreamliner this quarter.First Solar slumped 10 per cent to $38.70, on reports the German government will cut subsidies for solar energy. The solar industry remains heavily dependent on support from eurozone governments for demand.Eastman Kodak, the company that invented the handheld camera, ended a prolonged share price slide by filing for bankruptcy. The shares were last trading at 36 cents.

Titular: Higher copper prices lift Freeport profits
Texto: Freeport McMoRan, the world’s biggest publicly traded copper miner by turnover, raised its profits in 2011 despite a paralysing three-month strike that halted output at its largest mine.US-based Freeport lost production of 235m pounds of copper and 275,000 ounces of gold last year because of a violent strike at Grasberg, a remote Indonesian mine that is crucial to global supply. Attacks on Grasberg’s pipelines and employees exacerbated the effects of the strike, which ended in December when the company agreed to higher pay and more worker benefits.The disruptions drove a decline in annual copper production from 3.9bn pounds in 2010 to 3.7bn pounds last year. The impact on the group total was mitigated by stable or higher production at Freeport’s North and South American mines.Higher average copper prices edged pre-tax profits higher from $8.5bn last year to $8.8bn. Freeport’s profits exceeded the record levels it attained last year, when it declared a special dividend to clear excess cash from its books. Freeport remains in a net cash position.The company’s performance continued to track a copper price that remains buoyant despite a marked softening in the fourth quarter of last year.The company sold copper at an average price of $3.86 per pound compared with $3.59 last year. Production costs rose from 79 cents to $1.01 per pound, as multinational miners such as Freeport struggle to contain rising costs of labour, raw materials, and power.The strike hit Freeport’s gold production, which fell from 1.9m ounces to 1.4m ounces.Richard Adkerson, chief executive of the Phoenix-based miner, said the company was “taking steps to restore full operations” at Grasberg, where a force majeure declaration remains in place.The company guided the market to expect roughly flat copper production this year, with expected sales of 3.8bn pounds, and lower gold production, with expected sales of 1.2m ounces.Tenke Fungurume, Freeport’s mine in the politically unstable Democratic Republic of Congo, continued to expand production last year and remained the largest mine in that country.Revenues were $20.1bn compared to $19bn, while earnings per share rose from $4.57 to $4.78 per share.Freeport shares were flat at $44.50 in afternoon trading in New York.

Titular: Freeport strikes deal over Papua mine pay
Subtitular: Dispute crippled production at miner’s Indonesian operations
Texto: A deal has been reached between thousands of striking workers and managers at Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold, ending a three-month labour dispute that has crippled production at the miner’s Indonesian operations.Losses have run as high as $18m per day for the US company, which operates one of the world’s largest gold and copper mines in the remote eastern highlands of Papua, since roughly 8,000 workers began industrial action on September 15. The shortage of supply has also lifted international copper prices.Production was shut down completely in October due to sabotage of facilities and escalating violence. Police shot and killed two workers during a rowdy protest and unidentified assailants killed three miners on Freeport’s sprawling Grasberg complex.A trade union official said on Wednesday they had agreed to a 37 per cent pay increase over two years, with an initial 24 per cent rise on January 1 with the remainder coming a year later.Freeport said it was “pleased to have reached mutually acceptable terms with its union workers” and that they would start reporting to their positions in the coming days. It is still repairing fuel lines damaged during the strike.“Shipments of concentrate are expected to be limited until full operations are restored, which is expected by early 2012,” it added.The deal ends the lengthiest and possibly the most costly strike in Indonesian history.Freeport’s Indonesian operations are 90.6 per cent owned by US parent company Freeport-McMoRan, based in Arizona, with the remainder in the hands of the Indonesian government. Freeport is also Indonesia’s largest taxpayer, contributing $1.9bn in 2010 and more than $19bn over the past decade.Grasberg produced 625,000 tones of copper last year, or about 3 per cent of global supplies. It is also one of the world’s top gold mines.The strike has reduced production to just five per cent of normal capacity, leading to a fall in group profit and higher copper prices on international markets.Papua is Indonesia’s easternmost and least developed province. Despite vast natural resources, its people remain poor and they suffer systematic abuses at the hands of Indonesian security forces, rights groups say.Freeport has long been the source of conflict. The situation is further complicated by Indonesia’s only remaining separatist movement. Low-level fighting between poorly armed rebels and government forces claims a few lives each year. A majority of Papuans, who have different ethnic and religious roots to their political leaders in Jakarta, want independence.

Titular: Copper projects at risk as Peru leaders get tough
Subtitular: Community unrest is becoming the biggest threat to mining ventures
Texto: When Ollanta Humala won Peru’s presidential elections in June, the mining industry took fright.Six months later, the leftwing president, who rode to power on a promise of a windfall tax on the sector, has surprised even the most optimistic industry observers.Confronted with growing unrest over Minas Conga, a $4.8bn project that would be the country’s largest ever single investment, Mr Humala might have been expected to take the side of the protesters, his natural supporter base.Instead he has come down on the side of Newmont and Buenaventura, the miners, and is taking no prisoners. Ten days ago he declared a state of emergency, and over the weekend he replaced half of his cabinet, including the prime minister, apparently because of the failure of the negotiating process.Despite the remarkably business-friendly attitude demonstrated by this response, the escalation of the dispute over Conga should worry investors in Peru’s mining sector.The ramifications are potentially huge: Peru is the target of large investments by many big international miners, including Xstrata, BHP Billiton and Anglo American, and is set to be the source of a large part of the supply growth for key commodities in the next five years – most strikingly copper, for which it could contribute a third of new supply.Mr Humala’s actions over the past fortnight demonstrate that he is becoming more confrontational.As well as imposing a state of emergency, he has appointed Oscar Valdes, a retired army lieutenant-colonel, as his new prime minister, suggesting a hardline approach to the protesters.If the new approach aggravates rather than resolves social unrest, those mining projects that are delicately poised on the cusp of development could suffer.Indeed, there is overwhelming consensus among mining executives in Peru that community unrest is the most severe threat to mining investment in the country. Unlike neighbouring Chile, where many mines are in the desert, Peru’s mineral-rich mountains are also home to countless farming communities, which compete with the mining industry for resources – primarily water.Should the unrest at Conga spread to the rest of the state of Cajamarca, as much as $9.6bn of mining investment will be under threat, according to César Pérez-Novoa of Celfin Capital, including Rio Tinto’s La Granja project and Anglo’s Michiquillay deposit.Already this year, Southern Copper’s Tia Maria project and Bear Creek’s Santa Ana project have been scuttled by protests while Anglo American said recently in September that it would “pause” development at Quellaveco, one of its main copper projects, due to a dispute with the local communities.While higher taxes can be anticipated and budgeted for, local protests cannot. The greater the level of confrontation between government, miners and local communities, the harder it is for the industry to plan for future investments in the country.Indeed, Pedro Fuenzalida of LarrainVial, a leading South American brokerage, has pushed back his expectations for all Peruvian mining projects that are not yet under construction.In a worst-case scenario, that could affect such mega-projects as Xstrata’s flagship Las Bambas mine, Chinalco’s Toromocho, and the expansions of Cerro Verde and Antamina, two large copper mines owned by consortiums of miners including BHP Billiton, Xstrata and Freeport-McMoRan.Between them, the projects mentioned above are slated to bring about 1.5m tonnes of annual copper production on to the market in the next five years – more than the total current output of Peru, the second-largest copper producer in the world.The risks of Mr Humala’s hardball approach are clear.

Titular: Freeport Indonesia ends labour dispute
Texto:
A labour dispute in Indonesia that has brought production at one of the world’s largest copper and gold mines to a standstill and cost the company hundreds of millions in losses may well be over.US mining giant Freeport McMoRan Copper & Gold has reached a deal with trade unions to return 8,000 striking workers to work after a three-month stoppage, Reuters reported on Tuesday.A deal would be a huge relief to Freeport, which has been losing about $18m a day in missed income since it shut down operations in October after several miners were shot dead by unidentified assailants. The strike, fuelled by discontent over working conditions and lower pay than miners at other Freeport sites, has been marred by violence, with police opening fire at a rowdy workers’ protest, killing two.Reuters cited sources who said that the union accepted an offer of a 40 per cent pay rise over two years to bring to a close the longest industrial action in Indonesia’s history. Freeport declined to comment.Workers went on strike on September 15, demanding a massive pay increase of around 400 per cent, which Freeport dismissed as excessive. During weeks of tense negotiations, the demand came down from an initial $200 per hour to around $7.50. The current minimum wage is $1.50.A resolution could also impact international copper prices, which have been supported during recent global market turmoil by supply constraints at Freeport.Freeport’s Grasberg mine in the restive Papuan highlands, is the single largest source of tax income for the Indonesian government, paying more than $2bn last year. The site, located in one of the most impoverished and underdeveloped regions of Indonesia, is 90 per cent-owned by Freeport, with the state holding the remaining share.A resolution of the labour dispute would enable Freeport to resume production, but its troubles in Indonesia are far from over. It will now have to enter negotiations with the government, which is seeking a higher share of profits from 51 major oil, gas and mining companies.Related reading:
Indonesia: strike cripples Freeport’s largest copper and gold mine, beyondbrics
Striking Freeport workers reject 35% pay rise, FT
Copper strengthens on supply concerns, FT

Titular: Gold drops amid rise in risk aversion
Texto: Continuing Eurozone worries and US budget talks weighed on commodity prices with gold falling below the $1,700 level for the first time since the start of November.The rise in risk aversion spread to the yellow metal, which had been fluctuating in a band of $1,700 and $1,800 band for most of the month, having lost some its haven appeal of late.Bullion retreated along with other commodities to $1,682.80 a troy ounce in midday trading in New York, down 2.5 per cent from its last price on Friday.“The market is very volatile at the moment,” said Anne-Laure Tremblay, analyst at BNP Paribas.She noted that the Vix index – which measures volatility in US equities and is often dubbed Wall Street’s “fear gauge” – was up 8.8 per cent on Monday.Rising volatility in stock markets was crossing over to commodities, affecting sentiment among gold investors. Other commodities shrugged off tight demand and supply fundamentals, losing ground on macroeconomic worries.In the crude oil markets, ICE January Brent fell $1.14 a barrel to $106.40 and Nymex January West Texas Intermediary declined $1.90 a barrel to $96.77.Copper for three-month delivery on the London Metal Exchange lost 3.4 per cent to $7,296.25 a tonne, in spite of news of a strong outlook for Chinese demand.Morgan Stanley said Chile’s Codelco was looking to settle 2012 copper premiums – the price paid over the LME price – with Chinese consumers at $110 a tonne.The level is a 4 per cent fall from 2011 but higher than the $90 a tonne premium settled in October with European buyers.As the world’s largest copper producer, Codelco’s price agreements are regarded in the industry as a benchmark.Analysts at Morgan Stanley said the outcome demonstrated tight market conditions and lack of supply growth in 2012 as well as suggesting that the producers and consumers of the metal had a more positive view on fundamentals than the market prices implied.Also on the supply side, the strike at Freeport McMoran’s Grasberg mine in Indonesia, now in its third month, is expected to last until mid-December.Aluminium fell 2.7 per cent to $2,072.50 a tonne and nickel declined 0.4 per cent to $17,675 a tonne. Tin for three-month delivery on the LME declined 3.7 per cent to $20,700 a tonne.

Titular: Striking Freeport workers reject 35% pay rise
Texto: Workers at Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold Inc’s Grasberg mine in Indonesia will extend industrial action for a third month after rejecting a 35 per cent pay rise – prolonging one of the most serious labour disputes in the emerging democracy’s recent history.About 8,000 workers at Grasberg, which holds the world’s largest recoverable reserves of copper, have been on strike since September 15, demanding higher wages and better working conditions. Freeport is also dealing with continued wage problems at its Cerro Verde mine in Peru.The decision to prolong the Indonesian strike, announced by union leaders on Wednesday, adds pressure on Freeport as it is also being pushed by Indonesian authorities to renegotiate its contract and pay the government more revenue.Freeport is in the deepest crisis since it began operating in the remote Papuan highlands of eastern Indonesia in 1991. The strike has been accompanied by sabotage of its production facilities, a blockade of supply routes and the fatal shooting in October of three miners by unidentified assailants.Last month, following the shootings, Freeport shut down production of gold, copper and silver, prompting it to declare force majeure on millions of dollars worth of ore shipments, costing Freeport an estimated $18m per day.Juli Parorrongan, union spokesman, said on Wednesday the latest round of discussions broke down over a demand by workers for the minimum wage to be increased from $1 per to $4 per hour. They had initially sought $7.50. Freeport has offered up to $1.35 per hour and says its offer is more than fair by Indonesian standards.“This is our final number. It won’t be lowered. If the company agrees to pay, then we will stop our strike today,” Mr Parorrongan said.Freeport’s Indonesian operations are 90.6 per cent owned by US parent company Freeport-McMoRan, based in Arizona, with the remainder in the hands of the Indonesian government. Freeport is also Indonesia’s largest taxpayer, contributing $1,9bn in 2010 and more than $19bn over the past decade.Grasberg produced 625,000 tones of copper last year, or about 3 per cent of global supplies. It is also one of the world’s top gold mines. The strike has reduced production to just five per cent of normal capacity, leading to a fall in group profit and higher copper prices on international markets.Additional reporting by Taufan Hidayat.

Titular: Copper climbs back above $8,000 mark
Subtitular: Miners and industrial metals boosted by return of risk appetite
Texto: Industrial metals and mining stocks were boosted by the return of risk appetite following the eurozone agreement, and copper rose above the $8,000 level for the first time in five weeks.The first steps by European leaders to try and resolve the sovereign debt crisis cleared some of the macro economic worries which had been keeping investors away from commodities markets. Copper for three month delivery was up 5.3 per cent in midday trading in New York, at $8,150.25 a tonne, while zinc rallied 4 per cent to $1,943 a tonne and aluminium 1.8 per cent to $2,258 a tonne.“On the one hand it appears the macro backdrop is likely to become less hostile for commodities, and on the other, for copper, you’ve got some very tight underlying fundamentals,” said Nicholas Snowdon, base metals analyst at Barclays Capital in New York.The copper price, which has risen 14 per cent from the start of the week, has been supported by news flow pointing to returning demand from the Chinese, the largest consumers of the red metal, and falling supplies.Investors were cheered by Chinese import data of refined copper in September which rose to a 16 month high, while copper prices were supported by Freeport McMoran announcing force majeure for Indonesia’s Grasberg mine as well as continued labour problems at the US copper miner’s Cerro Verde mine in Peru. Together both mines account for about 5 per cent of global output and prospects of falling production pushed the price of copper higher.Mining shares jumped, with BHP Billiton up 7.1 per cent to £20.82, Xstrata up 10.8 per cent at £10.59, while Glencore, the trading house, rallied 10 per cent to 427.72p.However, iron ore prices continued their recent collapse, dropping a further 6 per cent on Thursday to $120 a tonne for benchmark 62 per cent iron content material, taking the fall since the start of the month to 30 per cent.Teck, the Canadian miner that is the world’s second-largest producer of coking coal, a key steelmaking ingredient, revised down its expected coal sales for the year on the back of weakness in global steel markets. “Concerns about a global economic downturn could further lower demand for imported steelmaking coal and reduce our fourth quarter sales volume,” the miner warned.Nonetheless, some analysts argue that prices have fallen beyond the level justified by fundamentals. Ric Deverell, head of commodities research at Credit Suisse, said: “If macro sentiment can be stabilised, the fall in the iron ore price will prove to have been overdone, with a significant rebound likely over coming months.”

Titular: Grasberg force majeure declaration lifts copper
Texto: Copper prices jumped more than 3 per cent on Wednesday after Freeport-McMoRan, the US miner, declared “force majeure” on some shipments from the world’s second-largest copper mine.The declaration, which allows the Arizona-based company to walk away from contracted deliveries, comes after a month of an increasingly acrimonious strike at the Grasberg mine in Indonesia.Grasberg, which is 90.6 per cent owned by Freeport, produced 625,000 tonnes of copper last year, or about 3 per cent of global supplies. It is also one of the world’s top gold mines.Freeport said that lower production had “impacted our ability to fully perform our sales commitments”, confirming that it had declared force majeure on “affected” sales agreements for copper concentrates, the raw material used to make the refined metal.“The strike action at PT Freeport Indonesia has impacted production and concentrate shipments,” the company said. “Throughout the period, we have worked cooperatively with our customers on the revised concentrate production and shipping schedule.”News of the force majeure declaration at Grasberg spurred a rally of more than 3 per cent in copper prices on the London Metal Exchange on Wednesday morning, helping to erase some of recent months’ punishing falls. The benchmark contract for delivery in three months rallied to a peak of $7,785 a tonne, up 15 per cent from last week’s lows.Companies that had been due to receive shipments from the Indonesian mine would now have to seek supplies elsewhere and potentially drive prices up, traders said.Freeport said in its quarterly results last week that it had lost 32,000 tonnes of production due to strikes at Grasberg in the second quarter, and estimated that over the full year the strikes would cut production by about 45,000 tonnes.Nicholas Snowdon, base metals analyst at Barclays Capital, said the declaration of force majeure “would appear to indicate that the company are anticipating a prolonged period of disruption at the facility”. He added that the strike was “already contributing to a period of clear tightening in the concentrate market”.Grasberg, set in the remote highlands of Papua, has been the source of communal tension and deadly rivalry between Indonesian security forces competing for protection contracts and lucrative illegal gold-tailings rackets, relating to leftover ground ore. Gun attacks killed several Freeport employees last year when buses transporting miners were targeted by unidentified assailants.The situation is further complicated by a low-level insurgency seeking independence from Jakarta, which some analysts believe is gaining strength due to local opposition to Freeport’s presence and a vast wealth divide. Papua is one of the most impoverished and least developed regions in Indonesia, with average income far below the national average.As many as 12,000 Freeport workers taking part in the strike are demanding an increase of their $1.50 hourly wage and employment terms, which their union claims are the worst of all Freeport’s operations.“We are committed to being fair and generous to our workforce, and we are hopeful we can reach a resolution soon,” Richard Adkerson, Freeport’s chief executive, said last week.

Titular: Surging solar stocks take Nasdaq positive for year
Subtitular: HealthSpring shares jump on Cigna purchase
Texto: Surging solar energy stocks, and Oracle’s acquisition of RightNow Technologies, pushed the Nasdaq Composite index into positive territory for the year on Monday.First Solar was up 7.8 per cent to $57.95 and SunPower Corp was up 13.6 per cent to $10.04, after Chinese solar panel manufacturer Yingli Green Energy Holding reported accelerating demand from Germany and Italy.Solar stocks have suffered badly in recent months, on fears that debt-ridden eurozone governments will cut solar subsidies.Software company Oracle’s $1.5bn acquisition of Right Now, which values the “cloud-based” software developer at $43 a share, pushed Right Now shares up 19.4 per cent to $42.94.The prospect of dealmaking in the cloud space buoyed other names. Taleo Corporation, which sells human resources software to businesses, was up 7.9 per cent to $31.61. SuccessFactors, which markets business education courses, rose 9.3 per cent to $26.24.The Nasdaq Composite index was up 2.4 per cent to 2,699.44 at the close.The S&P 500 advanced 1.3 per cent to 1,254.20, its highest close since the start of August, and decisively above the 1,220 to 1,230 range where two previous rallies stalled in recent months.The Vix index of implied volatility in the S&P 500 closed below 30 for only the second time since early August. Wall Street’s “fear gauge” had been above 30 for most of August and September.The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 0.8 per cent to 11,900.03.“EU debt negotiations didn’t go off the rails over the weekend, and it appears that some progress may have even been made toward an agreement,” said Colin Cieszynski, chief market strategist at CMC Markets.The rally was broadly cyclical with material and industrial stocks in the S&P 500 up 2.3 and 1.7 per cent respectively. Both sectors were helped by a better than expected “flash” purchasing managers’ index survey in China.Alpha Natural Resources, which supplies China with metallurgical coal for use in the manufacture of steel, was up 9.5 per cent to $23.79. Copper miner Freeport-McMoRan was 8 per cent higher at $23.79.The defensive utility, telecom and consumer staples sectors were the only S&P 500 components to fall.Caterpillar surged 5 per cent to $91.77, after the company reported record revenues and delivered earnings per share of $1.71, a full 15 cents higher than the average analyst expectation in a Bloomberg poll.The company raised its 2012 earnings outlook by a fifth, and said global economic uncertainty had not fed through to demand for its earthmoving equipment.Shares in health insurer HealthSpring surged 33.7 per cent to $53.71, after rival insurer Cigna announced it would purchase the company for $3.8bn.The deal values HealthSpring at $55 a share, and would give Cigna access to HealthSpring’s customer base. HealthSpring sells premium insurance to customers eligible for Medicaid, the federal health insurance programme for retirees. Cigna shares were down 0.6 per cent to $45.34.The deal helped Humana, another health insurer focused on Medicare-eligible clients, gain 4.8 per cent to $79.93.In the property sector, Citigroup analyst Josh Levin released a note arguing that “the structural excess supply of homes is exhausting itself.“The inventory of existing homes for sale [3.48m in September] has been declining on a year on year basis for the past eight months and now stands at a multiyear low,” Mr Levin told clients.Although he warned the “shadow inventory” of homes in foreclosure could yet add to the housing stock, homebuilder shares continued their strong October rally.The SPDR Homebuilders exchange traded fund, which tracks the return on homebuilders listed in the S&P 500 was up 2.9 per cent to $16.49. The ETF has risen 30 per cent in three weeks, after hitting a low of $12.30 at the start of October.Lennar Corp, considered one of the healthiest of US homebuilders because of its low debt levels, was up 1.7 per cent to $17.02, a gain of 33.6 per cent since October 4. PulteGroup, a more volatile stock carrying high debt, was up 6.3 per cent to $5.21, a gain of 47.2 per cent since October 4.Commercial property service provider CB Richard Ellis Group surged 9.5 per cent to $16.74.Lorillard, the maker of Newport cigarettes, fell 0.6 per cent to $114.97 after earnings per share of $1.94 came in below average analyst expectations. Gross profit of $563m was $3m lower than the same quarter last year, as higher costs offset increased sales of cigarettes and higher pack pricing.Kimberly-Clark, the manufacturer of Kleenex and other household brands, fell 4.6 per cent to $69.65. Earnings per share of $1.26 were in line with expectations, but net income fell to $432 million compared with $469 million in the same quarter last year.Sprint Nextel was down 2.9 per cent to $2.69, as a judge weighed whether to dismiss the third-largest US mobile network’s opposition to the takeover of T Mobile by its AT&T.

Titular: Stocks firm as investors await eurozone rescue plan
Texto: Friday 2130 BST. Trading was upbeat but twitchy ahead of the European summit this weekend to discuss a support plan for the region.Better than expected US economic data of late and a generally well-received US earnings season is encouraging bullish strategies, with the brave also prepared to bet on a positive outcome when details of any Euro-package are mooted to be unveiled on Wednesday.The FTSE All-World equity index was up 2.2 per cent in a market that has been adding “risk on” positions as the session progresses.The euro rallied strongly after an early dip and was up 0.8 per cent to $1.3894, while the dollar index, which traditionally displays an inverse correlation to risk appetite, was down 1 per cent. Indeed, the buck at one point hit a record low versus the yen of Y75.78, according to Reuters.Commodities were firmer, with Brent crude adding 0.2 per cent to $109.95, while perceived havens, such as US Treasuries and German Bunds, saw sellers, nudging yields higher by several basis points. Gold was up 1.2 per cent to $1,640 an ounce.Wall Street’s S&P 500 rose 1.9 per cent to 1,238, its highest close since August, and above resistance at 1,230. Extra impetus came from well-received earning reports from General Electric, Honeywell and McDonald’s.The FTSE Eurofirst 300 advanced 2.5 per cent, with the banking sub-index leading the charge on a gain of 3.8 per cent, as investors reckon a support mechanism to stave off Eurozone sovereign debt contagion will be delivered within the next several days.Despite the broadly bullish mood, investors will be aware that any negative news, chatter or speculation over the progress being made by the eurozone to contain the region’s sovereign debt crisis could see sentiment turn on a dime.This has been a stark feature of recent sessions, with assets vacillating in response to reports that point to progress or disagreement.That said, it was noticeable that Wall Street on Thursday appeared able to escape the clutches of eurozone angst and carve out a gain based primarily on reduced fears that the US economy could face a double-dip recession.A surprise expansion in the mid-Atlantic region’s factory activity – it’s strongest performance in six months – bolstered investor stoicism, and it looks like that has been carried over into Friday’s session.Still, traders remain nervous. The S&P 500 may be at the top of its 2½ -month, 120 point range, but the Vix index, a measure of expected market volatility that is considered a good gauge of investor anxiety, remains elevated at 32.Earlier in the session, Asian markets posted modest gains as banks and technology shares were lifted by cautious optimism for a comprehensive rescue package for the eurozone in coming days.The FTSE Asia Pacific index is up 0.2 per cent. South Korean construction firms rallied as the death of Libyan dictator Muammer Gaddafi boosted hopes for the resumption of stalled construction projects in Libya, pushing the Kospi index up 1.8 per centTechnology shares in Tokyo and Seoul were initially supported by Microsoft reporting a modest profit gain and after SanDisk beat Wall Street estimates. The Nikkei 225 closed barely changed, however, typifying dealers’ reluctance to take big punts in case weekend Eurozone events scupper strategies.Gains in the region were limited by declines in resources stocks after Thursday’s sharp fall in copper prices, and this left Australia’s S&P/ASX 200 index with a loss of 0.1 per cent.…..Trading Post.To maintain financial health one should always listen to the doctor: Dr Copper, that is.The red metal is so named because it is considered most erudite in its forecasting of global economic activity. Copper is not immune to daily risk on/off switches but its fundamentals demand respect, argue its disciples.If true, global equity investors should be nervous.The Shanghai copper future was limit down – a fall of 6 per cent to a 16-month low – on Thursday. It rallied 1.5 per cent on Friday, but the recent stumble is a function of demand concerns rather than a reflection of supply increases.Freeport-McMoRan, the biggest quoted copper producer, this week cut its sales forecast for next year.A slower pace of Chinese growth is meeting worries over the economic health of the US and eurozone. Funding difficulties in China as Beijing seeks to restrict speculation are also weighing and this has contributed to the Shanghai Composite index falling on Friday to a fresh 31-month trough, down another 0.6 per cent on the day.Some western investors tend to be pretty sniffy about the SCI, but a drop to March 2009 levels should not be so quickly dismissed.Note, the US-traded copper contract has not matched the equity market’s bounce of the past few weeks. It is having a good day on Friday, currently up 5.3 per cent to $3.22 a pound, but has still lost 5.6 per cent so far this week.Additional reporting by Song Jung-a in Seoul.Follow the market comments of Jamie Chisholm on Twitter:@FTGlobalMarkets

Titular: Three shot dead near Freeport’s Indonesia mine
Texto: Unidentified gunmen killed three people near the Grasberg mine in Indonesia’s restive Papua province on Friday morning, raising the number of fatalities during a month-long workers’ strike to seven.The sprawling Grasberg mine contains the world’s largest recoverable copper reserves and largest single gold reserve. It is run by PT Freeport Indonesia, an arm of Arizona-based Freeport-McMoRan.The deteriorating security situation at Grasberg, where thousands of striking workers have blockaded supply routes and sabotaged mining installations, forced Freeport to halt production earlier this week.Antara, the state news agency, identified one of the victims in Friday’s shooting as Aloysius Margana, who has worked for Freeport on a contract basis for 20 years. He was an uncle of a prominent Indonesian legislator, Roy Suryo.Two of the victims were still unidentified. Indonesian police did not respond to repeated requests for comment.Two others were shot dead last week near the same site.Since July 2009, 11 people have been shot dead and 41 wounded at Grasberg. The mine has been plagued by communal violence, with accusations that rival security forces are competing for protection rackets and also control of nearby run-off streams that can carry gold “tailings”.Earlier this month, police shot and killed two mine workers while trying to control a rowdy protest by thousands of striking Freeport miners, who are demanding higher wages and better working conditions.Papua, on the western half of the island New Guinea, is a militarised and underdeveloped mountainous province that is off-limits to foreign journalists and activists. It was annexed by Indonesia in 1969, following a vote widely considered to have been rigged by the Indonesian military.Indonesia is enjoying its longest period of political and economic stability in recent history. But Papua remains a highly sensitive issue for the government of Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, the retired general-turned-president. A low-level insurgency has been waged for decades in the impoverished region, which is seeking independence from Jakarta. Dozens of political prisoners remain in jail for ties to the largely peaceful independence movement.Elsewhere in the province on Wednesday, Indonesian troops opened fire on thousands of ethnic Papuans demanding greater social rights, killing up to five.The incident occurred after about 2,200 police and army troops surrounded as many as 4,000 Papuan protesters. A declaration on self-determination was read out and a banned flag was raised, according to the Asian Human Rights Commission.“Following this declaration the security forces opened fire, allegedly as warning shots only,” the commission said in a statement. “Tear gas was used and security personnel from the army and police started dispersing the crowd and beating up numerous participants.”Hundreds of protesters were detained and at least 100 remained in custody, the commission added. Five were charged with treason and face possible life imprisonment.The commission said it feared for the safety of those in custody and called for an investigation into the killings.Indonesia security forces in Papua systematically torture and abuse prisoners , the UN has said.

Titular: Dr Copper showing barely a pulse of demand
Subtitular: Fall of 6% in Shanghai futures should leave global equity investors nervous
Texto: To maintain financial health one should always listen to the doctor: Dr Copper, that is.The red metal is so named because it is considered most erudite in its forecasting of global economic activity. Copper is not immune to daily risk on/off switches but its fundamentals demand respect, argue its disciples.If true, global equity investors should be nervous.The Shanghai copper future was limit down – a fall of 6 per cent to a 16-month low – on Thursday. The stumble is a function of demand concerns rather than a reflection of supply increases.Freeport-McMoRan, the biggest quoted copper producer, this week cut its sales forecast for next year.A slower pace of Chinese growth is meeting worries over the economic health of the US and eurozone. Funding difficulties in China as Beijing seeks to restrict speculation are also weighing and this has contributed to the Shanghai Composite index falling to a 31-month trough.Some western investors tend to be pretty sniffy about the SCI, but a drop to March 2009 levels should not be so quickly dismissed.Note, the US-traded copper contract has not matched the equity market’s bounce of the past few weeks.

Titular: Seagate deal hits Western Digital stock
Subtitular: Financials up on Morgan Stanley and BNY earnings
Texto: Hard drive manufacturer Western Digital sank on news that the European Commission had approved rival Seagate Technology’s acquisition of Samsung’s hard disk drive division.The deal could complicate Western’s own bid for Hitachi’s hard drive division, which would leave only three participants in the hard drive industry. But analysts said they expected the Hitachi acquisition to be approved by the end of the year.“The hard drive market is mature and PC sales growth is under pressure, so consolidation makes sense,” said Jason Nyoland, a technology analyst at Robert W Baird.Western Digital fell 9.3 per cent to $24.44 and is down almost 14 per cent for the week after saying on Monday it had closed manufacturing facilities in Thailand due to flooding.Seagate shares were off 0.4 per cent to $12.05.The S&P 500 fell 1.3 per cent to 1,209.88 as Apple fell 5.6 per cent to $398.62.The group missed earnings and revenue targets for the first time in several years on Tuesday evening. Despite Wednesday’s losses, Apple remains one of the few S&P 500 stocks to have made gains since the sell-off began in July.The S&P 500’s retreat marked the third time this summer a rally has peaked narrowly above the 1,220 mark.In a sign of profit-taking on Tuesday, investors pulled $3.26bn out of the SPDR S&P 500 ETF after the index had hit a 75-day intraday peak of 1,233.1.The Dow Jones Industrial Average was off 0.6 per cent to 11,504.62 and Apple weighed on the Nasdaq Composite, which was down 2 per cent to 2,604.04.Morgan Stanley, the second-largest US investment bank by market capitalisation, returned to profit, posting $2.2bn in earnings for the quarter ended September.A “debt valuation adjustment” – an accounting measure used by many US banks this quarter to bolster the value of their debt – accounted for $1.12 of the $1.15 in earnings per share.But many analysts had been expecting an underlying loss.Morgan Stanley surged as much as 6 per cent in the first minutes of the session, trading above $17.50, a value not seen since August. But the stock was only up fractionally to $16.64 at the close.Regional bank stocks had mixed performance on quarterly results.PNC, up 0.2 per cent to $51.33 and US Bancorp, down 1.4 per cent to $24.13, took advantage of the big banks’ retreat from consumer lending to expand high margin loan books.But Dallas-based Comerica fell 10.5 per cent to $23.13, as its net interest margin shrunk to 318 basis points, much lower than the bank had forecast, as the Fed’s Operation Twist drove down the yield of its mortgage-backed securities.Intel rose 3.6 per cent to $24.24 after posting record quarterly revenue and earnings per share of 65 cents, despite a 32 per cent decline in sales of its low-power Atom microprocessors, as Apple’s iPad reduced the market for netbooks.Freeport-McMoRan, the miner, reported net income of $1.05bn despite a shortfall in output due to strikes at an Indonesia mine.Earnings per share of $1.10 were 14 cents lower than the same period last year but beat analyst expectations. But shares fell 2.8 per cent to $34.38.The materials sector of the S&P 500 lost 3 per cent.BlackRock, the largest money manager, was down 4.7 per cent to $148.92 after reporting a near-10 per cent fall in assets under management to $3,345bn during September.Abbott Laboratories was up 1.5 per cent to $53.25 after saying it would split into two entities, one focused on research and the other selling drugs and medical devices.Apollo Group closed up 7.9 per cent to 46.74 as quarterly earnings per share more than quadrupled from the same period last year to $1.37. The college said it had improved retention.Defence group United Technologies Corporation was off 1.2 per cent to $73.26, though it reported an 11 per cent rise in profits compared with the same quarter last year and raised full-year earnings guidance.Bank of New York Mellon was off 1.2 per cent to $19.54 after it reported a 4.7 per cent rise in profit to $651m.Analysts were cheered that trust assets had risen 6 per cent from the same period last year to $25,900bn, suggesting the largest US trust bank is managing to attract customers despite facing a federal lawsuit for regularly overcharging for foreign exchange transactions.

Titular: Mine strikes cause fall in Freeport’s profit
Texto: Strikes at the Grasberg mine in Indonesia cost Freeport-McMoRan, the world’s largest listed copper miner, production equivalent to about 7 per cent of its copper sales and 25 per cent of its gold sales in the third quarter, the company said on Wednesday as it reported an 11 per cent drop in post-tax profit.Grasberg has the largest recoverable reserves of copper and the largest single gold reserve in the world. An eight-day strike in July and a second dispute that started in mid-September have cut copper production by 70m pounds and gold production by 100,00 ounces, Freeport said. At its average selling prices for the quarter, that production would have been worth about $420m.The Indonesian unit is operating with only about 60 per cent of its workforce as a result of the strike by union members, who are demanding an increase in their $1.50 hourly wage and improvements in their employment terms, which their union claims are the worst of all of Freeport’s operations.Set in the remote highlands of Papua, Grasberg has been the source of communal tension and deadly rivalry between Indonesian security forces competing for protection contracts and lucrative illegal gold tailings rackets.Richard Adkerson, Freeport’s chief executive, said in a call with analysts on Wednesday that the open-pit mine was now running at about two-thirds of normal capacity, and the underground operations about 80 per cent.However, Freeport has been reconfiguring its work on the site to focus on production from the higher-grade areas, and it expects to limit the lost output to just 30m lbs of copper in the final quarter of 2011, even if the strike continues to the end of the year.“We are committed to being fair and generous to our workforce, and we are hopeful we can reach a resolution soon,” Mr Adkerson said.Freeport, which began open pit mining of gold, copper and silver in the remote mountains of eastern Indonesia in 1990, now hopes to expand its deep-pit operations there, opening up new reserves.Mr Adkerson said: “Our resource available to us at Grasberg is going to be there; it’s a question of when we are going to be able to mine it.”The lost production caused by the strike contributed to a 14 per cent drop in copper sales– to 947m lbs – and an 18 per cent decline in gold sales – to 409,000 oz – compared with the third quarter of 2010.For the fourth quarter, Freeport expects sales to drop further, to 915m lbs of copper and 305,000 oz of gold.Net income was $1.1bn for the third quarter, down from $1.2bn in the equivalent period of 2010, and earnings per share fell from $1.24 to $1.10.The figures were above the consensus of analysts’ forecasts, which had on average predicted earnings of $1.03 per share, according to Thomson Reuters.Stronger metals prices helped lift operating cash flows 38 per cent to $1.8bn for the third quarter. The average selling price of gold was up 34 per cent on the previous year, at $1,693 an ounce, while copper was up 3 per cent at $3.60 a pound.However, with metals prices now retreating again, Freeport expects a slowdown in operating cash flows to about $1.1bn in the final quarter of 2011.

Titular: Metals and miners lead declines
Texto: Industrial metals and miners led the declines following news that China’s gross domestic product in the third quarter grew at its slowest pace in more than two years.China, which accounts for 40 per cent of global copper demand, saw its GDP for the three months to September grow 9.1 per cent year-on-year. The figure was down from the quarter before, slowing for three consecutive quarters.Copper for three-month delivery on the London Metal Exchange fell 2.4 per cent in European late morning trading to $7,279 a tonne. The red metal failed to respond to reports that Freeport-McMoRan was weighing up the options over its Grasberg mine in Indonesia, including the possible mothballing of the copper mine.Zinc declined 1.8 per cent to $1,868 a tonne, while lead fell 1.1 per cent to $1,939 a tonne.China data hit mining shares. Rio Tinto, which had gained ground at the start of the week on news of the streamlining of its aluminium business, was among leading decliners, down 5 per cent to £31.37, while BHP Billiton fell 2.8 per cent to £18.57 and Xstrata lost 3.4 per cent to 917.1p.Concerns about French banks and the health of the European economy also weighed on commodity prices. Crude oil gained, with the December ICE Brent benchmark up 99 cents a barrel to $111.15, and the November Nymex West Texas Intermediate advanced $1.96 a barrel to $88.34.Gold, which failed to break above the $1,700 level on Monday, retreated along with other commodities. Bullion was trading down 0.7 per cent at $1,658 a troy ounce. Despite the morning weakness, Standard Bank noted a fall in speculative shorts, adding that “confidence in gold could grow over the coming weeks”.

Titular: Strike forces Freeport to halt operations at Grasberg mine
Subtitular: Death toll in Grasberg dispute reaches five
Texto: PT Freeport Indonesia, a subsidiary of Freeport-McMoRan, the largest listed copper producer, has been forced to shut down all operations at its Grasberg mining operation due to strike action, emphasising the risks of deteriorating labour relations in the mining industry.Concerns about a fall in production and supply at Grasberg in Indonesia, the world’s second-largest copper mine, underpinned the metal, with the price of copper for three-month delivery on the London Metal Exchange rising more than 1 per cent to $7,660 a tonne in early European trading.Although copper later fell 0.7 per cent to $7,506 a tonne on concerns about the global economy, it saw support at the $7,500 level.Freeport, based in Arizona in the US, had been operating at “minimum production” at Grasberg since 12,000 of 23,000 workers went on strike last month to demand higher pay.The group also faces problems in Peru, where its union has broken off talks about a contract during a strike at Cerro Verde mine, which supplies about 2 per cent of world output.Freeport shares closed down 4.5 per cent at $35.11 in New York trading.At Grasberg at least five people have died since the strike began, including two men who were shot by police trying to control a crowd.Freeport said it was compelled to halt activities due to the unrest. It gave no date for a resumption.“These production activities can only be carried out when it is safe for employees to work, facilities are protected from sabotage, and PT Freeport Indonesia communities are able to get necessary supplies,” it said.“Until these conditions are met and maintained, PTFI must stop production activities.”The group is expected to update investors about the impact when it reports its third-quarter results on Wednesday.Freeport said that during the past week at Grasberg “there have been numerous illegal activities and violent crimes committed”, including blockage by workers of truck convoys carrying essential supplies, threats and intimidation of employees, trespassing, and illegal use of company property.Grasberg has the largest recoverable reserves of copper and the largest single gold reserve.Freeport-McMoRan’s miners in Peru launched a hunger strike on Monday, Reuters reports. They seek to pressure the government to resolve a labor dispute 19 days into a walkout at the Cerro Verde copper mine.Workers at Cerro Verde , which produces 2 percent of the world’s copper, pulled out of negotiations on Friday and said the labor ministry must define a wage accord. The union demands an 11 percent raise.“We’ve exhausted all our options and only the regional government can solve this,” said union leader Leoncio Amudio.Amudio said 15 workers were participating in the hunger strike.

Titular: Wall Street ends week with a spring in its step
Texto: In a week where the S&P 500 moved into bear territory, breaking below the 1,100 barrier for the first time in a year, Wall Street closed Friday in surprisingly good cheer, buoyed by strong retail sales data and a better than expected employment report.The 23 retailers tracked by Thomson Reuters posted a 5.1 per cent year-on-year increase in same-store sales for September, handily beating analyst expectations. The corresponding figure in September 2010, when the economy appeared to be in much ruder health, was only 2.7 per cent.Bellwether discount retailer Target posted a 5.3 per cent increase in sales and its shares rose 5.1 per cent for the week to $51.56.Limited Brands, which operates high-end chains including Victoria’s Secret, enjoyed double digit year-on-year sales growth. The stock rose 5 per cent for the week to $40.43.Bulk goods retailer Costco posted a 12 per cent rise in sales, although a decision to raise membership fees to offset higher commodity prices alarmed investors. Shares fell 3.8 per cent to $79.02, the second-worst performing stock in the S&P 500.The consumer discretionary index of the S&P 500 was up 4.1 per cent for the week. Since markets began to slide in late July, the sector has outperformed the broad S&P 500 by more than two percentage points.“We’ve had sixty days of bad economic news and falling markets, but consumers are still going out and buying stuff, and at a healthy clip too,” said James Paulsen, chief investment strategist at Wells Capital Management.But some retail analysts were worried resilient consumer spending may be debt-driven.“Taken as a point in time, September sales data do look very strong,” said David Strasser, hardline retail analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott. “But we question whether that is sustainable, if consumption is outpacing wage growth.”At 4.7 per cent in July and 4.5 per cent in August, the personal savings rate – the fraction of US personal income that is not consumed – has fallen beneath 4.8 per cent for the first time since 2009.The broad S&P 500 was up 2.1 per cent for the week, as European politicians appeared to inch towards a co-ordinated recapitalisation of the continent’s banks. An FT report to that effect late on Tuesday had sent the S&P 500 up 4 per cent in forty minutes.The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 1.7 per cent for the week to 11,103.12, and the Nasdaq Composite index was up 2.6 per cent to 2,479.35.But US banks ended a volatile week on a low note. Financial stocks in the S&P 500 were down 3.7 per cent Friday. A leak, late on Thursday, of a draft text of the Volcker rule, which would seek to stop proprietary trading by banks, caused alarm. By the week’s end, Tuesday’s euphoria at the prospect of European bank recapitalisations had also given way to worries about the speed of implementation.“As with everything in Europe it’s going to happen slower than the markets want,” said Richard Staite, US banks analyst at Atlantic Equities.Bank of America was down 3.6 per cent for the week to $5.95, after a 6 per cent fall on Friday. Goldman Sachs fell 5.5 per cent Friday to end the week down 2 per cent at $94.56. But despite its own 6 per cent fall on Friday, Morgan Stanley ended the week up 5.4 per cent to $14.24.That represented a turnround for Morgan Stanley, which was hit early in the week by reports that some banks were cutting exposure to the firm, as the cost of buying insurance on its debt hit 30-month highs.On Friday Morgan Stanley received a vote of confidence from analysts at its rival Goldman Sachs. Goldman’s options team put out a note recommending clients buy calls and sell short-dated credit default swaps to profit from a rise in the Morgan Stanley share price.“We believe concerns regarding its European swap and loan exposures appear overdone,” Goldman’s equity research analysts wrote in the note.Apple shares were down 2 per cent for the week to $369.80, after a lukewarm reception for its latest iPhone model, and the death of founder and figurehead Steve Jobs.Sprint was by far the biggest faller in the S&P 500, losing 10 per cent of it market capitalisation on Friday afternoon, to close the week down 10.9 per cent at $2.71, after its chief executive said the mobile phone network may need to raise additional capital.Sprint also announced it will upgrade to a 4G network next year, which sent the share price of its current wireless network provider, Clearwire, tumbling 32.2 per cent to $1.39.Material stocks were the best performers in the S&P 500 on renewed hopes for global growth. Copper and gold miner Freeport-McMoRan was up 11.7 per cent to $34.01. Cliffs Natural Resources, which extracts iron ore and metallurgical coal, used in the manufacture of steel, was up 9.2 per cent to $55.87.Wynn Resorts, the casino chain, reversed two weeks of heavy losses to close the week up 12.1 per cent to $129.06. Nomura analysts came out in defence of the stock, which had been hit by fears of a decline in Chinese junket tourism to Macau.Shares in Yahoo jumped 17.5 per cent to $15.47 over the course of the week after reports suggested Microsoft was preparing a bid for the internet portal. Microsoft denied interest but Alibaba remained in the running, along with various private equity houses.AMR, the holding company of American Airlines, was down 15.5 per cent for the week to $2.50, on reports the company is considering bankruptcy.Seed company Monsanto was up 18.1 per cent to $51.56 after reporting strong quarterly sales.

Titular: Oil prices rally as risk appetite improves
Texto: Commodities and crude oil prices rallied on the back of expectations of easier monetary conditions as the Bank of England announced further quantitative easing and following the European Central Bank’s announcement to boost liquidity.The Reuters-Jefferies CRB index, which includes wheat, copper and oil, gained 0.8 per cent, as risk appetite returned. Crude oil prices, which had gained ground on a surprise fall in US inventory data on Wednesday, continued their ascent. November ICE Brent, which briefly slipped through the $100 support level earlier this week, rose 41 cents a barrel to $103.28, while November Nymex West Texas Intermediate rallied 84 cents a barrel to $80.54.Harry Tchilinguirian, head of commodity markets strategy at BNP Paribas, said news of increased liquidity helped an oil market, which was already supported at lower levels by supply and demand fundamentals.Oil demand in emerging markets was holding firm, with little spill over effects from developments in the leading OECD countries, while non-OPEC supply growth, which had been expected to come on to the market in the third and fourth quarters of this year, had been pushed back, he said.Hopes that liquidity would help Europe avoid a recession boosted industrial metals. Copper, which is closely associated with industrial activity and economic growth, rose above the $7,000 support level.Copper for three-month delivery on the London Metal Exchange, rallied 3.9 per cent to $7,187.75 a tonne, while other industrial metals were firmer with aluminium up 1.6 per cent to $2,225 a tonne, and tin adding 5.7 per cent to $22,100 a tonneAs London Metal Week draws to a close, the market saw news coming out of Indonesia, where Freeport McMoran, the largest listed copper producer, faced strikes at Grasberg, and Zambia, where the new government on Thursday lifted a suspension on metal export permits.The Zambian mines ministry ordered the suspension in a document sent to exporters on October 4, saying new guidelines were to be introduced to the sector. The decision followed concerns that copper exporters have not been paying their full duties to the state and it was seen as an attempt to improve transparency in the industry. Officials said the move was in line with a presidential directive that all exports be cleared through the central bank.Lifting the suspension, government officials said the new measures would come into effect when the Bank of Zambia was ready. Zambia’s copper production is expected to be around 730,000 tonnes this year and international companies including Glencore, First Quantum, Vedanta Resources and Vale have operations in the country.

Titular: Conclusions from LME Week
Subtitular: Demand, prices, M&A and the sale of the LME itself dominate
Texto: The biggest annual gathering of the metals and mining industry, LME Week, is almost over. As we expected, the talk centred on demand and prices, the prospect for mergers and acquisitions in the sector, and the future of the London Metal Exchange itself.Demand: “It doesn’t feel like 2008.” How many times did we hear that? Everyone came to LME Week looking for signs that the global economy was heading back into a financial crisis and recession; but at least from the metals trading community, there was little evidence of that.In general copper demand appears to be holding up relatively well. Volumes at most companies are still up year on year – even in Europe. The current market is flat, rather than sharply lower as it was in 2008, with Germany still showing reasonable growth.In the US, demand growth has slowed. Freeport-McMoRan, for example, told us that the US copper rod market, of which they account for half, would register 3 per cent growth – down from 6 per cent last year, but still growth. There are pockets of weakness – for instance, the construction sector or the beverage can industry in North America – but there are also pockets of strength. Yet everyone is rightly concerned about the “external” factors. A senior trader said: “My metals market is holding well, so I do not understand why prices are falling.” He added: “But if Greece goes down, then I don’t know what happens”.China, as ever, is the focus of much disagreement. Some believe demand growth has slowed significantly – say, to 5 per cent – driven by tighter credit conditions and the slowdown in the rest of the world, which would curtail export growth. Gu Liangmin, head of the copper department at Minmetals, predicted that copper prices could fall below $6,000: “Real demand of copper in China is slowing, the import of copper is slowing, the export (typically from bonded warehouses to LME warehouses) is expanding fast. The import of copper (especially this year) is closely related with financing activity, not directly with real demand to a big extent.” Others think demand growth in copper is still running at 8 per cent and it is merely a question of time before the Chinese return to the market and restock heavily. Minmetals itself has provided some evidence of that with its C$1.3bn bid last week for Anvil, a copper miner.The physical markets are also providing evidence of tightness. Spot treatment and refining charges (TC/RCs) – a measure of the tightness of the market for copper raw materials – have dropped to the lowest in a year at about $35/3.5c. Annual contract TC/RCs are likely to be settled in the same range as last year’s $56/5.6, traders believe. Annual premiums for refined metal have dropped, but not drastically. Codelco is offering European customers $90, down from $98 last year. Negotiations with the Chinese haven’t begun yet, but traders are expecting premiums of $105-$110, down from $115 last year.So, what does the demand situation mean for prices?Diego Hernández, Codelco chief, gave us a prediction of $3-$4 a pound ($6,600-$8,800 a tonne) for copper prices in 2012. Another senior miner gave us a wider range, from $6,000 to about $8,800. There are probably about as many people who disagree with him on either side of the prediction. Many are expecting lows below $6,000 – such as Mr Gu of Minmetals – while plenty of others expect copper to retest record highs in excess of $10,000.One reason to be bullish – scrap. The so-called “urban mine” of recycled metal accounts for about one-third of global copper supplies. As prices have fallen, so scrap flows have slowed down dramatically, tightening the market even if demand is weaker than a few months ago. The scrap dealers we talked to said they were not going to release their commodity until prices recovered; they did the same in 2008-09, helping to push prices up.Reasons to be bearish – Greece. Yes, the country consumes almost no copper when compared to, let’s say, China. But a default could trigger a chain of events in Europe and beyond that could push the global economy into recession.M&A: With share prices down as much as 40 per cent year-to-date and valuation metrics such as price-to-earnings below the 5-year average, everyone is betting that corporate predators are about to strike.Bankers have spent the past four days pitching deals to clients. Yet executives and investors think that a round of M&A faces two main obstacles: first, few companies want to spend lots of money in an uncertain environment; second, sellers would be hesitant to transact at current prices, even if buyers offer hefty premiums.Nevertheless, there are signs that dealmaking is on its way. As the LME Week was entering its third day, New Hope Corp, the A$5bn Australian miner said it had received “numerous” takeover bids. Others are likely to follow. Bankers and executives speculate that ENRC, the London-listed Kazakh miner, and copper miners in central Africa, including Toronto-listed First Quantum, could be bid targets.Who would buy? Glencore boss Ivan Glasenberg is on almost everyone’s mind. For sure, he appears to have the appetite to grow his company – and now has the money after the $10bn initial public offering earlier this year.The mining sector has seen deals worth $85.4bn this year, according to Mergermarket data, putting the industry on track to match the annual record of $114.4bn set in 2006. Mining has accounted for 5 per cent of global dealmaking by value this year, the highest share since at least 2005.As one executive put it, if you have the money – and most of us have the money, unlike in 2008-09 – and you remain bullish over the long-term, why would you wait to buy assets? One reason to wait, said another executive, is that if Greece goes down, the sector may need all the money it has to weather the recession.But the key word about M&A has been “bolt-on” rather than the “transformational” deals of 2007-08 – we saw an executive rushing away from a group of bankers trying to avoid another deal conversation. Those transactions, typically worth $20bn-$50bn, either failed or saddled companies with debt just before the commodities sector crashed.What they want is “opportunistic” deals in the $1bn-$10bn range that add some value but don’t reinvent the companies. Executives – and bankers – told us to expect the big names quietly snapping up smaller players. So the M&A round would generate few headlines, but probably end adding more value.A final point relating to M&A: when Glencore floated its shares earlier this year, its market capitalisation was about 12 per cent lower than that of Xstrata. Today it is about 15 per cent larger as the stock of the trading house outperforms the miner. Glencore, of course, owns 34 per cent of the London-listed miner. Almost everyone said a deal was inevitable.LME sale: Will the LME be sold? If our straw poll of shareholders is anything to go by, the answer is yes.Only one company of those we chatted to was dead-set against a sale, regardless of the price. Almost everyone else, it would seem, is prepared to take a look at what is on the table and consider whatever hefty windfall is on offer.It would be possible for the naysayers to block a bid, however, since a potential buyer needs support of 75 per cent of the shares. That means Goldman, Metdist and JPMorgan, the three top shareholders, could between them prevent a sale.We don’t think all three are opposed to a sale, but there are other conceivable permutations that could block it. For example, if you exclude Goldman and Metdist (assume, for the sake of argument, that they will be happy to sell and realise their big profit on the shareholding), exclude companies without a big metals futures trading business, and exclude the small, privately owned brokerages (on the assumption that it may be hard for them to refuse a big cash offer – though perhaps that is not universally true), we calculate that about 30 per cent of the shareholding of the LME is in the hands of large companies with a strong metals business, which could potentially want to block a sale.

Titular: Crude oil falls below $100 a barrel
Texto: Crude oil tumbled to close below $100 a barrel on Tuesday for the first time since early 2011, pulled down by fears the global economy could be on the brink of another growth-sapping crisis.ICE November Brent crude, the global benchmark, dropped $1.92 to settle at $99.79 a barrel, the lowest close since February 7, before fighting stilled Libya’s oil wells. In New York, Nymex November West Texas Intermediate fell $1.94 to a one-year low of $75.67 a barrel.Analysts have been trimming estimates of oil consumption, as the economic outlook darkens and the European debt crisis intensifies. Oil partially recovered from steeper losses earlier Tuesday as Ben Bernanke, US Federal Reserve chairman, testified before Congress.Michael Wittner, US head of commodity research at Société Générale, said: “The bottom line is the oil markets are in the process of pricing in a weaker environment for economic growth and for oil demand growth.”Oil contributed to broad declines for commodities, with the Reuters-Jefferies CRB index falling as much as 1.4 per cent to the lowest reading since October 2010.Base metals softened just as LME Week, the largest gathering of the metals and mining sector, entered its second day in London. Copper for delivery in three months at the London Metal Exchange fell 0.1 per cent to $6,870 a tonne. Aluminium for delivery in three months dropped 0.5 per cent to $2,186 a tonne.Goldman Sachs, historically a commodities bull, reduced its Brent crude oil price outlook for 2012 from $130 to $120 a barrel and cut its copper forecast from $10,790 to $9,200 a tonne.“Barring a global financial crisis, we view the European turmoil as a headwind to global growth, which we expect will only take away some of the upside to commodity prices, not reverse it,” wrote Jeffrey Currie, Goldman’s head of commodities research.For some, Brent’s decline brought back memories of October 2008, when the benchmark collapsed from $100 to $65 a barrel at the height of the financial crisis.“The big question is: what phase of the cycle are we in now?” said Colin O’Shea, head of commodities at Hermes Fund Managers. “Currently it seems like this will be a modest slowdown. If that turns out to be reality, this should not be a repeat of 2008.”Gold was caught up in the negative sentiment, falling 3.2 per cent to $1,604.09 a troy ounce.The mining sector took another hit after Credit Suisse cut its target prices for leading companies a day after Morgan Stanley did the same. The natural resources sector is critical for London’s stock market, where it accounts for nearly a third of the blue-chip FTSE 100’s market capitalisation.Xstrata, the London-listed miner, suffered particularly, dropping 3.4 per cent. Rio Tinto fell 3.8 per cent, while BHP Billiton, the world’s largest miner by market capitalisation, declined 2.5 per cent. Anglo American slumped 3.4 per cent.

Titular: Miners set for increase in deals
Texto: Mining executives are anticipating a pick-up in deal-making with the sharp 40 per cent drop in sector share prices over the last 10 months flushing out corporate predators.Sector executives and bankers see the share price falls, which have intensified over the last three weeks, as opportunity to buy up scarce natural resources near the bottom of the cycle.This has pushed valuation metrics, such as price-to-earnings multiples, below five-year averages, executives told the Financial Times at the annual LME Week, the largest meeting of the mining and metals sector.The comments came as it emerged Qatar Holding, an arm of the gulf state’s sovereign wealth fund, is planning to create a standalone investment vehicle to buy stakes in, or take over, gold companies. It intends to invest about $10bn in metals and mining companies, according to people familiar with the matter.“Everybody is looking, everybody is analysing potential opportunities. I think there will be transactions,” Richard Adkerson, chief executive of Freeport McMoRan, the world’s largest listed copper company, said in interview with the Financial Times.KGHM of Poland, one of the top-ten largest copper miners, also said the current drop in metals prices and mining stocks had created an opportunity for dealmaking as it presses ahead with plans to spend $3bn over the next two years buying smaller rivals.“This is a good time to buy projects,” Wojciech Kedzi, KGHM vice-president, said. “For M&A this is an opportunity to get some good projects cheaper,” he added.The mining sector has seen deals worth $85.4bn so far this year, according to Mergemarket data, putting the industry on track to match the annual record of $114.4bn set in 2006. Mining has accounted for five per cent of global dealmaking by value so far this year, the highest share since at least 2005.The mining industry is in far better financial shape that in 2008-09, when a series of acquisitions at the peak of the metals prices surge saddled some companies with large debts. Now miners are sitting on cash piles after 18 months of high prices, and all still believe the recent correction is merely a blip in the longer-term bull market for industrial metals.However, one big obstacle is that shareholders would be reluctant to sell on a falling market, unless buyers offer hefty premiums.Alex Williams, director at First Reserve, the private equity company which focuses on natural resources and is a top Glencore shareholder, said the price correction was a “buying opportunity for long term investors”, but added: “The question is, is anyone going to sell?”However, mining companies and trading houses from Rio Tinto to Glencore to Minmetals of China have launched recently takeovers in the $1.5bn to $5bn range. Bankers said more deals were likely in the short term in spite of anxiety about the outlook for the global economy and falling commodities prices.Executives and bankers said that copper, iron ore and coking coal were particular targets as companies bet that prices would remain strong. Potential targets include ENRC, the London-listed Kazakh miner, Australia’s New Hope Corporation, and copper miners in central Africa, including Toronto-listed First Quantum.Mining executives and bankers said companies are likely to be prudent, embarking on single-digit or low double-digit billion dollars acquisitions, mostly in cash, as they want to preserve a strong balance sheet amid worries that the global economic growth could slow further, in which it demand and prices for metals.Catherine Raw, natural resources portfolio manager at BlackRock, said M&A activity was likely to focus on buying smaller companies, paying in cash, rather than in the gigantic projects of the previous boom such the failed BHP Billiton’s attempt to merge with Rio Tinto or Xstrata’s unsuccessful takeover bid for Anglo American.“No one’s is going to go out and blow their brains out because, in a market where getting finance is harder than it has been, you need a strong balance sheet,” she said.

Titular: Relief rally lifts copper and industrial metals
Texto: Copper and other industrial metals – which have been weaker for more than two weeks amid concerns about a Europe-led recession – staged a relief rally after Germany ratified greater powers to back the eurozone’s rescue fund.Commodities prices, which are closely linked to economic growth, have been hit hard by concerns that the eurozone debt crisis could push the continent into recession, dragging other developed countries with it. Copper, the most vulnerable in a downturn, suffered a heavy sell-off.Compared to industrial metals prices, which staged a recovery on Thursday – with copper for three-month delivery on the London Metal Exchange up 2 per cent at $7,210 a tonne and aluminium rallying 2 per cent at $2,245 – resource stocks failed to rebound.BHP Billiton, the world’s biggest mining company by market capitalisation, fell 1.9 per cent to £17.89, Xstrata declined 3.9 per cent to 856p and Glencore, the trading house, lost 3.3 per cent to 415p.Over the past few weeks, resource shares have been much more volatile than commodities prices, with equities leading the declines. Copper, for example, has fallen about 22 per cent since the start of September, but Antofagasta, the London-listed Chilean copper miner, has declined 29 per cent while Freeport-McMoRan, the US based mining group, has declined more than 33 per cent.Iron ore has only fallen 5.9 per cent since the start of the month but Rio Tinto, the mining group which sees about 70 per cent of earnings from the bulk commodity, has dropped over 22 per cent.“The equity market is very nervous about the global economic outlook,” said Grant Sporre, analyst at Deutsche Bank. “There has been a lurch down in mining equities, followed by the commodity complex – with the exception of iron ore – followed by another lurch down in mining equities.”The pattern of share price declines in resource stocks followed by commodities prices is similar to that of the market turmoil in 2008. However, analysts point to differences, such as the strong balance sheets of the large raw material groups.“The equities are pricing in too aggressive a fall in commodities,” said Ash Lazenby, analyst at Liberum. But with fears over the economy weighing on sentiment, “you will continue to get weakness until you get a real resolution in the eurozone,” he added.

Titular: Resources tumble on demand fear
Texto: Commodities and resources stocks have plunged to their lowest in a year after several miners warned that some customers were “unexpectedly” curtailing their orders.The comments, coupled with weaker activity in China and a warning by the US Federal Reserve that the risks of a slowdown were rising, spooked investors.The benchmark Reuters-Jefferies CRB index, a basket of commodities including wheat, copper and oil, fell 4.4 per cent to its lowest level since last December, while the FTSE 350 Mining Index dropped 9.2 per cent to its lowest since July.Energy commodities also dropped sharply. In late trading in London, ICE November Brent, the global benchmark, fell $4.87 to $105.49 a barrel, while Nymex November West Texas Intermediate tumbled $5.41 to $80.51, after falling below $80 in intraday trading.The drop in mining equities was exacerbated by a warning from Alpha Natural Resources, a leading US coal producer, that it was likely to ship less coal than forecast this year because of “unexpectedly curtailed customer activity levels”. Alpha’s comments follow that of Rio Tinto chief executive Tom Albanese, whose remarks about weaker demand caused jitters among investors.But analysts and mining executives said that investors were wrong in comparing the current slowdown with the global financial crisis in 2008.Michael Lewis, head of commodities research at Deutsche Bank in London, said that compared with three years ago there was less leverage in the system and that trade credit had not frozen.Goldman Sachs, bullish on commodities, reiterated its upbeat view. “We continue to recommend an overweight positioning in commodities,” said Jeffrey Currie, head of commodities research in London.Copper, which is closely linked with economic activity and sensitive to fluctuations in Chinese demand, hit a new low for the year. Copper for three month delivery on the London Metal Exchange fell below the psychological support of $8,000 a tonne, dropping 8.6 per cent to 7,620 a tonne.Other base metals were sharply lower, with tin falling at one point more than 10 per cent. Aluminium fell 4.4 per cent; lead dropped 6.2 per cent and nickel fell 10 per cent to the lowest level in a year.The health of the natural resources sector is critical for London’s stock market, where it accounts for nearly a third of the blue-chip FTSE 100’s market capitalisation. Commodities are also important in Sydney, São Paulo and Toronto.The fall in commodities prices dragged equities lower, with sharp falls in blue-chip stocks including BHP Billiton, the world’s largest mining company by market capitalisation.BHP fell 8.3 per cent; Rio Tinto shares were down 10.8 per cent, while Xstrata dropped 9.6 per cent. New York-listed Freeport-McMoRan, the world’s second largest copper producer, tumbled 9.7 per cent, extending this week’s losses to 22.7 per cent.In oil, Total of France fell 5.7 per cent while BP dropped 4.9 per cent.

Titular: Mood of cautious optimism takes hold
Subtitular: Business slowly accepts president as early fears of an authoritarian approach seem to fade away
Texto: Ollanta Humala admits he sometimes looks in the mirror and cannot believe he is president. Members of the exclusive Club Nacional, styled on the English gentleman’s model and situated a few hundred metres from the presidential palace in central Lima, feel the same way.It has been less than four months since Mr Humala, a former army officer with no government experience, unexpectedly won the June 5 run-off. His narrow victory over centre-right candidate Keiko Fujimori, the daughter of a former president, sparked a record sell-off on the Lima stock exchange.Since then, Mr Humala has dispelled many of the concerns held by investors – including the buttoned-down businessmen lunching in the Club Nacional’s chandeliered dining rooms. “There is a mood of cautious optimism,” admits one.Even by Latin American standards, it has been a remarkably volatile year in Peru. It is the world’s second-biggest producer of copper, silver and zinc, and one of the globe’s fastest-growing economies, having trebled in size since 2000.Electoral tensions really began to heat up in April, after centrist candidates split the electorate and Mr Humala scooped up their votes in the first round. Local debt markets subsequently clammed up.
